reviews.content: Though not as sci-fi heavy as the preceding Soviet film from 1972, Soderbergh's version of Solaris dives deeper into the human consciousness and focuses much more on the emotional aspects of love and death. The atmosphere of the movie can be described as strange and dreamlike, much because of the story being partially told through flashbacks. I can't stress enough how much I adore the chemistry between our main character Dr. Chris Kelvin (played by George Clooney) and Rheya (played by Natascha McElhone). Their relationship is front and center which makes the dive into Kelvin's mind and struggle to understand what's happening so much more engaging. The planet of Solaris takes a backseat and is not the main conflict of interest, instead it shimmers in the background as an unexplained mystery that makes it appear as alien as something can be.Having not read the novel, I can understand if some people are disappointed in this movie's lack of explanation towards Solaris itself. However, even if you've read the book I think there is enough emotional resonance in this film to appreciate the story being told. After all, it's a tale about how we as humans cope with life, love and death and why it's so hard for us to accept the loss of those things.

reviews.review_title: The most boring movie I have ever seen.
reviews.content: I have never seen the original version of Solaris, but after seeing the remake, I do not care to. This movie reminded me a whole lot of my senior Biology class. It lasted forever, it made no sense to me, and it was incredibly dull. Quite frankly, this movie is unwatchable. I have never seen a film creep along at a slower pace. For every 30 seconds of actual dialouge or action, we are forced to sit through 10 minutes of close ups on George Clooney's face, and views of stars out in space. This makes the plot incredibly difficult to understand because by the time you are done staring at the 10 minute closeup of George Clooney laying down on a bed, your mind has wondered and you can't really remember what is going on. I spent most of my time watching other people in the theatre. When the show started the place was nearly full, by the end of the movie almost half the viewers had walked out. Unfortunatly I was not one of them, although the thought had occured to me over and over again. When Solaris finally ended everyone stood up in unison and began piling out as quickly as possible. Bottomline, unless you are a raging insomniac who is in dire need of sleep, there is absolutely no reason to see this movie. Save your self the $7 and just sit at home and watch the paint dry on the walls.

reviews.review_title: A Classic for Science Fiction Drama...
reviews.content: This is an incredible film. However, it's not a film that will be approachable for everyone. It is thought provoking only to those who will put forth the effort of seeing the questions in this movie for what they are. It's a philosophical and emotional journey rather than an explosion filled action thriller. It is fantastically atmospheric and eerie, which is very fitting considering the subject matter.The movie puts forth a few questions to the viewer: What does it mean to be alive? Where did we come from? Who are we? And what makes us who we are? This is one of the most well directed films I've seen. It's rather surreal in feel and surprisingly doesn't have a lot of science throughout. It's like a long relaxing dream. I don't understand why it only has around a 6 on IMDb. The direction was great, the philosophy is thought provoking, and the movie itself is just very well done. I especially enjoyed the music therein, as it went from very relaxing to eerie and back again at certain points.The acting is also just perfect. I was very surprised how deep of a character Clooney was able to pull off. You can really feel his character's emotions and understand him.I actually wish the movie was a little bit longer, only to extend the atmosphere a little more. At an hour and thirty-two minutes it still feels too short. Yet, I think when a movie feels like it should have more length it is a very good sign, as it means I wanted to experience it a little bit longer.I think people that don't like this movie are just the kind of people that don't like to think about movies. The same people that don't enjoy movies like The Fountain. Maybe they expect all science fiction movies to be The Matrix, I don't know, but this is a wonderfully well done piece of science fiction that I think deserves a lot more credit than it receives. So, if you're not looking to have a movie shoved down your throat, and if you're looking for a strange, yet beautiful piece of art, I'd say this is one of your best bets.One last thing, I recommend that people see this twice, as I didn't understand a lot of it the first time through, so I missed a great deal of the philosophy beneath the surface. I also didn't understand the ending the first time I watched it, but I now understand it perfectly.

reviews.review_title: Quite possibly the worst movie I've ever seen
reviews.content: I like to think of myself as someone who truly appreciates a smart movie, e.g. one of my favorite movies last year was Memento. After hearing that this was more of a "cerebral" movie, I decided to give it a shot. The only thing "cerebral" about this movie was the droning headache from boredom I was getting. Near the end when Chris (G. Clooney) asks his wife "Am I alive or dead?" I was thinking to myself "WHO CARES??!!". This is one of the only movies I've seen at the theaters where I spent as much time looking at my watch as I did the movie.

reviews.review_title: Decent sci-fi flick uses thought instead of action to tell the story.
reviews.content: Review: I didn't know what to make of Solaris when I heard about it. Eventually, the previews told me I should give this a chance (with movies like 8 Crazy Nights and Treasure Planet, my options were slim). However, this movie is actually decent, in a weird, erotic sort of way. Clooney proves that he can stretch his acting range as a pyschologist dealing with the death of his wife, which he blames himself for (she committed suicide.) Imagine arriving to a ship and going to sleep, only to wake up with your wife who has been dead for years. Weird, eh? This movie does get REALLY slow at times, which in part is necessary for tension, but at times it draaaaaaaaaaaags. If you're not a fan of non-action sci-fi movies, then skip this. This is a movie that makes you think, but the violence level is zero. No action, unless you count sex. The performances are strong by the supporting cast. The ending is weird as well. You WILL have to watch this more then once to appreciate it. I'll appreciate it again when it comes to DVD next year.Final Score: 6.4 out of 10 (A decent sci-fi flick that relies more on thought then action. However, that could turn off most people who need that boost of action in their films.)

reviews.review_title: Touching the Outer Limits.......In More Ways Than One.
reviews.content: Steven Soderbergh's hypnotic ode to the original Russian production of the same name and even Stanley Kubrick's "2001: A Space Odyssey" is one of those immensely interesting projects that most will likely respect more than they like. An emotionally scarred psychologist (George Clooney) is called from Earth to go to a space station that is orbiting the titled planet. It seems that the crew members (Jeremy Davies and Viola Davis) are seeing visions of loved ones who have passed away. Clooney ends up being no help to them as he too is sucked into the mysterious environment and starts seeing visions of his dead wife (Natascha McElhone). Flashbacks, traumatic situations and highly emotional circumstances all combine to question God, death, the meaning of life and our place in a seemingly endless universe. The movie hugs you tight, but still keeps its audience at an arm's length with its sterile look and cold tone. Soderbergh, a truly magnificent filmmaker, reaches very high with this ambitious production and nearly succeeds completely. Overall "Solaris" is a deep thinking film that will intrigue and fascinate with its style and cinematic approach. 4 stars out of 5.

Director Steven Soderbergh continues to challenge audiences with his remake of the 1972 Russian epic, "Solaris". The original was a strange, very demanding movie, and the remake is no different, only much shorter. This is not a sci-fi film for the people who think "Independence Day" is a sci-fi film.The year is not given, but it is clear that the story takes place sometime in a pretty distant future. Something strange has happened aboard a space station orbiting a glowing ocean planet called Solaris. Before the crew cut off contact, they were exhibiting bizarre, seemingly paranoid behavior. Chris Kelvin (George Clooney) is summoned to go to the space station and find out what happened, and upon arrival he finds a trail of blood and two of the crew members dead.In a more ordinary film, this is probably where slimy, fanged aliens would start jumping out of the shadows, but this is not that kind of movie.Apparently, the planet of Solaris is conscious. It responds to tests as if it knows it is being observed. Most disturbingly, it has the power to reach into your subconscious and replicate any person, living or dead, from your life and put them right there on the space station. This is what Kelvin finds out when he wakes up next to his wife, Ryeah (Natascha McElhone), who killed herself years ago, but is now here, seemingly in flesh and blood. What is she? Is she human or alien? The catch is that she doesn't know, either. She exhibits emotion, believes she is Ryeah and doesn't remember dying. This obviously is a moral dilemma, as she is clearly not "real", yet is a conscious, emotional being who is seemingly the same person as his dead wife."Solaris" gets even much more complicated than that, as it inter-cuts scenes of Chris and Ryeah's tragic relationship on Earth with all the confusion aboard the space station, with the ever-present glowing ocean of Solaris seeming to silently observe them the whole time, like rats in a moral maze.The movie is undeniably slow-moving and strange, and a lot of people will not like it. Some people enjoy watching movies like this that force you to examine the very nature of humanity, and some don't. If you don't like movies like that, then you will not have a good time.But for a patient and open-minded movie fan, "Solaris" is riveting, powerful stuff.

Okay, so about three years ago, my mom and I were all by ourselves. We didn't have my annoying little sisters with us, so we decided to go see a kiddie-free movie at the new theater out east. I begged my mom that we should go see "Die Another Day", but she HAD to see this "Solaris". I should let you know, I am a die-hard Sci-Fi fan, but I was not in the least bit interested to see "Solaris".About five minutes into the movie, I thought that it was "okay". Ten minutes, it was getting bad. Fifteen I was lost, and at twenty, I about left the theater. I wish I would've so I could've snuck into "Die Another Day" but I thought "Maybe it'll get better". I was WRONG! I have pretty good taste when it comes to movies, so I was not used to seeing such plum-bad movies. I figured that it would get better, but I should've known once a movie goes bad, it stays bad! I was totally lost. There were so many flashbacks, and a lot of the shots were taken so you could only see half of the stuff that was going on.Overall: Never see this movie! I never did get to see "Die Another Day" and I wish I had now, and so does my mom. This was by far, the worst film ever made. I have one question too: "What was George Clooney thinking?" I would rather watch some dumb kiddie movie than sit through that two-hour monstrosity again!

Hats off to Steven Soderbergh, James Cameron and others who had the vision and courage to make this thoughtful film. A very moving meditation on love and loss. While it may suffer at the box office, which is no surprise, it is far better than the typical Hollywood drivel so prevalent at the mega-plex today.

reviews.review_title: My cat napped in front of the TV and I didn't care
reviews.content: I'm shocked both George Clooney and Steven Soderbergh were involved with this garbage. This is one of the top ten worst films I have ever seen. It was the most boring, incoherent garbage I've had the misfortune to witness. Like I said, my cat jumped in front of my television and I didn't even care that I couldn't see half the screen. That's how much I didn't care about this film! The plot is interesting, but the delivery and super-slow paced script ruined it. All these questions the characters kept asking, (over and over and over!) I didn't know the answers to and couldn't care less about them. This movie turned what was apparently a great novel into a boring space soap opera. No, I take that back, a soap opera is much better than this. I'd watch old episodes of General Hospital that this snooze-fest. I heard that this film got a rare "F" from Cinemascore, and it deserved it! Avoid this one at all costs!

I had high expectations for this George Clooney movie. What disappointment. The acting was wooden and the plot - what exactly was the plot again? Clooney should buy all copies if this movie and burn them.

reviews.review_title: The kind of science fiction film we should see more of
reviews.content: Steven Soderbergh's Solaris is my personal favourite sci fi film of all time. It abandons aliens, pyrotechnics and spectacle for a much more mysterious, soulful and ponderous approach, and at times seems like an impressionistic painting or a symphony set in the havens of space. It uses the ultimate vastness of space to ironically focus inward to the soul, and attempts to tackle some really difficult questions of identity, the origins of emotion, and the composition of a psyche and how others perceive it. George Clooney strips away his charm and suave antics for an emotionally raw, staggering portrayal of a broken man named Chris Kelvin, who finds himself spiritually and emotionally challenged beyond anything he has known, and the guy is a psychiatrist. After a brief, ambient prologue set on earth, Clooney is beckoned by an ambiguous message from his friend (Ulrich Tukur), urging him to journey to the distant planet Solaris, where strange phenomena is plaguing the members of a research vessel in the planet's orbit. Curiosity prevails and he makes the trip. Things get strange when he realizes the ship is in desolate disarray, and the crew members are disturbed by the arrival of 'visitors', replicas of deceased loved ones that appear out of nowhere. Chris's visitor is his deceased wife Rheya (Natasha Mcelhone), who has little memory or cohesion, and no answers for him. What does Solaris want? Why has it chosen to bring these lost loves back to the crew? Is it curious? Malevolent? Soderbergh's version of the book by Stanislaw Lem is the better version in my opinion. There is deep, deep contemplation at work here, that affects you on another level. The nature of a soul, in its complete form, as opposed to the image we reflect unto others with our actions, resulting in a version of ourselves held onto by our loved ones, incomplete and altered by their subjective perceptions. These intriguing themes are explored by the two leads with stunning depth and compassion. Clooney paints a vivid portrait of heartbreak and haunted memories. The underrated Mcelhone is angelic as both the visitor version, confused, emotionally stunted, and as Rheya herself in flashbacks, flawed, loving and scared of life's possibility. Visuals of the planet itself watch over the unfolding revelations, painted in deep gorgeous purples, sonic blues and ethereal, scintillating swaths of cosmic red. The look and design of the ship is built on practicality, and humble, muted colours. One of the key factors in the films atmosphere is the genius score by Cliff Martinez. It's a spacey, moody electronic jangle that hovers on the fringes of our awareness like galactic, auditory lace, and puts out a beautiful musical carpet of stars for the characters to wander and wonder in. The supporting cast is wonderful too. Tukur strikes a noble chord and nails his scenes. Twitchy Jeremy Davies gives his trademark weirdness. Viola Davis is dynamite, her terrified astronaut delving into scary primal places. Soderbergh gives his usual polished, mature approach to the visual aspect and direction. Sci fi films this ambitious, beautiful, deep and affecting all in one package are all too rare, but I constantly find myself wanting to revisit it's poetic, emotional grandeur and intimate, heartbreaking performances again and again.

Solaris was very good. A few people in the audience were expecting Star Trek or something similar. I was quite prepared for 2001:a Space Odyssey. And I wasn't disappointed.Its not as sprawling or epic as Kubrick's 1969 masterpiece, but the long periods of silence and the understated performances from the main characters are clearly Soderbergh's reminder to us of the vast quietness that exists in space. Clooney was excellent as the troubled psychologist dealing with the suicide of his wife. He is summoned to the Prometheus, a space station orbiting the moon of Solaris. The message is vague, but tells him that "strange things have happened, and the easiest thing would be to return home, but (they) don't want to". So he goes to help out.............It was captivating. The music is mesmeric and the performances by all the lead characters add to the general eeriness.If you want a thoughtful considered piece of movie-making then it's worth watching. If you like loud explosions in space, go for Starship Troopers.

reviews.review_title: Intriguing, Science Fiction drama about love, second chances and having trouble of letting go.
reviews.content: Chris Kelvin is a Psychologist (Oscar-Winner:George Clooney), who's still can't let go of his dead wife (Natascha McElhone). Who unexpected committed suicide, after an argument they had. When his friend (Ulrich Tukur) sends him a video message from an space station. He asked his friend to join him an mission in a space station "Solaris" for help him studying an unusual phenomena that happened. Once he arrived, some of the crew died mysterious including his friend. Only two remaining scientist (Viola Davis and Jemery Davies) are still alive. When Chris tries to convinced them to return to earth with him. Chris finds himself interacting with his dead wife. Which the crew are seeing people from their lives. For those, who's still alive on earth or not. This strange phenomena is coming from the "Solaris", they are studying and these "people" think, they are real. Which it's been created by the "Solaris". The psychologist and the scientist are trying to find an reason, why they are re-created from their mind and trying to find the secret of what "Solaris" holds.Directed by Oscar-Winner:Steven Soderbergh (Ocean's Eleven "2001", Out of Sight, Traffic) made an fascinating, psychological drama set in the near future. This is a remake of the 1972 Russian film, which it's based on a novel by Stanislaw Lem. Which originally that Three-Time Oscar Winner:James Cameron was going to directed but stayed on as one of the producers instead. Clooney gives one of the best performances here and he's has an strong presence in the film.DVD has an sharp anamorphic Widescreen (2.35:1) transfer and an good-Dolby Digital 5.1 Surround Sound. DVD has an good-hearted, humorous commentary track by the director and producer:Cameron. DVD also has two featurettes, trailers and an still gallery (Which is the entire screenplay, written by the director). This science fiction drama was an major box office disappointment and it was misguided by the studio. Still, this film certainly did have an cult following on DVD. Although since "Solaris" is a very serious film, it does have comic relief from Davies' performance. It is worth seeing but certainly not for all tastes. Panavision. (****/*****).

reviews.review_title: pretentious piece of crap, watch the original instead.
reviews.content: The original was very good - thoughtful and intelligent. Therefore I was looking forward to this very much - its been a while since we've gotten a 2001 type sci-fi movie, but unfortunetly what I got instead was a big budget artsy student film that constantly pulled me out of the movie every five minutes, thanks to Soderburgh's masturbatory direction. horrible horrible horrible! Go see the original instead. (which is twice as long, slow paced and in a different language but still managed to hold my attention better.)

'Solaris' is a remake of the Tarkovsky version from 1972. This one is much shorter and I think a larger audience will like this movie. It is a very fascinating movie, raising all kinds of questions.Director and writer Steven Soderbergh does a pretty good job, presenting us all kind of beautiful images. Some scenes did remind me of '2001: A Space Odyssey'. The arrival of the spaceship and the way George Clooney looks in his helmet. In a way it is the same kind of science fiction movie, both without the usual sci-fi action, both inviting the audience talk about it after it is seen.Soderbergh and Clooney take a risk with this movie and I like it. It is no block-buster like 'Ocean's Eleven' or a intelligent movie but still made for large audiences like 'Out of Sight'. For some reason Soderbergh can handle a lot of different things and Clooney as an actor can as well. Fortunately there are still people who like to take the risk to make this kind of movie.Like I said Clooney stars as Chris Kelvin. He must visit the planet Solaris because strange things are happening. When he gets there he meets two survivors both a little strange. The first is Gordon (Viola Davis) who doesn't want a discussion with him until "it happens to him". The other is Snow (Jeremy Davies), who seems to be nervous whole the time. After Kelvin's first night his wife wakes up next to him. She committed suicide a few years earlier. In nice flashbacks we see how they met and hooked up on earth, where it is raining in every scene. His wife, played by Natasche McElhone, knows there is something wrong. She remembers things but she doesn't remember experiencing those things. She is not an imagination by Kelvin. Snow and Gordon see her and both had their own visitors. From this moment the story gets interesting every minute.I can understand many people will not like this movie. It doesn't come with a real solution, it moves slowly, there is not much talking, most things are not sure. But it also looks amazing, is very fascinating and you can talk about it for hours. If you liked the last sentence you will like this movie.

reviews.review_title: Leave it alone if you are shallow
reviews.content: I'm pretty sure I am an anti-intellectual. I have read Solaris (in English translation). I have watched the Andrei Tarkovsky Russian movie. And now I have watched the Steven Soderbergh version with George Clooney.I think I understand the story, which is fairly simple. Kelvin (Clooney, in this version) is on planet-watching duty in orbit around the planet of Solaris. What nobody realises is that Solaris is able to feed off Kelvin's thoughts and memories and create, from them, a replica of Rheya, his late wife. And this forces him to re-examine memories which we would rather have left buried. So, much of what follows is flashbacks to incidents in their life together, and his reactions to the memories of then and to the replica Rheya now.It is an interesting science fiction notion and, to a more rigorous mind than mine, I am sure it is a very rewarding journey. Sadly, I have a complete absence of profundity. I am as shallow as a puddle. And, quite frankly, I found Kelvin, his problems, Rheya (both the original and the replica) and her problems, extremely tedious and boring.I've given Lem's novel a fair hearing, I think, having read it and watched two versions of it (in the grounds that I must be missing something, surely), but with a complete lack of engagement on each occasion.Solaris is not for me.

reviews.review_title: One of the best sci-fi films of recent years
reviews.content: Comparisons with blade runner are certainly apt in the case of this film, not least by virtue of its brilliant visual language, excellent acting and subtle themes. An eerie sense of mystery is maintained throughout, which had me gripped until the end. In fact I felt this film was at least half an hour too short, basically ending as soon as the central theme of Kelvin's desire to resurrect his dead wife - excellently realised by the two actors - is fully played out. I was disappointed, however, that the film failed to explore in any depth the presence of the other "visitors" on the ship, which did not fit neatly in to the "life after death" theme. Of course we are told "there are no answers, only choices", but I would certainly have appreciated a deeper exploration of the choices made by the other characters. It's one of those films to leave a bittersweet taste in the mouth; for example the decision not to include Gordon's "visitor" at all I found a bit galling at first, but in retrospect may have been a brilliant device. I would have liked to have seen more about the moral dilemma facing these humans in the face of the "facsimiles".Though the acting was brilliantly restrained, I did feel the script denied the humanity of the astronauts to some extent, and would have enjoyed just a touch more psychodrama. None of the characters appeared to take any interest in each other at all, and though this was certainly consistent with the powerful character of Gordon, and though Kelvin was understandably preoccupied, the incoherence of the third character was rendered somewhat pointless by the fact that the visiting psychologist made no attempt to do his job.While I would like to point out that simply visually suggesting Philosophical themes is not quite the same as exploring them, this is still an excellent sci-fi film that fits firmly in to the tradition of Blade Runner and 2001 and the original Solaris.

The story had to be remade. Nice questioning about life and reality. Is there another life form and what would we do with it? Good little film. The end is similar to the russian film of the same name and origin, but more virtual. Are we now in heaven in heaven?

Good movie but very slow. If I didn't read the book, I don't think I would have liked it.  By removing the main concept of the book, that Solaris is a planet with a world wide sentient ocean, we remove the explanation that Solaris represents an alien form that can not be understood by man. Solaris, in the book, is the entity that unlocks the human subconscious. So what are we left with, why are we seeing these people that can teach us so much about ourselves?  I don't know but it felt to me that this film was only a reflection of our society where everything is only about ME.  What is missing from my life, how do I fulfill my needs?  I love someone else only because I see myself in them.  Maybe we have to get over ourselves and look outside, leave our subconscious alone and move on. If we weren't so self absorbed we might find a real reason for existence.

reviews.review_title: Easily the worst movie of all time
reviews.content: What can be said about this ridiculous piece of garbage? Guy goes to space, ghost if his dead wife appears, guy wants to stay with ghost and forget his life. Literally the worst movie I ever bought. This makes the star wars prequels look like masterpieces

I must say not right off-hand, this is not a bad film. I'm giving it a 6 out of 10. But, it could have/should have been a lot better. Soderbergh is one of the most talented directors of his generation. He puts out an enormous volume of work. In fact, within the last 12 months, he has also released "Ocean's 11" and "Full Frontal," the later of which I have not seen. "Traffic" was a riveting film. No one could argue with that. But, "Solaris' was not really a project suited for Soderbergh's talents. He seems to fare better with simple real-to-life films, "The Limey" is a great example of this. "Solaris" is also dwarfed by Tarkovsky's original, which is an enigamtic as hell yet masterful piece of work. This film lacks the depth of imagery of the original, and it is really hard to Americanize such a film which was clearly very Russian in its themes when it came out in 1972. There is some sex here, and modern special effects wizardy than you don't see in the Tarkovsky film, but it doesn't make it any more memorable. But, I think it is a noble failure, and certainly proves Soderbergh and Clooney are not afraid to take risks, alas they did it much better in "Out of Sight." Still one has to look forward to this talented director's next project, let's just hope it will not be based on a movie that's been done before.

Solaris is a film that probably would only be appreciated by hardcore George Clooney fans. If there are such fans, that is. Hey, at least you get to see his butt twice. The butt shots, however, may be some of the more interesting details of this film. The film touches on some interesting ideas and will definitely pull at your heart strings a little. Unfortunately, the sum total elements of the film are only slightly engaging.As far as the plot goes, imagine the film Event Horizon. Now take out the gore and suspense. Turn up the emotional issues for the ladies out there, and you pretty much have Solaris. Clooney plays some sort of a psychiatrist who is called out to a space station to examine some of the odd goings on experienced by the crew already there. It seems that the nearby moon "Solaris" is playing mind games with the people sent to observe it. Basically, the moon can create clones of loved ones for each person that comes to close to it. Clooney, after his first night in the space station wakes up with a clone of his dead wife, for example. Another crew member is visited by a clone of his son. Another by a clone of himself, and so on. Clooney is still very much in love with his wife who committed suicide back on Earth, and now finds himself unable to say goodbye to a woman he knows is not really nor should be there with him.Rather than focus in depth on any possible scientific explanation, the film takes the emotional road more than anything else. We feel Clooney's pain, and that of the other crew members. That leads to a depressing experience watching this film. The film cheats in terms of its futuristic settings by having the majority of its shots be internals. The few externals we get are impressive (Jim Cameron was on board as a producer), but there should have been more of them. Also, too much time is spent with flashbacks to Earth where only people's clothing shows any sense of a futuristic setting. And once again, there are too many internal shots and the sense of wonder that should be found in a science fiction film is all but lost.This is one of those "high concept" sci-fi films, so we are left with some big time ambiguity toward the end. It worked for Stanley Kubrick, but not so well in this case. At only 99 minutes, the film seems half an hour longer. The character played by Jeremy Davies was most certainly meant to be weird, but he comes off more annoying than anything else. The scenes with him are like running over a big speed bump you weren't able to avoid.The film lost a small fortune at the box office, and I find that unfortunate. Not that Solaris is a good film, but it proves once again that films which don't pander to those with tiny brains often fail to make any money.The film had potential, but will ultimately go down as a failure. Too bad. 5 of 10 stars.The Hound.

I love the performances in this film. The film takes you on a somber ride of love and loss. Clooney plays a doctor who has lost his wife. Spiraling in sorrow he takes a job flying to a mysterious planet called Solaris. Clooney is a shrink and it seems that the crew near Solaris have some mental issues. Upon his arrival he discovers that his friend who had asked him to come committed suicide and what's left of the crew aren't the cabin buddies you would want. Soon we find out why. It seems that Solaris can make the dead live again. Each character is met with a deceased loved one. Clooney's backstory is shown in timely flashbacks as we meet his "wife". This haunting story is a great sci fi drama with plenty of chills.

A remake of a little-known (that, of course, is now on DVD) Russian film, Steven Soderbergh's Solaris is a hauntingly beautiful sci-fi masterpiece that borrows from other films, such as 2001.George Clooney is Chris Kelvin, psychiatrist. In the futuristic world of his that doesn't get too over-the-top (such as Minority Report), he must go and try to solve bizarre occurings that are happening on a space station that is around the planet Solaris. He goes up, and, of course, sees a vision of his dead wife Rheya (Natascha McElhone). Soon he becomes transfixed and believes that she is the real deal, while other members Snow (Jeremy Davies) and Gordon (Viola Davis) try to convince him that it's a "visitor" from Solaris. Oddity ensues.This movie is unlike any others I have ever seen. Unlike the mindless blockbusters in the summer or the drek of the fall/spring, this movie is an original piece of work that really makes you think. Don't put your mind on hold. As soon as the art begins, you're transfixed with the escapades of Chris and co. Going into it, I was feeling somewhat apprehensive, because of the mixed review it has been garnering. All of the nay-sayers must not be able to think deeply and consider The Animal the greatest movie of all time.Clooney gives a compassionate performance, while McElhone is also incredable. The supporting characters were great and we can hope that their names go out in the future. The sweeping cinematography was so magnificent-the turns and the flashes and everything else. Its 99-minute runtime seemed long, but I wished it could have been longer.The music score proved that you don't need large booms to make effective. In fact, the point is made with silence a lot of times. The ending was perfect. It isn't cut-and-dry, but also it isn't so muddled and mucked up. It's open to debate, like all good movies should be. You can't really argue about Eight Crazy Nights. Like most classics, the ending is left to the imagination (2001 comes into mind again).Solaris is a spectacular achievement of mind and body with superb acting and an awesome script that leaves much to the imagination. Unfortunately, most audience will not like it because it isn't clear and they don't want to think.My rating: 10/10Rated PG-13 for sexuality/nudity, brief language and thematic elements.

George Clooney plays psychologist Chris Kelvin, who's sent to a bizarre world into space.There he meets Dr. Gordon (Viola Davis) and Snow (Jeremy Davies).He also finds his wife Rheya (Natascha McElhone) from his bed.The only problem is she's supposed to be dead.Steven Soderbergh's Solaris (2002) had be captivated straight from the beginning.The movie's based on the novel of Stanislaw Lem's, who sadly passed away recently.The Oscar winner George Clooney (Syriana) does an excellent job in the lead.And so do all the others.This truly is an interesting movie.And it is that till the very end.There's something for the sci-fi lovers and those who like some romance.

reviews.review_title: A Thin Red Line in Space
reviews.content: This movie was quite good. It's editing style was unique in many ways and the atmosphere embodied the melancholy I imagine one must feel when stuck on a space going vessel alone. Its a movie that is saturated in nostalgia from which it draws most of its powers, memories of lost love back on earth. The movie renders the emotional juxtaposition between the living and the dead and the loved and the lost. Its nowhere near as psychologically or politically profound as the original film, as a stand alone movie it is quite enjoyable just the same.

I have not seen the original 1972 Solaris movie, nor have I read the book so these comments assess the 2002 Solaris movie as an independent story without regard to its originality nor adherence to the book. Perhaps the 1972 telling is better in conception and execution and if you choose to see only one Solaris, maybe the original is the better choice, or maybe not. But in either case, the 2002 Solaris definitely has significant merits. Two days after viewing the movie, I find myself still thinking about it.So, should you watch this movie? Is it good entertainment or a waste of time? That depends, of course, on your expectations so let's help set some expectations. More than most, this film requires you to be in the right mood; if you're in the right mood with the right expectations it is a pretty good movie. But if you're not, you certainly will not like it.Is it science-fiction? It has a science-fiction setting, and some science-fiction themes running through it but those themes are minor compared to its main themes and are not explored much. There are some acceptable special effects and science-fiction imagery but they provide a counterpoint to its brooding atmosphere more than anything else.This is a fairly serious film, with central themes exploring the "human condition" and human nature. The sci-fi setting allows the storyteller to put the characters into unusual situations that just don't otherwise occur, at least in the here and now. The characters will act and react according to how the storyteller, relying on her/his own sense of human nature, thinks they will. So it's a sort of thought-experiment. If the storyteller has real insight, the characters' actions will seem reasonable to us, although perhaps only after some thought because the situations are certainly unusual.What else does Solaris offer the viewer? It is one of a short list of "puzzle" movies. Such movies tell their story without any real third-party narration. They are seen entirely through the eyes of one or more characters; the audience is required to sort out the objective facts of the story from the subjective narration. Well, maybe this isn't the best definition, but it's somehow part of it. I'm thinking of, but not comparing Solaris to, movies like Sixth Sense and Identity. What was going on? Is that scene a flashback or occurring in the present or a dream? Does just the protagonist see that or does everyone? There was no objective narration; it was presented as an intellectual puzzle to the audience to solve. (To digress momentarily, I would argue that Sixth Sense presented enough clues, and presented them early enough that figuring out the solution to the puzzle was possible early in the movie. Whereas Identity did not present enough clues until late for the puzzle to be solved, thus becoming more of a surprise-ending movie.) Solaris is rich in a brooding atmosphere. And it has a slow pace, perhaps to give the audience time to think about each clue before the next is presented.So why watch Solaris? If you're interested in solving a "puzzle" movie, one that will possibly continue to engage your thoughts after the movie is done, if you're willing to explore some very serious themes about human nature and the human condition, and if your mood matches the brooding atmosphere and slow pace, then watch, puzzle, cogitate and drink it in.Is it a good movie? Within the constraints of the above, it is better than most. My chief praise for the storytelling is the way it continued to periodically deliver us puzzle clues, unlike some other movies which deliberately withhold the clues. And I was also pleased that there was a solution at the end, consistent with the clues and with the story pushing us towards it - although the interpretation of that end solution is open to discussion. So, as an intellectual puzzle, a good challenge but a fair one.I really enjoyed the acting and somewhat enjoyed most of the cinematography. I did not enjoy the music quite as much as most viewers posting here seem to have, but it wasn't jarring nor distracting. I also found the volume of the soundtrack uneven, so make sure you have your remote handy. And the pace could have been picked up just a little, but not too much or else it would have lost its atmosphere. Overall, an 8 out of 10 but not for everyone and make sure you're in the right mood.Hope this helps.

I have never walked out of a movie before, until now. My nephew and I just couldn't take another minute of the boredom. This movie is so slow, so short on conversation, just plain bad. I think they were very deceptive in their advertising for this movie. I kept falling asleep, even during the Clooney shots, so you know that was a sure sign I was bored. I hope I can save someone from spending $13, take a free nap at home. I say save the money at the video store too, not even worth the $3.

Having just watched the trailer for Steven Soderbergh's remake of Andrei Tarkovsky's Russian sci-fi classic, it seems to be some kind of action-horror hybrid. In fact, it's a solemn psychodrama about a psychologist named Chris Kelvin (George Clooney) who travels to a research station orbiting a planet called Solaris, where his late wife is brought back to physical life by an unseen alien intelligence.Tarkovsky's creeping meditation is more conversational and a (very) good hour longer than Steven Soderbergh's terse remake. Perhaps if Soderbergh and (producer) James Cameron had known it wouldn't break profit, they'd have gone easier in the editing room. Or perhaps they wouldn't have made it at all, which I suppose might have saved us from Ocean's Twelve.Tarkovsky's vision is my favourite of that director's films, and is also, arguably, the most accessible. It contains a more straightforward narrative than The Mirror, a slightly quicker (though not quick) pace than Stalker, and it's less dense and stagey than The Sacrifice. I feel it's the most successful blend of story and character in Tarkovsky's canon; the best balanced both emotionally and philosophically.Soderbergh's version, while seriously truncated, is an intelligent and often elegant work. Gone are the former filmmaker's Oedipal motifs, the existential monologues, and the weightless ballet. This is a taut film about the romanticising, catastrophising power of memory.Soderbergh dispenses with the now infamous 10-minute car journey sequence taken by Henri Burton (Vladislav Dvorzhetsky). Is Burton's car journey a reference to Bowman's "Stargate" experience in Stanley Kubrick's 2001: A Space Odyssey? Later, aboard the space station, Snaut (Jüri Järvet) makes a speech questioning whether man should be exploring new worlds before he has learned to truly communicate with his fellow man. Burton's terrestrial "journey", after his experience with Solaris, is every bit as profound as Bowman's.Natascha McElhone, while not the match of Natalya Bondarchuk, who acted everyone off Tarkovsky's screen, delivers an eerie, uncanny performance as the almost-human Rheya, "remembered wrong". Clooney's Kelvin is a more glaring, shell-shocked presence than Donatas Banionis - whether you prefer the former's range to the latter's subtlety is up to you; each belongs to their own film.Soderbergh regular Cliff Martinez provides the bubbling, electro-orchestral score, lending the images a delicate sense of the lost, the wistful, and sometimes the dread. Where Tarkovsky's script was as cold and sprawling as space itself, Soderbergh's is warm and focused. And as for the ending - well, let's just say that the young buck doesn't try and take on the elder directly, choosing instead something softer, less awesome, yet still ambiguous and fascinating. Which fairly sums up the film, I think.

reviews.review_title: I loved the movie, the music was amazing too!
reviews.content: Man, I loved this movie... George C's acting was brilliant, and man, for a minute there, I felt so awful for that guy. I dunno how we're supposed to take movies, but I didn't watch it like some summer flick which isn't supposed to make sense...this movie is DO deep! (Even though its got elements of 2001: A Space Odyssey)And the music by Cliff Martinez...man, its really haunting, and in some ways, grows on you...especially First Sleep...I really don't care what everyone else thinks, I sure loved this movie. Oz

Solaris is a good romantic sci-fi movie that will have you thinking about the "letting go" of someone you love. *****************Spoilers************************ Questions the film raises: "If you had a second chance to be with the person you love after their death - would you take it knowing it is not actually that person?""Could you separate yourself from what is reality and what is seemingly real if the vision seems perfectly real to you even though you know it is not reality?" ***************************************************A very good movie for those that are interested in romance and metaphysical concepts as well as science fiction. 8.5/10

For the last couple of years, film audiences have gotten Science- Fiction films mixed with Science-Fantasy.  STAR WARS, LORD OF THE RINGS and MATRIX are Science-Fantasy, where 2001,A.I.: ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE, and MINORITY REPORT are Science-Fiction.  Science-Fantasy is more about locations, worlds, legend, and creatures/species.  Science-Fiction is more about taking the emotions and thoughts of the human mind that is explaining the philosophy of human existance.  Where more questions are given than answers provided.  Such as 2001, what did the monolith represent?  A.I., can a machine be intelligent enough to have emotions?  MINORITY REPORT, should the technique of preventing a crime still be used when people can possibly change their mind and not commit the crime?  Steve Soderbergh's lastest masterpiece, SOLARIS, ask the question, can a person love a being that looks, acts, and has the memory of a deceased loved one, but really isn't that person?SOLARIS is based on the Stainslaw Lem novel that was made into a long, but very well done film by Russian director Andrei Tarkovsky.  The story is set in the future, psychartrist Chris Kelvin (George Clooney) who has been suffering for the last couple of months after the sucide death of his wife Rheya (the very beautiful Natascha McElhone).  Chris is asked to go out to the space station that is above the water planet of SOLARIS where all but two of the crewmen have died.  When Chris arrives on SOLARIS, he sees that the two survivors, Snow (Jeremy Davis) and Helen Gordon (Viola Davis), are still having psychological sufferings.  As Chris investigates with what happened at the station, he wakes from sleeping one time to see a person or creature that is exactly the splitting image of the deceased Rheya.  In one of the most heartbreaking scenes in cinema, Chris dismisses this person or thing being his dead wife back from the dead and sends her out into space as he breaks down into tears.  Then a few hours later after Chris goes to sleep again, the appearance of the thing that looks and acts like Rheya appears again.  And should Chris believe that it is Rheya back from the dead?  Or is this a hallucination that is created by Chris' mind?SOLARIS is like Kubrick's 2001: A SPACE ODYSSEY, in being a film that is full of philosophic questions.  I feel the reason why nimrods are dismissing and getting angry with SOLARIS is that they believe it will be as fun filled like OCEAN'S ELEVEN, or action packed like ALIENS since Soderbergh and James Cameron worked on the film.  It's not.  If there is any movie where your brain is required to be used before seeing the movie, while seeing the movie, and after seeing the movie, SOLARIS is that film!  If you don't like using your brain while watching a movie, then catch the next showing of DIE ANOTHER DAY or MAID IN MANHATTAN.SOLARIS is a film that proves that Steve Soderbergh IS one talented and versatile director.  Most entertainment shows and film audiences think of Soderbergh as the director of easy to understand films like OCEAN'S 11 and ERIN BROCKOVICH.  But this is the same brillant mind behind complex films like SEX LIES & VIDEOTAPE, THE LIMEY, and TRAFFIC.  While I personally find TRAFFIC to still be Soderbergh's best film, a hair-line fracture behind TRAFFIC is now SOLARIS.  I was so glad and pleased to see that Soderbergh respected the story and sci-fi genre by making SOLARIS into a highly intellectual film where thoughts are required, characters are the key element to a film, and technology and location are used with what they should be used for, background support!Georgy Clooney proves that he IS one of the best and underrated actors working in Hollywood.  Clooney does a fantastic job with his acting of the in-pain and confused Chris Kelvin.  But the scene that really got me emotional was the scene when Chris breaksdown in tears.  Natascha McElhone, I have always seen to be a very beautiful and underrated actress that should be given more leading roles.  In SOLARIS, McElhone manages to have one can't help but to think about their significant other (being male and female) and just wanting to love them even more.  Jeremy Davis does a fantastic job as the some-what disturbed and confused Snow, who might or might not have to answers to the happenings on the station.  And Viola Davis is good as the strong minded and conflicting Gordon.If SOLARIS proves anything, it's that Soderbergh, unlike most Hollywood directors, hasn't sold out to the evils of box office success, and continue to make films the way he wants to make them, and tell the stories the way he wants to tell them.  Why are people walking out of this movie angry and upset?  I believe it is because the film requires a lot of thought.  This same exact thing reminded me of a film that was released last year that I loved but people looking for a brainless film hated, VANILLA SKY.  And for those who hated VANILLA SKY, then stay away from SOLARIS.  But for those who like intelligence and symbolism as a main ingredant for a film, then SOLARIS is the ideal film for you.   Right now, most people will be dismissing SOLARIS as a slow, weird, and pointless film.  But ask me this question, what movie will be more talked about and praised twenty years from now, SOLARIS or XXX?  Only time will tell, but I'll be hoping it's SOLARIS. Since SOLARIS is becomming to be a box office failure, hopefully like another intellectual sci-fi film that suffered the same fate, BLADE RUNNER, SOLARIS, WILL be the next cult favorite.  This is one of the best films of 2002, and please see SOLARIS the way the film should be seen, on the big screen.  ***** (out of five) ONE OF THE BEST FILMS OF 2002!!!

The film is a MASTERPIECE.I still don't know what I think of it but I think its a masterpiece.Its been ages since I've seen the Tarkovsky film, not since it came on tape had I watched it from start to finish. I have the DVD but the last time I actually tried to watch it was on IFC when sunspots were messing up reception. I gave up when the picture kept skewing.Regardless of when I saw the first film it has haunted me ever since, its mediations on memory and going home again have stayed with me since I saw the film some ten or fifteen years ago. I'm so haunted by the film I was curious what Soderbergh and Cameron would do with the film.The plot essentially is the same as the first film, which is such a stripped down version of the novel by Stanislaw Lem that he all but disowned it.Actually the film follows reasonably closely Tarkovsky's film for the first 35 or 40 minutes before adding new bumps to the story that spin it off into new directions.What the film is about is a meditation on love and god and existence and other stuff. Its an equally valid take on the story as Tarkovsky's and equally intriguing.Of course the film bombed- with the people involved people in America wanted action.But there is none, or little. There is more alluded to than in the first film, but basically this is 95 minutes of people talking and brooding and emoting and simply being and trying to come to terms with life. There is no car chase or shoot outs or anything other than a planet, two spaceships and people. This is a film that requires an investment on the part of the audience and if you can't or won't work with it and meet it half way you're going to think its awful.Yes its pretentious twaddle but it still is asking some very interesting questions and providing no answers.I can only imagine what people going in expecting a scifi thriller made of this film which is like the best scifi not really about the sci or the fi but about us here and now. Soderbergh and Cameron had ideas they wanted to explore , ideas which simply could not work in a realistic setting and so grafted them into a scifi story which would allow their ideas to grow.No the film is not perfect. There are bumps and jumps and oddities, at least I think their are since I saw this in three parts broken by two interruptions. But flaws or no the ideas flow through.If you can see the film letterboxed the compositions are very deliberate and balanced. Also see if you can see it with a good sound system because the sound, the music mostly creates and excellent mood and audioscape.Go in clear minded and know that you may have to see it a second or third time simply because its similarities to the first film are at times distracting since you lean towards one way while the movie goes the other.What is the plot, I hear you asking...Kris Kelvin goes to a space station around the planet Solaris to investigate strange happenings there. Things become even more complicated when his dead wife shows up.Its really not much more than that. I could tell you the whole plot, and even then it wouldn't make a damn bit of difference since the plot is incidental to the discussions.Forgive me I'm still pondering this film over an hour after the fact...If you love to think or question see the film. If you love films with out any answers see the film.If you want it all explained, then stay away, this is not for you. The same thing if you want a film that is more than talk.If you are adventurous and open see this movie....

When discussing what is out there in the universe and beyond, people often bring up very compelling questions. Unfortunately, the most intriguing ideas about the cosmos haven't translated that well to movies, making the sci-fi genre a long line of movies essentially about blowing up aliens with lasers. There are plenty of great sci-fi movies, but few stray from the never-ending battle of human vs. alien. `Solaris' deserves attention not for the mini-controversy surrounding its rating (a publicity stunt by Twentieth Century Fox because they reportedly had trouble finding ways to market the movie) but for having a premise set in deep space that doesn't involve evil aliens preying on overmatched humans.In `Solaris', George Clooney plays Chris Kelvin; a psychologist dispatched to a space station orbiting the titular planet to find out what went wrong on a routine exploration mission. When Kelvin arrives, he finds that two crewmembers are dead, and one of the two survivors has locked herself in her quarters because of what has gone on in the space station. When Kelvin finally does persuade the reclusive Dr. Gordon (the excellent Viola Davis) to talk, she tells him that `It isn't really worth talking about until it starts happening to you.'Though `Solaris' is a deliberately slow paced movie, `It' happens to Kelvin after his first night on the station; he wakes up to a kiss from his wife Rheya- who died years earlier. More haunting is the fact that she is not a figment of Chris' imagination, Rheya (played by Natacha McElhone) can recite memories of the life she and Chris shared together without any help from him. Both Clooney and McElhone fit their roles perfectly. Natacha McElhone has an intriguing beauty and she uses it to fit the haunting atmosphere of the film, and Clooney increasingly shows the wear of an intelligent man who cannot comprehend the events transpiring around him, and ends up with one of his best performances to date.What drives the film is the originality of the story. `Solaris'was written as a novel by Stanislaw Lem, and first adapted to film in 1972 by the legendary Russian filmmaker Andrei Tarkovsky. Tarkovsky's is a sci-fi classic and considered by many to be the foreign equivalent to `2001: A Space Odyssey.' Steven Soderbergh (who won Best Director for `Traffic'- itself a remake) refuses to call this `Solaris' a remake, and contends that his film is simply a new adaptation of Lem's novel.Soderbergh's argument is credible, his `Solaris' is almost half the length of Tarkovsky's near 3-hour epic, his screenplay concentrating mostly on the relationship of Rheya and Kelvin.The 1972 version eyes the scientific morals of the mission, something completely missing from the latter movie. The 2002 `Solaris' is a chilling film with great acting that asks intriguing questions about humanity, space and essentially love itself. Tarkovsky's `Solaris' is the superior film, but unlike many remakes, Soderbergh's film does not disgrace the original.
Grade: B+

reviews.review_title: Why would you do this to Tarkovsky?
reviews.content: Andrei Tarkovsky's Solaris is a flawless and thoughtful masterpiece of cinema- this is, ummm, not that.That's all I'll say.

I read the book by Stanislaw Lem just before getting the film, and there are of course elements of the story well explained in the book which were removed from the film - or simply too hard to pump into a film.The plot is the following, people in a space station above the planet Solaris receive "visitors", lifelike persons from their past, all dead already. The question of their nature, their origin, their purpose is key as they are not aggressive, not "aliens in disguise".George Clooney delivers a good performance and while the film takes us miles away from a typical SF movie into a psychological drama, a debate on reality, love even, I would say that the result is surprisingly good.Still enigmatic, the very nature of Solaris, the nature of the "visitors", only tends to find an explanation through metaphysical and religious terms. It opens a debate as well on "what is a person" and "what is the essence of a person", never quite a full answer in the film, nor in the book.

I never read anything about "Solaris" before viewing it and after its end the whole movie was great experience for me. Story is very interesting and it makes you think about few things. What is actually happening on board? Why are this visions coming to the main characters? And lots more. Beside story, actors are also on top. George Clooney plays main role and I have to say that this is very difficult role to play. In my opinion Clooney was very good, just like Jeremy Davies and Natascha McElhone. I didn't watch the Russian original "Solyaris" so I cannot compare it to this American one. But the story is simply great and I bow to the people who wrote this, so I probably guess that original is better (I have to find the original). If you never watched it, you will be pleased with "Solaris". It isn't long, it is interesting and very good SF movie.

reviews.review_title: Loved it--but only in comparison to Russian Version.
reviews.content: I LOVED this movie, but after a bit of reflection I think that most of what I liked about it relate directly to how it does or does not deviate from the Tarkovsky version. I'm not sure how much I would have cared if I had seen it on its own. MANY people walked out of the opening night screening I was at. Today a Fox exec in the NYTimes says he guesses "it wasn't the Holiday Fare we thought it would be." Well, Fox Exec, maybe a brain would be in order. It's too bad this film will be seen as a flop because they're putting it out in a season and with a campaign guarateeing it to tank. Nice move, Fox. The performances all round were good. The acting here is extra challenging because they have to act realistically in a totally bizarre and false situation, and I think they all do well. In this way it reminded me of "Existenz"--having to act naturally in a surreal situation. At first I was thinking "I am being prevented from examining the serious moral and philosophical issues presented here because George Clooney is just SO DAMN HANDSOME!" but I think it's a testament to his acting that it is possible to forget that after a while. The real revelation was Natasha McE, who I think had to show some of the most raw emotions in situations that don't call for it, and she really ran off with the gold. The script--and this may come as a surprise to those who say this is the most boring thing they had ever seen--was clearly written to emphasize the THRILLER aspect of the story. If you've seen the 3-hour Russian version (which I wrote a scathing review about on IMDb, but has grown in my estimation since) you can spend the first half-hour admiring the economy with which the story is told. I also loved the care and composition of every shot in the first two-thirds. The conception of the planet was very good, very beautiful, but, like much of the film, I think it got away from Soderbergh in the end. No one ever comes out and SAYS "the planet is a sentient being," and I think it would have helped the movie if they had, because just changing the color of the planet as the film moves along and interspersing shots of it with George thinking does NOT necessarily make the connection, and toward the end it began to feel like "Hmm, I don't know what to do here... okay, let's just show the planet again!" This film erred on the side of subtlety too often I thought, which may be admirable in some situations, but here I think it actually held the film back, because if you HAD the information, you could proceed to think about what was happening and what it meant, rather than just trying to catch up with what was happening at all. Some things I think should have been SAID OUTRIGHT: (SPOILERS here:) "The planet is a sentient being!" "But your wife is dead!" "My wife was unfaithful!" "My wife killed herself!" and "The space station is sinking INTO the planet!"(SPOILERS END) I really enjoyed the music. It was very reminiscent of Philip Glass (and I can't help thinking would have been better if it WERE by Philip Glass, not that I don't love ya, Cliff, and that opening music to "Kafka" is ASTOUNDING). I also loved the long musical passages of the film, I wish more films would do this--though of course then it would turn to crap. Unfortunately, I feel like Soderbergh lost control of the film at the end. I was quite surprised at the beginning that he had jettisoned Kelvin's father and the rest of his family, a decision that I think comes back to haunt the ending, and really strip it of the emotional heft the earlier version had. This version, limiting the focus only to the love of the wife, and moving away from her place within the larger scope of his family and his entire existence, I think made the film a bit banal in the end. Okay, let's face it, the whole concept of this movie is straight outta original series Star Trek, but for the way it's handled, but compared to the Tarkovsky, it just seems less weighty. This movie begins to lose focus in the final third, and even the shots themselves do not seem as controlled. I was stunned that he also dropped the final shot of the Tarkovsky version, which almost single-handedly explained what you just saw, and I just don't think that what he came up with compared in any way. The placement of the flashbacks also just started to feel arbitrary, and the one crucial one RIGHT at the end I really think should have been inserted much before, it has the effect of stopping the momentum. Nevertheless, I can't wait to see it again. I think I might rent the Tarkovsky version (and watch it with the benefit of a fast-forward button) then see this once more. I also think, if you're going to see it, DON'T rent it, but definitely see it in all its beauty on the big screen, and when your attention will be focused on the screen.Regardless of the minor flaws, big props to Steven and George for doing this. I wish this film would always be at theaters so I could go see it whenever I want.--- Check out website devoted to bad and cheesy movies: www.cinemademerde.com

What about the Soderbergh's film? What are the good and the bad points of the movie? Lem: l though I admit that Soderbergh's vision is not devoid of ambition, taste and climate, I am not delighted with the prominence of love. Solaris may be perceived as a river basin - and Soderbergh chose only one of its tributaries. The main problem seems the fact that even such a tragic-romantic adaptation seems too demanding for mass audience fed with Hollywood pap. If in the future someone else dared a faithful adaptation, I am afraid the effects would be understood only by a tiny audience.I read the book, and I think that in fact that book is about the unattainable, and inconceivable. More of the unattainable love, than Lem himself said. It is in the subconscious of the book. I really loved Soderbergh's film.It's about God too.

I really liked this film! I found it gripping and absorbing, I suppose in a similar way to 2001, as they both play with the idea of unseen forces that manipulate and control the human protagonists. The cinematography was brilliant as well - the use of lighting trademark Soderbergh, with a rich yellow cast to the scenes on Earth and a harsh blue white light on the space ship. I found that the pace was fine in fact - the tension racketed up and racketed up as you realised (SPOILERS) that she wasn't going to die, that Snow was a copy, that Chris wasn't going to leave, that Chris was also a copy (that has to be the most heart stopping moment of all). The whole mystery of it - this place that this planet has created where these 'people' can now exist - is what gives it is force, exemplified by the repeated Thomas line - 'lovers may be lost but love is not'. And this was not overly sentimental at all but had a moving truth to it. There was a certain chill and coldness - I didn't get lost in their story as I may have in a more conventional movie - but I liked the sense that the main character was being driven forward by guilt - and of course first time round he reproduces that mistake. Actually, the question of what happens to that version of his wife is one of the most troubling aspects of the film.....

Because of the slow pacing, the Philip Glass-ey music and the obvious references to 2001, you might get the idea that this is a thoughtful film that engages the intellect.  You would be wrong.While it's true that many recent films are all rather shallow, filled with hyperactive action-adventure (the recent Bond film comes to mind) but not much else, it does not follow that stripping a film of action and adventure automatically make it a "good" film as some here have averred.  Solaris is as devoid and sterile of genuine thought and emotion as its crash bang counterparts are.Mr. Soderbergh has made "Solaris" a post-modern love story.  The swirly colors are pretty to watch, and the soundtrack is easy on the ears.  But ultimately, this is a pretty vacuous experience.

I should have known when I found out that this movie did not run in the Big Screen Movie Theatre but in the independent movie theatre: This is an art movie. I didn't believe that a big budget movie by Steven Soderbergh with George Clooney in it would not be "high profile" enough to be omitted by the Big Screen - but well, it was, and what a shame!This movie somehow is like a new "2001" with a clearer message and a much shorter running time - and that's a good thing! It is a contemplative experience with visual and acoustic brilliance which never gets boring though there is not too much happening on screen. Well, the casting of Natascha McElhone was certainly a big addition to the atmosphere - not because she is especially good, but because she has a certain scary quality about her which is hard to bear. The are scenes in which she is looking directly into the camera where I for my part would not like to be alone in a room with her. Soderbergh could have casted a beautiful woman - that would have made the movie a different film - but he decided to cast McElhone, and therefore gave the movie an eery, surreal touch. Well done!All in all a very satisfying movie which certainly could have been faster, longer or more action packed, but that would not have captured Stanislaw Lems spirit - and though I hardly remember the book, having read it a decade ago, I am sure that in spite of many changes the movie captures it right now. You probably won't remember this one for years - but it's certainly worth a look!

reviews.review_title: Go Straight to the DVD for your Term Paper
reviews.content: Solaris is not going to be for all tastes for the reasons outlined in other reviews: some will see it as slow, confusing, etcetera. It's an art film masquerading as a Sci Fi star vehicle if you look at the credits and the bare plot outline. As far as the plot, I'm not going to bother saying anything at all, because basically anything you read about the plot is a spoiler. The more you know about it in advance, the less you're going to enjoy the unfolding. Let's just say it's definitely not a Cameron-inspired action flick, and it's as much Soderbergh's homage to Godard's Alphaville as a remake. Speaking of which, I enjoyed the original, admired the book, and I actually think Soderbergh improved on both by using a lot of pure film technique to make it more taut. There's very little in the way of loud action movie over-explanation here.What I did find particularly delightful is the commentary on the DVD edition -- James Cameron and Soderbergh talking about many of the choices that went into the movie, a host of techniques, where they think they made mistakes, what they did differently but then changed back, and so on. You couldn't have two more different directors in on a collaboration, and it's really quite cool to listen to their dialogue about the making.So here's the punchline: while this is definitely a filmmaker's film, it's even more of a film student's film. For those of you who haven't done the same and are of the analytic bent, it's great fun to go through the film, then the commentary, then read the screenplay (included no the DVD!), then go back and see the Tarkovsky and then go back to the Lem novel. You could do a whole intro to film technique course that way.I give it a 6/10 on merit but an 8/10 on guilty pleasures for peeking inside the filmmaker's toolbox.

Many seem to think Solaris is slow and boring. If you're looking for a new Aliens, of course you'll be disappointed. It's not supposed to be an action film set in space. If you're looking for an existential drama set in space, Solaris works better.It's difficult to describe the story, but the acting and production keeps you interested, even when it's unclear what's happening. The photography, editing, and music are simply brilliant. Those who have seen the seduction scene in Soderbergh's Out of Sight will recognise that same style throughout the whole film. I haven't read Lem's book, or seen Tarkovsky's film, but I found Solaris to be quite hypnotic. If anything, I wish the film had been half an hour longer, as it feels a bit rushed towards the end now. [5/10]

reviews.review_title: A beautiful masterwork. Clooney's absolutely brilliant.
reviews.content: I will not tell you the plot of Solaris, you can find that anywhere. This movie is a thing of beauty, anyone that needs a car chase or some kind of explosion, nudie scene, or murder, stay away, everyone else please watch. I was not a fan of George Clooney, now I am. His performance is one of the top 5 in the last 20 years, this role is so hard to play and yet he plays it beautifully. Kudos for the director who gave this pretty boy the role of his career. McElhone is excellent as his wife. The only weakness on this movie is Davies, too over the top, too cliche, it is a shame because it is the only thing that stops this movie from being absolutely perfect. As far as the direction, it is fantastic, this is one of the most intimate movies ever filmed. The presentation of Clooney's encounter with his wife from the beginning to the end of their marriage is gorgeous, 100 words are maybe exchanged and yet a lifetime is presented. The score is excellent, it is so original, it would have been out of place anywhere else but here. As far as anyone saying this movie is slow, they have been playing to many video games. This is an excellent mystery/romance/sci-fi/thriller, all wrapped into one. 8.5/10

reviews.review_title: too subtle, slow paced, NICE gRaPhiX, semi-meaningfulessnessis.
reviews.content: The dialogue was kind of weak. this film requires a mature mind to enjoy the complexities thereof. thus, the film poses questions but doesn't give any real possibilities.Lots of eye candy, pretty fluffy colory clouds and stuff... oooooh.. i rike. ;) Basically, the main character, ( Clooney ) would rather live in alternate unknown life with his suicidal alien wife simulation. Or, maybe solaris is heaven, Or, an alien planet that manipulates ones mind so that what the experience seems real, even though it's not.The discussion at the table concerning god and religion etc,.. was such a joke, very weak, and dumbed down to a point of meaninglessness.The movie is very SSsssssLLllllllOOoooooooWWwwwwwwwww paced. And, the transition from one scene to flashback to another scene reminded me of Microsoft PowerPoint, you know with the cheesy image transitions. Also, The movie does, however, stretch ones imagination, only cause you'd have to imagine the possibilities that the movie doesn't seem to address properly. There are subtleties that I liked, however, like the slight touching of the hand with his fiancée. But that was all. I didn't get the connection with the boy holding his hand out to the main character during the finale.One commenter had this to say which made me laugh heartedly: " explores the uncharted realms of the human condition as much as the unknown realities of the universe, and swims upstream against the currents of ethics, physics, and even metaphysics, you will probably enjoy this moody, slow, multi-leveled and heavily textured film."human condition" ?? what ? being trapped in a spaceship with illusions of lost love, is a metaphor for the Human Condition ? yeah Right...Unknown realities of the Universe ? like staring at the miasma of cream and hot coffee at the break of dawn.Multi-leveled ? reality and illusion, afterlife, spirit world dreamworld alien simulated life ? whatever man.. doesn't look multi-leveled to me, just your basic dreamy romance story in a spaceship setting entering a world of illusion.but then again, "what is real?" Well, how about a better movie like "The matrix".In order to be receptive to this movie you'd need a particular frame of mind: "high on weed".However, the acting by all the cast was solid, just the way in which this movie was written. And, the music was, well, great if you need to get some sleep.Overall the movie seemed low budget and unfinished. the concept wasn't depicted strong enough, and the slow pace makes the mind wander and thus doesn't do much to keep one interested enough.I know a good film when I see, it, and Solaris is marginal at best. Hardly worth the the price of a good book.If there is one thing I hate, are Writers that do these stupid remakes, add a few differences here, there, better graphics, steal other writers ideas then viola', everybody calls Steven Soderbergh a genius, quite the contrary, for this film, no way.One facet I did like about this film is the point where Chris realizes Nobody ever knows all there is to know about another person, and that's what makes the surrealism of the story so compelling or wishy washy, mixed up and meaningless.And, this sums up it all up, from another commenter: Soderbergh has managed to leave out just about everything that could justify the title .Serious, it was a weak film, However I respect Soderbergh cause of his other work. Oh well, remakes are usually lame anwyay.

Minor spoilerSolaris has a pretty simple story, which can be told easily in 30 minutes or so. So what I am suggesting is it is excessively long.
Also, it doesn't sound very logical to me: if Gordon had 'killed' her 'visitor' and the station was clean, WHY WOULDN'T SHE JUST TAKE EVERYONE BACK IMMEDIATELY? I mean, apparently, she was the one to suggest to head back toward the end of the film, but Chris didn't bring any changes to the station really, except for summoning up that robot-like Rheya, whose death is the only point in the film which made me high --- and, p.s., why was Chris wanted in the first place? For a trip to the space and have some virtual sex??Arty and dumb. 5/10

reviews.review_title: A film in its own right
reviews.content: I liked the film very much. I can understand the criticism of some other contributors stating that the movie is not very authentic with respect to the book, although it it is called Solaris and states in its credits that it is based on the book. This is of course misleading and it would have been better to give it a different name and rather say that it was "inspired" by Lem's novel. Therefore I only gave a 9 to a film which I otherwise would have graded 10. Because in its own right I find it very well made indeed. The subject is an absolutely relevant one: Who are we? What makes us human? What is life? What is love? Do we need explanations or meaning in life? The movie concentrates on these questions, different from the book. This is a completely legitimate approach. Don't concentrate on the comparison of film and book, and you are fine. I got curious to reread the novel, and I am not expecting to find too much from the movie in it. That's OK.Also the cinematic realization and the acting was very good. The planet, the spaceship, the drama of the relationship between "humans" and "replicas". Who is human and who replica in the end? Who dreams whom? The result seems to be that being human is defined by nothing else than the relationships themselves, to persons or to the inanimate world. And in Solaris, this "inanimate" world turns out to be more alive than expected, another subject worth being explored.I really cannot understand the relative low rating of around 6 and the many negative reviews this film has received. I think it's great.

Okay, so we can all talk about how boring it is, sure, well, I can't argue. Not to say I don't REALLY like this movie, cause I do. I like it a lot, but it doesn't make me sleepy. I like that fact. This movie is not normal. The pace is slow, and the soundtrack is extremely relaxing (fantastic in my opinion.) So don't expect to be on the edge of your seat. If you'd like to see some of the best SCI-FI photography work done since 2001 space odysee, than watch this. I am in now way saying this is ON PAR with 2001, but FILM MAKING WISE it definitely deserves association. I thought that this film feature some extremely beautiful sequences, and was in many ways a (to borrow a phrase) "...return to what sci-fi was meant to be." If you can look at this picture http://www.geocities.com/natewood007/solaris.jpg and still say that the film is not genius, I am completely baffled. WATCH THIS MOVIE, and fall asleep at peace with the universe.

reviews.review_title: Maybe the most foreign American film I've ever seen.
