reviews.content: Steven Soderbergh has subverted another genre again. This sci-fi is one of the strangest motion pictures I've seen in quite some time. I still don't know what I just saw an hour ago, but I think I liked it quite a bit. (I never saw the Russian original --I never cared to.) I could describe the film's plot but I don't think it would make any difference. It is a hermetically sealed psychodrama set aboard a spaceship orbiting a sentient planet called Solaris (I think). George Clooney is in top form in a very difficult role as a psychiatrist trying to figure out what the heck is driving people nuts aboard the ship. Jeremy Davies is a wonder to behold as one of the people who has witnessed many of the goings on. His performance recalls Brad Pitt's work in "12 Monkeys" (but imagine Pitt in slow motion from that film and you'll have Davies in this). It is, however, very tough film to sit through. The story doesn't unfold before your eyes so much as it thaws before your eyes. It is a 2 hour film that plays like 3. Several people in the audience walked long before this film ended and I can't say that I blamed them. Nevertheless with that said, "Solaris" does have a weird trance-like power. It isn't so much spellbinding as it is intriguing. The ending definitely raises some questions. It is a beautiful film to watch. The production is first class. It defies easy easy explanation and I doubt that it will do much box office. You got to give Soderbergh credit trying something very different. Whether he succeeded or not is not up for popular vote but is up to you --the individual viewer. It is a very unique and very strange film with an odd power. If you want entertainment go see 007 again.

I love this film. It gives you time to think and feel. The planet Solaris provides a different experience for each crew member and the film Solaris does the same for audience members, drawing on your emotions and experience. Incredible. You need to focus on the film from the start. If you have a short attention span or limited life experience it's not for you. It's not for everyone.

reviews.review_title: A man grapples with his own beliefs
reviews.content: George Clooney stars in Steven Soderbergh's "Solaris," a 2002 film also starring Natascha McElhone and Viola Davis. Clooney plays Chris, a psychiatrist, still grieving over the suicide of his wife (McElhone). He is asked to travel to a space station orbiting the planet Solaris. Strange things are going on with the crew. When he gets there, he finds some of the crew have killed themselves; dead loved ones have appeared to people in the space station, and shortly after his own arrival, his late wife Rheya shows up. Is she real? Is she a figment of his imagination? Is she some sort of planetary manifestation? Rheya remembers their life together, but no emotion of actual involvement. Helen Gordon (Davis) thinks she's a destructive facsimile, while Chris wants to believe she's real and wants to be reunited with her.Though slow-moving and dialogue-heavy, "Solaris" is still an effective and thought-provoking film, tapping into something very universal - the desire to be reunited with those we've lost. Chris isn't a religious man and has to question his own belief system as he looks back on his life with Rheya, while Rheya suspects that she isn't really Rheya at all. Meanwhile, Helen is pushing for Rheya to be destroyed as a dangerous entity that can make trouble on earth.I haven't read the book or seen the Russian film - I understand this is quite different. Thanks to the depth of Clooney's and McElhone's performances, the movie works on its own level. It's not for everyone, since it's about concepts and ideas rather than action. I found it intriguing.

reviews.review_title: a piece of art, but less than the novel
reviews.content: The film itself is very good, perhaps one of the best I've seen. But I still recommend that you read the original before watching. Not even with a picture of Tarkovsky, but with a book by Lem. Without this, the meaning of the film cannot be understood, because the director misses many important plot points. However, he can be forgiven. If he decided to capture Lem's idea exactly, we would have to watch an incredibly long (and rather boring) series.The visual component of the film is also on top, although it is clear that the authors were inspired by Blade Runner.

Went to see Solaris with my husband and before we even went in to see the film, so many interesting things happened. As we were paying our entrance fee, the cashier at the Multiplex advised us not to see it. Said it was the most boring picture she had ever seen in her life and people were walking out.Next as we were giving our tickets to the ticket taker,he again repeated how many people had walked out of the film, angry and bored, wanting their money refunded. He told us that if after 25 minutes, we didn't want to see anymore of the film, we could leave and go in to see the new James Bond movie at no extra charge. We sat down to watch the film, I checked my watch and when I checked again an hour had passed. Obviously we were not bored. We were most interested in what was coming next and why. However, we did see a few people walk out.As for trying to analyze the film, why bother! I think that one of the problems is that everyone wants a beginning, middle and end plus a rational reason for everything. It's like looking at an abstract painting that seemingly has no meaning except in the eye of the beholder.The changing scenes and moods appealed to us.We chose to look no further than that.As for the ending,and I think this might be  a spoiler, I thought of the long time ago movie "Splash' One of Tom Hanks early films along with Daryl Hannah. The majority of the viewers who saw it, would have preferred the mermaid to become an earthly woman. Instead, Tom Hanks preferred devoting his life to her, splashing together in the sea. They wanted to be together. Same thing with "Solaris" Did it really matter where they were? Probably the majority of the population that saw the film and stayed till the end would have liked to hear that the entire film was a figment of Kelvin's imagination and never happened at all. They just wanted to be together.There is no answer I can give. After all the universe is infinite.We can always ask the question, what is outside the universe????Back to "Solaris" Too bad so many people were "bored" and walked out angrily asking for a refund (which the manager gave, due to such anger) We discussed it with him and quote his feelings "A great deal of the masses are asses"

SOLARIS (2002) ***  George Clooney, Natascha McElhone, Jeremy Davies, Viola Davis, Ulrich Tukur, Morgan Rusler.  Filmmaker Steven Soderbergh's auspicious revamping of Russian director Andrei Tarkovsky's 1972 sci-fi cult classic incorporates existential angst, navel gazing and ultimately the human condition when it comes to love, life and death (and their meanings) that is more miss than hit despite a welcomingly complex turn by Clooney as a psychiatrist  who is dispatched to a space expedition that has gone awry when apparently their deepest emotional thoughts are realized with an O. Henry twist or two ahead for him, including the grips he must come to when an embodiment of his late wife (McElhone, smartly cast for her ethereally beautiful looks) takes form and to task his very sanity.  Methodical in its tone and supremely slow pace may be taxing to the viewer's nerves but ultimately this is a thinking-man's sci-fi film that asks more questions than provides answers which is always maddening yet the effect is slightly chillier than anticipated with its spot on sterile production design and sleek blue/silver cinematography achieved by Philip Messina and `Peter Andrews' (Soderbergh's alter ego behind the lens), as well as an affectively melancholy score by Cliff Martinez.  Executive produced by James Cameron.

Solaris (2002): Dir: Steven Soderbergh / Cast: George Clooney, Natascha McElhone, Jeremy Davies, Viola Davis, Ulrich Tukur: Ominous film starring George Clooney as a psychologist receiving a message to travel to a space station. He arrives to sheer silence with dry blood painting various areas. Eventually he finds two individuals who attempt to provide information and warnings but Clooney chooses to remain. Jeremy Davies attempts to explain the situation without really explaining it. Viola Davis prefers to remain in her room. Clooney's sleep is interrupted by memories of his wife and her suicide. Intriguing despite questionable conclusion but director Steven Soderbergh is skilled at its mystery in terms of its cross over from reality to dream like state of being. Soderbergh and Clooney both previously worked on the entertaining Out of Sight and the overrated Ocean's Eleven. Clooney is in his element playing an individual shocked at the experience yet faced with haunting memories. Natascha McElhone mirrors the fragile confusion of his wife whose image enslaves his thoughts. Jeremy Davies and Viola Davis seem to evaporate but they steal their scenes when they are on screen. Other roles are much less broad and not very interesting. An unsettling visual achievement ripe with ideas, but it addresses how others are presented in our mindset. Score: 6 ½ / 10

reviews.review_title: Soderbergh's sci-fi exercise, eye candy and nothing else
reviews.content:
After just seeing Solaris, I have worked and re-worked my thoughts on Steven Soderbergh to a point that I think is finally expressible.  Let me start by acknowledging Soderbergh's obvious and pure talent; it is total, visually evocative as well as thematically minded, and his films are often a pleasure to watch for their keen cinematic intellect.  However, I tend to think, particularly after Solaris, that Soderbergh is still searching to channel that boundless, preternatural cinematic gift into his great masterpiece. His career has been spotty so far.  Between films, and even within films, he can go from inspired to pretentious film-school brat in a matter of shots. His more successful ventures (at least the ones I have appreciated the most: Out of Sight, The Limey, and Traffic) have contained only a modicum of that generic, `indie' (which I use pejoratively) and a lot of worthwhile bits. But Soderbergh is still searching for something, a genre, a style, an expressive voice, maybe even a muse.  I like to think of his movies as exercises.  Traffic was an exercise in using an Altman-esque sense of scope and interlocking stories to politically condemn the American involvement in the drug trade.  Out of Sight was an exercise in creating a cool, up-to-date crime caper and giving two of our sexiest and most bankable STARS meaty roles.  Sex, lies, and videotape was an exercise in seeing exactly how far the early independent filmmaking scene could be stretched.  Et cetera, et cetera.  Solaris is just another installment in his succession of filmic exercises.All of the director's usual production values are in place in Solaris, and they are more effective than ever:  The jittery handheld camera for intimate scenes, the blue filters for emotional distance, and the fabulous movement-cinematography (this time, as usual, by Soderbergh, with nom de cine).  Solaris' (and Soderbergh's) best visual creation is the solaris itself, a swirling nebula of pink and orange.  He keeps returning to this image, as if he knew it would become the one with the most staying power.
I mentioned all of these visual components first, because they fully overshadow any plot or characterizations that might be present in the movie. Essentially, Chris Kelvin (George Clooney) is a psychologist asked to journey to Solaris, a space station floating dangerous close to the aforementioned pink nebula.  He has been summoned because of some extraordinary goings-on at the space station that basically remain unnamed throughout.  To add a dimension to Kelvin, he is grieving over the loss of his wife (played by Natascha McElhone in a very muted, nearly plastic performance).  The reason Kelvin was summoned into space stays as nebulous as the solaris:  weird things have been happening and the remaining crew members (Viola Davis and Jeremy Davies, both passable in their parts and well-cast) have been visited by facsimiles of their deceased loved ones. All three reach a psychological breaking point when Kelvin is visited by his dead wife and ethical issues over her existence, the fine line between life and death, and her proposed termination arise.That is basically all there is to the plot, and why an emphasis is better placed on Solaris' production values.  This seems like an aesthetic, stylistic exercise for Soderbergh.  He is merely playing with eye candy, cloaking a thin script (a supposedly thin adaptation of Tarkovsky's classic film of the same title) in a lot of evocative stuff.  But there isn't much here, not much for audience and director alike to sink their teeth into, and it seems as if Soderbergh knows that.To hit upon George Clooney for a moment, this is one of his more serious-minded performances but that by no means suggests it is his best. Clooney, one of the sexiest men in movies by default, has risen above all his star power by making the most consistently smart movie choices of anyone in Hollywood.  I don't know if this is as smart a move for him as, say, David O. Russell's Three Kings or the Coen's O Brother, Where Art Thou?, but it is interesting and shows balls.  He tampers down his inherent charisma in Solaris, but when he allows it to shine through, those moments constitute some of the best scenes in the film.  Whatever you make of his performance, it is a gutsy one for a star of his caliber, even if the material isn't particularly groundbreaking or even well-constructed.

Just had to view this film on a Friday night, as it was listed as "Friday Nite Horror Show". Much to my surprise, it was more than I had bargained for and held my interest from beginning to end. George Clooney,(Chris Kelvin),"Ocean's Eleven",'01, played a head shrink and wound up almost a complete Nut Case. Natascha McElhone(Rheya),"City of Ghosts",'02 played his wife that was with Chris one minute and off somewhere in space the next. There was a clear message in this film, which they called a Poem, that some what mentions the fact that real love between two people never dies after Death and continues on into the Spiritual world or simply Resurrection. So in other words, you really got a Sermon on Life & Death in this film.

reviews.review_title: poor ending lowers the rating on this movie
reviews.content: part philosophy,alternate reality,God.human existence.this movie seems to ask a lot of questions.it is compelling for most of it's running time,although it i found it quite deep,with very little action.I also thought George Clooney took awhile to grow into his character.at 1st,i didn't find him convincing in his role,but somehow that changed throughout the course of the movie.the problem i found with this movie is that it for much of the time it is a deep,thought provoking movie.I don't believe in some of the views put forth,but nevertheless,the movie was engaging.however it drew me in, and then the ending was a cop out,too neatly tied up,and not at all realistic.i don't mind watching a 'pure, shut of your brain' action movie,because i no what i am getting.so if a movie stars out compelling and engaging i expect it to end appropriately.in my view,this movie does not do so.i would have given it 8*,but because of the ending i am deducting 2 stars.as a result,my vote for "Solaris" is 6*/10

reviews.review_title: Let the steel drums carry you away.....
reviews.content: As a sort of fan of the original, this was one of the few movies that nowadays I have bothered to go to see in the cinema. Having seen it once I wasn't overly impressed by the movie as a whole, but primarily by Steven Soderbergh's extraordinary photography of Natascha McElhone's lambent beauty.Since the film has made its way to satellite and cable, however, I discover that I cannot resist putting it on and watching it again, and allowing myself to be subsumed by the utterly tragic mood. The main contributor to this is Cliff Martinez's phenomenal score in which the constant thrumming of steel drums over an ethereal orchestra carries you through long exploratory shots of the luminous sea of Solaris, or eloquent silences between characters.Clooney and McElhone are very affecting as the, almost literally, "star-crossed lovers". Unfortunately I find the two Davi(e)ses somewhat detracting from the whole, with Jeremy's "Snow" a slacker whom it is difficult to believe would qualify to fly in space, and Viola's "Gordon" seems to be out of a rather more conventional "space alien" movie - in fact her performance more than a little resembles Yaphet Kotto's in the movie 'Alien'! Ulrich Tukur as Gibarian, however, is a wonderfully understated reminder of the original material's European origins.The one failing of this movie compared to its predecessor is Soderberg's inability to portray Solaris as a character in its own right, something Tarkowsky seemingly managed with ease.

reviews.review_title: Where Real Science Fiction Meets Hollywood
reviews.content:
In one of the special features documentaries coming with the DVD, director Soderbergh explains his 'Solaris', as a science fiction work 'as it used to be': less about robot fights and laser guns, more about humans. He is correct, with one observation - Real science fiction always was, is, and will be about human beings and their emotions - fear, hope, love. It is Hollywood who hijacked the genre and transformed it in a commercial pop-art based mainly on effects, at the expense of what real art is meant to be. But not all cinema is done at Hollywood, thanks God, and directors like Soderbergh find ways to do good films even in the Hollywood system.
For example, this 'Solaris' is a legitimate attempt to reconcile the two approaches. It takes the classic 'Solaris' book (by Stanislaw Lem) and picture  (a real masterpiece by Tarkowski) and  gives it a Hollywood twist - the story is more about relationship and human emotion, less about the experience to discover a new civilisation and world, with different rules than ours. This works no bad, and 'Solaris' is a good film. The robot fights and laser guns fans will be disappointed, but they have many other films to satisfy their lust.Compared with the classical film of Tarkowski this 'Solaris' loses in depth - but it is probably on purpose. Staging and camera are good, though reminding too much of Kubrick's '2001'. Casting is interesting - most of the characters including George Clooney seem slightly mis-casted, but it somehow helps, adding to the strange atmosphere of the film. Clooney always seems to act better than you would expect, and I wonder why. It may be his looks that are too close to the 50's legends (Carry Grant, James Stewart). But then, as in 'Brother' he surprises the audiences for the good. I kind of dis-liked the final. It tried to be at the same time original and happy-end-ish, but it looked confusing and cheap to me. However, there was a lot of good stuff in the rest of the film to make it worth watching. 8/10 on my personal scale.

reviews.review_title: No SFX Needed for This Character- and Plot-Driven Gem!
reviews.content: Several things must handshake well together in order for me to actually recommend it to people. You know what they are: an engaging plot, believable acting, creative cinematography, and a nice film score (or nice choice in music). The story truly was a bit eerie as the plot thickened and morphed. By the end of the film, I sensed my own paranoia as I put my own mind in the situation.All the characters really drew me in to their situations - the fact that there were so few main characters (including, the planet Solaris, which I consider a character) made it even better. The scenes were amazingly shot. Not every camera was set to the best framing - what film has *every* camera shot that tight - but I cheered the cinematographer when his name flashed on the screen (and later found out that Steve Soderbergh was the cinematographer after all).Within 10 minutes of the start of the movie (watching it at home) I searched for the film score, and now have a CD. The scoring blended seamlessly with the feature. But IMHO, I can see where some people can't embrace this tight film. Working behind the camera for a news organization, I've learned quickly that people in general don't like to sit through something that doesn't move, change, and develop quickly. And they tend to enjoy film scores with a faster beat, or even something with a more dramatic flair. The scoring by Cliff Martinez was magnificent, and any other type of scoring, or adding what I call "Bruckheimer beats" (music in films produced by Jerry Bruckheimer) would have destroyed it. Some people are uncomfortable with films that have lots of "air time," which allow one to think, feel, and allow all the aspects of a movie to surround the viewer and seep in. It lacks in testosterone scenes. While I enjoy those films as well, this one I thoroughly enjoyed and will watch over and over. But I would recommend them only to people who can not only appreciate a character-driven film that relies on plot rather than adrenaline, but also wants a movie that doesn't have to spell everything out for the viewer. Does a film-goer have to rely on getting all the answers, when we can make our own conclusions, based on our own life's experiences and personalities?

SOLARIS divides opinion totally ... I stayed in the cinema till the end of the credits, lost in the music and the mood.  One other person stayed too, and all the rest left mumbling their disgust.  I was lucky, it pulled me in, and I stayed with it.  It was a beautiful experience.SPOILERS ********The woman behind me had only come to see George's bum (folks, you see it twice - once a glimpse, and once a bloody long stare, if you choose to look to the left of the screen) ...Look, the sequence early on in which the shuttle docks with the space station is - probably - the single most beautiful, awe-inspiring sci-fi sequence I've ever seen.  If it had lasted twenty minutes, I'd have devoured every second.  As it is, it must have been just two or three, but ... what colours, what a view, what music.And then the film settles into its philosophical explorations, close-ups (Natascha McE was put on this earth to be seen in close-up on a giant widescreen, trust me ...), thoughtfulness.  I let it wash over me, became melancholy as it seemed to want me to, became sad, felt loss, felt tears, and felt rescued.  I will buy the DVD, and will watch it again greedily.  Good luck when you see Solaris, for you might not like it.  If you do, however, you'll absolutely love it.  It's a thing of dignity and beauty.

reviews.review_title: A Great Experiential, Thinking Sci Fi Movie
reviews.content: 29 November 2002. This version as well as the original Russian version are no action adventure (Star Wars, Matrix, Independence Day) movies. This sci fi movie is definitely for the cerebral and humanistic type of audience who like strange, mysterious alien influences that seem to get under your skin - to feel and experience what's going on in a movie. It is definitely a relationship movie about what it means to be human and to make human choices. This is going to be a great cult movie in American science fiction (though a bit overly simplistic and too cute for the taste of the intelligent, International, sci fi community. The relationship between Kelvin and the first appearance isn't given nearly sufficient screen time and the female scientist on board the space station isn't given enough depth and "almost" becomes more of a stereotypical character. However, on the whole, this sci fi movie is a great substantive, a heavy-weight in science fiction, much like "Forbidden Planet" or "The Day the Earth Stood Still" were classics of the 1950s. But that doesn't mean that it will be a popular hit with the general public, it definitely won't be because most of the audience won't understand what's going on and it,s way too slow for the average American filmgoer.

I think Solaris is a great film. I was really struck by the vulnerability George Clooney allowed himself to display in this film. What I mean by this, is that in in a lot of films, I felt when Clooney was smiling, his eyes were sad. Solaris really exposed something I felt he had all the time, but maybe he wasn't ready for it until Solaris.Aesthetically I think the film is beautiful. The color palettes in this film range from deep browns, to dark greens, which when combined with rain, gave Earth a muted darkness. On the other hand, Solaris is full of raging electrical storms and vivid light. One could make the case that the 6&7th characters in the film are Earth and Solaris. All of the casting was great, particularly Natascha McElhone, because she has a compelling face, that, in some points of the film looked other worldly, which allows you to accept that fact she isn't human. I also felt Soderbergh did a great job in giving the film a retro SCI-FI look, which didn't lock the viewer into thinking about technology, so that you could concentrate on the plot of the film, which is really where the viewer's focus is needed.The action in Solaris, is the mind of the viewer and the viewer's ability to accept what is put before them(Rheya) and to also think about what wasn't tangible on film, such as Gordon's visitor. For example, I think Snow is just an interpretation on human beings tendency to take on the characteristics of people around us, or assimilation. I think Snow is saying if there is complete assimilation, a part of the individual dies, or can't survive. Kelvin(Clooney)is a juxtaposition between the Kelvin on Earth, who ignores some clear signs that Rheya is unable to commit emotionally and has some psychological issues, which he chooses to ignore. Kelvin didn't see Rheya clearly on Earth, which causes problems for Rheya on Solaris, because she feels he remembered her wrongly. On the other hand, Kelvin on Solaris is willing to accept Rheya for what she is, whatever she is, because he needs her. The manipulation of memory to suit one's purpose is a dangerous thing on Solaris. Besides the issue of memory, Solaris brings up questions about the after life, death, guilt, and the thought of being accountable to the people we love and ourselves. Solaris is whatever was in the mind of the characters and the viewer. So, if you believe in reincarnation, you saw that flag in the film. I was glad there wasn't a clear cut answer at the end of the film, though I'm not sure after seeing Kelvin's finger heal, you don't know what's up at that point. I thought the pacing of the film did work. The question of what is real and what is memory and what is life and what is death, just seemed to go around in the film and gave the film a sense of suspended animation. Next, what was the purpose of Michael? When I first saw the film, I missed a quick glance of Michael on earth, being held by his father. Michael runs away from Kelvin the first time he encounters him on the spaceship, which may symbolize Kelvin's initial resistance of what Solaris was about, Kelvin was an intruder at that point. At the end of the film, we see the choice Kelvin makes and Michael takes his hand. Of course symbolically, you can see Michael as the arch angel, protector of heaven if that is where you were going with that character.The music was great, it was a wonderful character actor and I enjoyed the sounds. Watch the film again. Discuss it with someone. Thinking is good for you and no one should be disappointed in a film, and director that requires you to think. One more thing, I kept thinking about the rain and why did it keep raining on earth? Besides the spiritual aspects of water, rain has a tendency to distort vision and concentration. Oh yeah, Earth seemed to represent the monotony and repetition of life, so maybe the rain was like the drivel of becoming oblivious to daily function. No one on earth seemed to have any joy. Though everyone was in constant motion, traveling on trains, walking, etc, it seemed like no one was making progress. That's all I got. Bye!

Movie buffs should note one thing before watching Solaris: this is not a remake of Tarkovsky's masterpiece. This is a movie based on Stanislaw Lem's novel Solaris, and as such, much closer to the novel than Tarkovsky's movie. Tarkovsky could, at best, be said to be "inspired by" the novel. But comparing the two would be like comparing "Star Trek: Insurrection" to "Apocalypse now", simply because they were both inspired by the same novel ("Heart of Darkness").Those looking for a grand space opera, complete with laser beams going Whizz and space ships exploding with ear-deafening booms, are also in for disappointment. This is a drama, which happens to be set in a fairly distant future. As with the best of literary science fiction, it is about people, and about here and now, although the story works by introducing elements that we don't have in the world around us today.The pace is slow, the acting is brilliant, the story is powerful. And the title of my review compares it to "2001", since it tells us just how utterly, utterly alien an alien world will be. The trailer actually says most of what you need to know: "There are places where mankind is not ready to go".

reviews.review_title: Slow, confusing and ambiguous like these sorts of films are but there is plenty here to keep you busy once the film has ended.
reviews.content: Science-fiction is one of those tough little genres that offers plenty to chew on in the form of content and ideas and yet you can have two extremely stark science fiction films; there are your Star Wars films and your films like Starship Troopers and Aliens that are able to tie in the war and romance genres, amongst others but then there are your more drawn out science fiction films such as 2001: A Space Odyssey which in themselves can be something spectacular whilst remaining ambiguous. Other films like Blade Runner and Alien can also use familiar narrative structures and yet are able to deliver on an entertaining and sophisticated level; at least to the masses, anyway.Solaris is a film made by Steven Soderbergh, a man who I am rapidly developing a split opinion of; Sex, Lies, & Videotape was brilliant as was Ocean's Eleven albeit for different reasons; this twinned with Traffic which I thought was slightly overrated and Ocean's Twelve which was a mere exercise of cinematography and star power, if anything. Solaris is probably Soderbergh's most interesting film but that isn't saying it's his best in fact it's far from his best. Solaris actually emphasises 2001: A Space Odyssey's brilliance as a sci-fi film but also reinforces the fact that art can sometimes be entertaining as well as eerie  Solaris may have been a bizarre and confusing film as 2001 was but it wasn't particularly eerie and at times at least to me, felt slow and dreary since I wasn't exactly sure as to what was going on.The film takes on a range of themes and attempts to reference previous sci-fi films from the past. The situation is straight out of Alien although the 'enemy' is a force that is not physical but psychological; Solaris also tries to use the idea of mental illness and psychological disturbance as its underlining theme since most of its character will suffer from hallucinations or seem to suffer from very random bouts of anger with pretty much the whole crew acting like they've got some horrible, dark secret locked away inside them. This actually moves me onto my next item: the hallucinations. It would seem that a massive ball of glowing energy is bringing back people from the crew's past lives and putting them on board with them in a sort of sick, Big Brother sort of a twist. This is where Solaris falters because Rheya (McElhone) and Chris (Clooney) begin to fall for one another yet again and the film quickly turns into a mere love story that's set in space with the bulk of these flash backs taking place on Earth; suddenly it's not so much a sci-fi as a character in a romance film having flashbacks.It's also worth noticing that within these flashbacks, there are numerous conversations between people and friends of Chris and Rheya about God and religion; this being significant since most of the flashbacks are these two peoples love stories. Flashing back to the present in space and Rheya herself says that she is 'unable to communicate with her creator'  is this suggesting Solaris itself is indeed God? That this ball of energy can create life? because we are never sure if Rheya is a hallucination or indeed, a clone. This energy ball can clearly read minds and recreate organisms from raw memory right down to the colour of the person's eyes and their accent. This is where Solaris works because it's challenging the viewer to work out why certain people or things are there and what they're purpose is. The reference of the quote being that Rheya can't communicate with her creator since we can't communicate with God and the Solaris energy ball puts her in the same situation.It's worth saying that Solaris does not cover a lot of what it is. The purpose of the space ship, the reason the types of people that are on board were selected in the first place and why more people aren't sent remains unanswered. Also, the massive ball of energy is never really utilized as an element in the film: it is the reason there even is a film since it enables Chris to reconcile with Rheya both on Earth and in Space; remember that no one ever thinks to investigate Solaris further. I said it earlier but it still counts: Solaris is not a great film of sorts and only emphasises 2001: A Space Odyssey's brilliance since Solaris is a basic love story with a bizarre twist in the way it looks and feels. It's premise is interesting as a detective story but ends up as and consequently falters as a love story that's actually already happened down on Earth. Solaris is a film for people who will enjoy a good 'trip' but just like most sci-fi's, should never be a film you'll just 'pop in to give a watch'.

reviews.review_title: Slow - and a couple of catchy performances only
reviews.content: This movie has limited sci-fi spirit left, most of the depictions are about human relationships, guilt etc - the issues that "profound and deep" filmmakers are so interested in. But they can be easily dealt with on Earth, no need to move onto a spaceship and then forget about the rest of elements the sci-fi movies should include. Flashbacks become annoying soon, moreover, they are confusing as well. As for the cast, the strongest performances are carried out by George Clooney as Chris Kelvin and Viola Davis as Gordon; the remaining are rather ordinary.Remakes are usually worse than original versions and this is no exception. Steven Soderbergh is a great director in other genres, but he is no Andrey Tarkovsky who was a master of similar movies.

Solaris is based on the Stanislaw Lem novel. Owning both the 1972 Tarkovsky movie and the Soderbergh version of Solaris, comparisons between the two films are inevitable. However, I think it is important to treat the two movies as individual films.The plot is based around a space station orbiting around the planet Solaris, where the astronauts and a security team have either gone missing or are not very coherent. One of the astronauts aboard the space station contacts psychiatrist Chris Kelvin (Clooney) who flies off to investigate. He soon discovers some amazing developments that offer him a second chance, and questions how far anyone will go to grab that chance.I feel that Soderbergh really couldn't win however he made this film. This may be deserved to a degree as remakes are notoriously easy to criticise, and very rarely a good idea. This is one remake that may have some justification, the original film is nearly three hours long, and the shorter version may encourage some viewers to seek out the Tarkovsky version as a result of watching, which has to be a good thing. This version could be viewed as a companion piece or an introduction of sorts to the Tarkovsky version, although it is a fine film in it's own right.Solaris is criticised at the same time for being boring, too short, too complicated, and too simplified. It is also derided for having two very good looking leading actors. At 90 minutes it never has time to become boring, and while the pace is never fast, the viewer must have a very short attention span to get even close to boredom. The character development is achieved by flashback, which in the important dream sequences makes perfect sense, and releases information slowly but very interestingly. Solaris needs to be watched closely to piece together all the threads of the plot, but is not overly complicated. Some information is kept to a minimum, the viewer has to make some assumptions and use some imagination, which may be a bridge to far for some. Clooney and Natascha McElhone make excellent leads in my opinion, and anyone who says that Clooney can't act should watch more of his films.The special effects are beautiful, but not overused. The sets and locations are very sparse and futuristic while still being recognisable and possible. The music by Cliff Martinez is excellent and captures the mood brilliantly.Overall Solaris is a very moody, almost hypnotic film that requires some effort. The acting and plot development grab you and means that you keep watching to see how things develop if someone is given a second chance, and the implications that it brings.

Chris Kelvin (George Clooney) is approached to join a crew on board a space station. The crew are studying a phenomenon known as Solaris and Kelvin is asked to join the remaining crew members to discover what is going on there and also to recover the remaining crew members - only two crew members remain on the space station as the other members of the crew have either committed suicide or simply disappeared - this includes the Security Task Force who were originally assigned to the task. What seems like a seemingly ordinary task for Kelvin soon proves difficult when he witnesses the phenomena of Solaris first-hand.Solaris markets itself as a film full of intrigue and mystery, but the reality here is that it isn't really any of these things. Here are some of the problems;For a start, all the characters are bland here with Doctor Snow starting every sentence with the words 'Hmmm' 'Yeah' 'Well' 'Hey'. He never has anything interesting or useful to say (although him being part of Solaris all along does explain why), but even so as a character he annoyed the hell out of me - he both sounded and looked like a stoner. Doctor Gordon was given very little screen time and as a result made very little impact on the film. Clooney and McElhone were sleepwalking through the film most of the time, but I think this was due to the dull script which clearly limited their performances. The dialogue was also dull and rather meaningless for the most part.The bulk of the film revolves around Kelvin and his wife Rheya (Natascha McElhone). The film flits between his memories of their time together and his existence with a carbon copy of his wife that has been created by Solaris. This could potentially have been interesting, but Soderbergh seemed more pre-occupied with giving the film long silly dream sequences which often contain little narrative content meaning that the film often seems pretentious rather than insightful or interesting. Another thing that angered me about the film is the sheer arrogance of the whole thing; I got the impression that Soderbergh genuinely believes that he's actually made something clever and thought-provoking when in reality that just isn't the case. I suppose the only thing that can really be taken away from this is that it asks the question 'If you had another chance to go back and put things right would you do it?', but this whole concept is tackled in such a boring manner that I just didn't really care by the end.It's no surprise that the critics mostly gushed over this as it's the sort of film that they can claim that they get because it's deep and meaningful and intelligent and that if you're thick you won't get it. All I'll say is that I did understand what the film was trying to say, but still thought that it was a pretentious load of baloney.

Based on the novel by Stanislaw Lem, this cerebral sci-fi yarn has psychologist Chris Kelvin (George Clooney) being sent to investigate strange happenings on a remote space station orbiting an odd planet. Kelvin has ghosts of his own to deal with, as he is haunted by memories of his wife, a suicide victim. His mission is to find out why the crew members have not come home and to explain their bizarre behavior (as evidenced by their plaintive messages imploring Kelvin to visit).There have been many movies that depict what happens when strange happenings are investigated, and as in most of those movies, nothing here is really as it seems. The tone for the tension and suspense is set almost immediately, as Kelvin awakes onboard the station next to his dead wife!Who is she? What is she? Is she really his wife, returned from the grave? What affect does Solaris the planet have on this.... this entitity? Is Kelvin turning as nutty as the remaining crew members? Is he hallucinating his wife? Is he even on the space station - is this a bad dream?
Devoid of outlandish special effects and with a threadbare cast, the movie must lean on the solemn plot and the stoic acting of Clooney. This is his show all the way - his is the flawed hero and the willing victim combined into one multilayered character. It's some of Clooney's best work; he cannot rely on his whiplash smile or suave charm. Neither of those qualities, although surely valuable in other films, can help his character here.Like the best thinking-man's sci-fi, Solaris doesn't answer every question. It's mystical without being too abstract, and its quiet strength lies in what one doesn't see.The only drawback is that it's often tough to understand the actions of the crew members, including Kelvin. Are they insane, or merely acting? Hamlet himself may not have been able to discern the truth here. Compounding this is the sometimes unlikeability of Kelvin himself. It would be taking the easy way out, however, to have made him into some sort of superhero. Therefore even though it's tough at times to relate to Kelvin and consequently to root for him to succeed, this is a successful, well-made film, thanks to its complexities and multilayered main character.

(Small spoilers ahead)Proof that there's intelligent life out there  well, in the American cinema industry at least  arrives by the plateful with Solaris'. Imbued with a special vision and hallmarked throughout with a rare integrity, it's the kind of movie that makes you almost, but not quite forget, the catchpenny rubbish of Mel Gibson and Signs'.Unfortunately though, being intelligent is one thing, intelligible, quite another. And where this version of Solaris' is concerned, the eclipse of meaning is total.Solaris' is not, according to Soderbergh, a planet in the conventional sense. But an organism. An organism which draws upon the subconscious mind of those who come too close to it. (Andrei Tarkovsky played it the same way with his 1972 version, though at least as a film-maker battling against the Soviet regime he had a pretty good grasp on how mind-warping can ensue when one is drawn in too close to a monumental ideology).Soderbergh's organism, however, seems unrepresentative of anything at all. It exists. And whilst that's okay, scientifically speaking -- because organisms don't have to have a hidden agenda -- it's anything but okay, dramatically speaking. And that's the problem here: Solaris', meant to be a major presence in the movie, has no impact at all - there's not a single Solaris PoV shot of the spacecraft hovering above it, not a single attempt to stamp its purpose, substance and identity upon the audience's consciousness.(Think back, if you will, to how Kubrick handled this kind of thing with HAL in 2001: A Space Odyssey -- the sudden HAL PoV shot, lip-reading the mouths of the astronauts, is as cinematically chilling as anything Hitchcock ever contrived).Here though, Solaris doesn't, er, do anything. Glimpsed through the spacecraft's windows, it changes colour, and in the closing sequence seems more vivid and more active than before. Why though is not explained: the organism simply is', so whether it's getting excited about preying upon human minds, or hyper-charged at the interaction of those minds with itself, is a non-sequitur: we don't know what it cares about, so we've nothing to care about, either.Little wonder, then, that Clooney is reduced to looking worried and confused and then even more worried and more confused, whilst McElhone pops up, or does not pop up, in sequences so reminiscent of Last Year In Marienbad' that you begin to wonder if Resnais, not Tarkovsky, was the director Soderbergh had in mind when embarking on this odyssey into what is real and what is not.That said though, what Solaris' certainly isn't is a cogent exploration of themes like love and hate, loss and redemption, or even religion and spirituality: though you sense Soderbergh and his producers would like to think Solaris' touches on all these, viewers less inclined to self-delusion will note that instead of some grand and enigmatic narrative arc, there is instead only a giant black hole here into which collapses all sense and all logic (the screenplay's conclusion isn't so much mysterious as woeful, inexplicable not in the sense that some great truths are carefully hidden within but inexplicable because Soderbergh cannot actually explain what point he he has been trying to make in the preceding, achingly-long 92 minutes).More worrying than that though is the way Soderbergh yet again seems incapable of improving upon an original: The Limey' wasn't merely one of the worst films of 1999, it was about as bad a remake as it's possible to achieve with source material as brilliant as Get Carter'. ..For older audiences, however, it's neither the Russian version nor anything by Resnais or Kubrick which is most likely to float clear of the subconscious at the conclusion of Solaris'. Rather, it's remembrance of sci-fi movie that scared the wits out of my generation of schoolkids -- the one in which the secrets of the mind came to knock at the doors of human existence.Forty-eight years on from the time it was made, Fred Wilcox's Forbidden Planet' still holds mesmeric sway: it had a tale to tell, and it knew exactly how to tell it. Would that Solaris' was worthy of a similar verdict.Rating: 7/10.

reviews.review_title: George's Bottom (2001 Mk 3 with Deep Meaningful Thoughts)
reviews.content: This film pulls off a double whammy  it has sufficient intellectually stimulating material (of the what-is-reality and what-is-intelligence brand of sci-fi mind games) and it also has George Clooney's naked charms artistically photographed on more than one occasion. This means the ladies can spin on endlessly to us guys about what an interesting movie it is but break out into an enthusiastic glow when describing its more basic appeal to one another. Clooney goes off to investigate a space station where the radiations from the nearby planet turn people's dream characters into tangible reality. Enter Clooney's dead wife, now alive again (several times) in the curvaceous shape of Natascha McElhone, providing emotionally-challenging love (and lust) interest as Clooney struggles with the nature of reality. Directed in classy Soderberg style with Space Odyssey' type music to provide lots of Deep Meaningful Moments  who cares if the storyline gets a bit fuzzy at the end? It's one of those Bring Your Own Meaning films, far too clever to be dismissed as popcorn fodder, and entertaining enough to make everyone feel they've got their jollies in respectable art-appreciation style.

reviews.review_title: Yawnaris AKA Steven Soderbergh shouldn't be allowed behind a camera.
reviews.content: Solaris Someone warned me not to watch this movie. Steven Soderbergh shouldn't be allowed behind a camera. The man just can not direct anything with a budget of over 10 million dollars. Anyway, the biggest problem with this movie is that it is needlessly boring. The acting is wasted thanks to quick camera work sprinkled with bad angles, over exposed close ups and basically everything a fresh out of film school director would do when he is trying too hard to be artistic for the sake of being artistic. The actual story that this movie is based on is a solid enough novel with an actual plot but we only get to see it during the first 5 minutes and the final 7 minutes of the film. The rest of the film is just filler. Avoid this film. It is pointless and you'll get nothing out of it.

Not having read the book, I cannot direct my comments in terms relative to original excellence etc. I saw a movie, pure and simple and it stands on its own for me.It is a pretentious philosophical sci-fi psychodrama suffering from endless views of a lady's profile (with no apparent purpose) and of the main hero sweating in his wife-beater shirt or showing his buttocks, that was frankly far from scary and just plain boring. It also suffers from what I call the 2001 malaise, that is an ending that is just as much subject to individual interpretation as it is a loose end that appears to need tying. An intellectual challenge? Only if one decides to make it so, and I was hardly inspired to do so.The (real) characters never appear to be in any actual physical danger. The only thing threatened is their ability to distinguish real from unreal etc. or figuring out a reason for the whole mess. This movie could have been aptly titled "Confused." Considering how much of its running time is cluttered with filler love-making scenes and somewhat obscure fade backs, it could have been better done as a much shorter Twilight Zone episode where the uncertainty of an ending has always been at its best. Too much film wasted on facial closeups and not enough on a better evolution of the story line. The things that will stick with me longest about this movie is probably the hump on Natasha's nose.

reviews.review_title: "Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?" in space
reviews.content:
"Solaris" is virtually literally about how men are from Mars and women are from Venus.  As a "Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?" in space, including a fantasy child, with the "solaris" space phenomenon replacing alcohol as a loosening agent, we see that a husband mostly remembers seduction and sex from his marriage, while his wife remembers how he didn't listen or communicate.
The stream of noisy guys who walked out of my audience were clearly expecting more of a sci fi adventure with George Clooney, not that the isolation of space would be an intellectual metaphor. But this is Clooney's best, and most emotional, role since "E.R."The bare, metallic environment of a space station leaves the characters with only emotions and memories to rely on, with fatal/sanity consequences as the past is in effect re-enacted over and over.  The rich, gleaming cinematography and changing, pulsing, ambient sound are important in maintaining the tension. I do now want to read the novel that Steven Soderburgh based this on and see the earlier, Russian movie version that gets shown on cable.

Solaris is a brilliant stand-alone effort that does not require an in-depth knowledge neither of Lem nor of the brilliant past effort of Andrei Tarkovsky. Soderbergh's true auteuristic production takes the Lem material and condenses it into one eternal question: is our memory of a person or event trustworthy, real, entire, intact? Solaris takes a stance, much the same way that Eternal Sunshine did a few years later, and claims that, in the end, the question doesn't matter. Although our memory is insufficient to construct our lives, human life, human resolve, human emotion is designed to "make do". Edited, shot, adapted and directed by Soderbergh, it is difficult to find any fault with Solaris at all. Clooney proves again why he is the current darling of quasi-indie directors. Overall wonderful and deeply moving, Solaris is one of the 13 films I have awarded 10/10 to out of 1500 films I have seen.

reviews.review_title: Not for everyone, but captivating for the rest of us
reviews.content: Most people are vexed to one degree or another by the question what if I'd made a different decision? Education, careers, lovers, children...I think it's only human to wonder.What this movie does a good job of pointing out is that interrogation is flawed by the way we remember people and things...we were after all only a part of what happened.In the end, the different decision was Kelvin's to make...which he did by going to Rheya instead of way from.Most "different" decisions are merely a change of one's own perception...free of abuse of course...if parties want to be together...then most relationships can work when all is truly forgiven...whether infractions are real or imagined.As to where Chris and Rheya are...or if they really are...remember that nothing is every destroyed...only transformed.

This is the first George Clooney movie that I'm very disappointed in. I've got the book but never read it, and after watching this movie I'm glad I never did! This movie is filled with flashbacks between Kelvin and Rheya that does nothing more than fill up time. Dead wife comes back again to haunt him?? I mean, what is the point here?!

God, this movie was well written.  God, this movie was well acted.  God, this movie was boring.  Guess what this movie is all about?(Possible Spoiler)....God!.....(End of spoiler).Possibly the most fatal combination in movie-making is god (or God, if you prefer) and science fiction.  As the original "Star Trek The Motion Picture" and "2001 A Space Odyssey" proved, putting a space traveler in pursuit of the concept of what happens after we die is about as exciting as watching grass grow.  Thought-provoking...yes.  A great dinner topic at your next Mensa meeting...yes.  Just please, PLEASE, don't waste the talents of fine actors such as you see in "Solaris" on such deep and dense material again. George Clooney is a great guy, but I found myself flashing back and forth between this performance and his character in "From Dusk Till Dawn" just to stay awake.  Noble effort, George, but you might want to get a new agent. He'll probably want to put you in the remake of "Ghandi" next.  How about being the next James Bond?  One can only hope.....

Being a Russian of Polish origin, i cannot but treat this film with a fair share of criticism. I'd like to point out two positive facts: 1) the makers of the film watched Tarkovsky's "Solyaris" (1972) VERY attentively, and they may have read the novel by Lem; 2) the makers managed to avoid the blockbuster stunts and special effects, which helped to preserve the atmosphere of the original novel. There is also a pleasant surprise - Clooney is certainly an adequate choice for the part of Chris; he has more than fine looks to offer though he also studied Banionis' Chris too attentively. Unfortunately, there is a drawback - in contrast with "Solyaris" (1972) the film has problems with holding the viewer's attention all the time; there are "dropouts", as it's hard to retain the same degree of concentration throughout the film. In this respect "Solaris" (2002) loses points to "Solyaris" (1972; Tarkovsky used symbols (like seaweed and the Breugel picture)just in the right places, so that they served both for relaxation and for reflection. I also wonder why the makers of the film decided to rename the characters - why did Khari become Rheya? why did Sartorius and Snauth give way to Snow and Gordon? Why on earth was the all-male crew of Lem's novel transformed and included an Afro-American woman never mentioned in the original? Is it impossible to shoot a film without an Afro-American on the cast as it is wrong from the point of view of political correctness, and the author may go to hell?In spite of all these drawbacks, I'd like to say that the film seems to continue the chain of problems raised in Tarkovsky's "Stalker". There the main characters went to the Zone to find a room where all the most cherished wishes could come true. In "Stalker" the characters reach the room, but they don't enter, as they do not know which of their wishes will be granted by the Zone, they don't know whether the dark side of their nature will be revealed or not.They do not trust themselves and have no faith. "Solaris" (2002) may be telling us to learn to trust. The giant thinking planet acts as God restoring the long-dead beloved and granting wishes. Do you remember that at the end Rheya says that everything has been pardoned and that what was does not matter anymore? So if gods give us presents having searched our souls, shall we doubt and send back the gifts?

This film will not appeal to those who think Star Wars and Star Trek is what sci-fi is about. The film caters more for the intellectual sci-fi buff. A psychological thriller come love story dealing with ones inner most guilt and desires. Thought provoking well presented film. Clooney is cast in a role far removed from the genre he usually stars in. Not having read the book or seen the original I had no preconceived expectation and found the film watchable although it could be slow at times. The special effects are believable especially the majestic opening scene as Clooney's ship approaches the space station orbiting Solaris. The score does the job of setting the mood. Overall not a bad film.

The problem Soderbergh faced with Solaris is that it is ultimately going to be compared by a lot of people to Tarkovsky's 1972 version. I have seen the latter and although it has some excellent moments it is a very self indulgent movie for the Director I suspect. It is a fantastic piece of cinema in some aspects, but rambling and tortuously slow at some points. Therefore in my opinion a remake was certainly a good idea to make the story more accessible to people that would not watch, or have not seen this movie.In respect of Solaris 2002, I found this to be an excellent movie. Clooney puts in a mainly good and emotive performance, which is fundamental to the story line. People have decried Jeremy Davies performance, but I think he was playing a bizarre character hence acts well... bizarrely! Viola Davis is also very good in the slightly smaller part of Helen Gordon. In my opinion Natascha McElhone steals the film though as the haunting yet enchanting Rheya.So what is the movie about? I'll try and cover this without giving too much away about the plot. Well the story covers many things, and although it is put forward as a science fiction movie the science takes a back seat in the main. For me it was principally a romance, and a story of unrequited love. Given the choice would we step back into the past and try and live things again. It is also to a lesser extent philosophising about what makes us human, and if we aren't human does it matter? (in a similar way to Blade Runner) So two fairly deep topics. I would stress that this movie is not for everyone, but if you like carefully played romance, and philosophy with a twist, you may like this movie.Also of note is the soundtrack written by Cliff Martinez which provides a very good extra dimension to the film, and accompanies the interplay with Chris and Rheya beautifully.For me, 5 out of 5. A classic.

It was said that Jim Cameron was the original director on this project, but chose to remain a producer. I think that Solaris would have been competent in Cameron's hands. Instead that task goes to director Steven Soderberg, whose attempts to craft an emotionally complex story just turn sloppy and dull, with torpid performances from a descent cast, and no life.The story is essentially about an astronaut sent out to explore an abandoned ship orbiting a celestial body known as Solaris which has mystical powers, once on board, he sees hallucinations of his long dead wife, and his past slowly comes back to haunt him.Solaris does succeed in looking mystical and sometimes dreamy, but many of the sets feel just as hollow and empty as the story. Nonlinear, unengaging, and totally unclear, in the end Solaris amounts to nothing but a reminder of how brilliant '2001' is.

reviews.review_title: Experimental Effort, But An Utter Failure
reviews.content: In his many years as a director, Steven Soderbergh has always had the desires to go beyond how other directors get their pictures done. He takes risks that others wouldn't dare to. He also remains loyal to his independent origins and takes liberation towards making them provocative albeit eccentric. And though his motives are not problematic and his experimentations deserve some sort of applause, but like all good scientists, some experiments don't always go as planned. "Solaris" is one of those films that is very daring in its intentions, however, it's quite lumbering and dreary in its delivery.Starring the always cordial George Clooney, who sacrificed his perky charms in exchange for an eternally drab character, the green backgrounds from "Solaris" has similar vides to another, more successful Soderbergh picture "Traffic". The whole cinematography behind is immaculate. The camera work is handled with caare a percision to create the correct atmosphere. The problem is that the gloominess is quite overkill and doesn't offer anything uplifting or spontaneous and feels that remaining gloomy is a symbol of artistic intelligence.Clooney stars as Dr. Chris Kelvin, a widowed therapist who willingly follow the same dreary path of existence everyday in the future not that far behind as I speak. He may wear stylish clothes, but his television looks archaic even for 2002 standards. While basking in his melancholic ways, he gets interrupted by a colleague of his named Dr. Gibarian (Ulrich Tukur) who resides at a space station near the planet Solaris summons him to come forward right away because something urgent is happening though we'll only know what's happening once Chris arrives.When Kelvin arrives at the space station, blood stains strangely start to materialize and if that's not strange enough, crew members had all except for two died off from suicide, including Gibarian himself. The two survivors include a demented, but amusing man named Snow (Jeremy Davies) who's really not reliable of information. The other survivor is Dr. Helen Gordon (Viola Davis) is even less outgoing.In reality, their taciturn ways is just a figure of speech by ways of storytelling. Anything remotely outgoing for them will very likely get them out of their comfort zone. We don't want that now don't we? The station has a macabre possession where deceased love ones start to manifest. In Kelvin's case it was his deceased wife Rheya (Natascha McElhone). It seems that the mysterious planet that's being studied, might actually be the planet istelf studying the humans. By doing that it seems to go into a person's dreams and create duplicates of the people who are in their dreams.The idea seems very weird, and it's no surprise that Soderbergh wanted to direct this kind of film. It also caught the eyes of Russian film director Andrei Tarkovsky in 1972 who made an equally sluggish movie adapted from the novel by Polish author Stanislaw Lem. And sure the film reflects upon the subject matters of life. Death, grief, redemption, and neddiness, it just feel like it filmed in a boiler room. It has Kubrick intention in terms of subject matter and keeps its distance from the audience.There really isn't much of a sci-fi story, instead we get a love story, bombarded with illusionary manifestations, backed up by a myriad of flashbacks, and plenty of space inclined dialogue. The worst aspect of the dialogue is that someone speaks and then they pause for a long time. It's as though they either forgot their lines or that Soderbergh deliberately made them pause between conversations. It just makes the slow and heavy-handed movie all the more labouring.Soderbergh's script never really moves the settings very much and we don't really explore the surroundings of the planet. Kelvin's deceased wife has came back from the dead (or is she?). There is nothing raptus about it, or anything joyous either. It's just a barrage of questions regarding Rheya's existence. She might be a cloned duplicate of Rheya, but in reality it's not Rheya which adds nothing but confusion ad nauseum. The intense situation is neither relieving or happy, but more leanient toward philosophical and theoretical in its intentions. When he glazes into her existance, he question his own level of sanity and see if he can piece something together for all this to make any logic behind it. The end result is both revolting and mundane.It all results in a very trance inducing predicament that will likely get viewers to become very impatient rather fast. It doesn't help that the score by Cliff Martinez is one-note and uninspiring. There will be times when a person will gaze at the window and notice a red thing swirling which was to be Solaris. The window scenes are the only outdoor moments we will find in "Solaris" which makes the whole movie so isolated and grounded. The strange thing is that in spite of "Solaris" being a big-budgeted movie, there is really nothing that shows it.

The original book by Stanislav Lem explores the truly alien nature of the planet Solaris with it's inexplicable living ocean. The ocean that can bring your dead relatives back to life, and conjure anything from your memories. One of my favourite interpretations of alien life because we never get to understand it and we are left with a feeling of wonder afterwardsThis movie on the other hand, is a love story using the planet Solaris as a backdrop. Just look at the poster...I feel if the cast were believable, (stop putting Clooney in non rom com roles that's all he can do) the script was written properly, and the direction was good this could have been a good adaptation but for me it's just a weak effort. If you're not going to portray Lem's vision of the living planet itself as one of the main characters then why even bother?

reviews.review_title: After 30 years, Hollywood has yet to learn from Tarkovsky
reviews.content: I congratulate producer James Cameron and Steven Soderberg for deciding to film Stanislaw Lem's book. I congratulate Soderberg for being more intelligent than George Lucas and company who reduced Hollywood science fiction in space to literally loud films for the aural senses and special effects feasts for the visual senses. And yet...what a disaster Soderberg's Solaris turned out to be!!If you liked this film see Andrei Tarkovsky's film made 30 years ago when most moviegoers around the world thought Russians only made third rate propaganda war movies.Tarkovsky's film gripped you in so many ways that Soderberg cannot. Tarkovsky's choice of Bach's music "Chorale in F minor", his casting of the brilliant Estonian actor Yuri Jarvet (Grigori Kozintsev's choice of King Lear that had Lord Laurence Olivier doffing his cap) as Dr Snauth a character Soderberg tried to recreate ineffectively in Snow (Jeremy Davis), Tarkovsky's brilliant visuals (Soderberg does copy the rain on the windows)--give you sufficient reasons to realize that Andrei Tarkovsky remains one of the finest filmmakers of the century--a filmmaker who most moviegoers do not adequately know about in the US and elsewhere.What amused me is that before the film was released there were the publicity about how Soderberg wanted to make the film as one superior to Tarkovsky. Soderberg is no Tarkovsky and will never be.Tarkovsky did not use nudity to make his film sell--his film has made waves even when the Communists were afraid of Tarkovsky's messages and suppressed his work in the Seventies in many ways--all because of the care he took with the direction, the script, the editing, the photography and the music. His script, so different from that of the Soderberg film, delivered more punch without a Clooney and his fabulous voice. Hollywood's answer to Tarkovsky is probably the late Orson Welles and in recent times, Terrence Mallick. Cameron probably knew his limitations as a director and cleverly opted to produce the movie. Soderberg thought he was bigger than he is and attempted to remake Tarkovsky's work without even acknowledging the work of the Russian genius in the few press statements I came across.If the Soderberg film appeals to you, it is Stanislaw Lem that gets you not Soderberg. While the film is better than the average Hollywood product this film does not stand up to great cinema elsewhere in any department save for the above-average sound editing.
Wonderful filmBeautiful to watch and to listenSoft, gentle and thoughtfulCinematic heaven if you will forgive the pun - we are all forgiven at the end

I enjoyed this movie.  I thought George was wonderful.  I also liked Jeremy's character.  I go to the movies to be entertained.  And I was most definitely entertained with this one.  There was enough science fiction in the movie to appeal to me without turning me off.

reviews.review_title: The BEST scifi film since the first MATRIX
reviews.content: SOLARIS is the rare modern scifi film that is a meditation on ideas instead of wham bam lazer fights in space. Many pseudo-intellectuals dismissed the film as a "second chance at love". The main theme of the film is the exploration of the meaning of relationships. Chris Kelvin (Clooney) while on a space station circling the newly found planet Solaris is "visited" by a flesh & blood facsimilie of his dead wife Rheya (Natasha McElhone). She isn't a dream nor is she simply an alien disguised as her. She is a mirror of his memories of his wife--HIS memories. This is the theme of the film: what are our relationships but for our memories of what has already happened? How much can we really know a person? How much can we approximate how another person feels, how things feel to their touch, how things smell to them? The "visitor" replica of Rheya is a conglomeration of Chris' memories of her--but that is just how she begins "life". The Visitor Rheya is conscious of what is happening & knows she isn't really Rheya & makes Chris aware if this, yet he still cannot let her go as the love that he felt during his troubled marrige has come back & its a feeling he can't abandon easily. Which also begs the question what is the meaning of love?SOLARIS is a beautifully made, well acted, moody film THAT IS NOT A REMAKE. Like the 1972 Russian film by the great Tarkovsky, it is based on the novel of the same name by the Polish writer Stanislav Lem. The dimwits who don't understand the subtlties of Soderberg's film have given themselves a pass by dismissing it as a "bad remake". If all one gets from seeing Soderberg's adaptation of Lem's novel is that it is a "second chance at love" story then there is NO WAY they ever saw Tarkovsky's 3 1/2 hour snail paced film. Chances are they never saw 2001: A SPCE ODYSSEY either but they probobly read a lot of reviews so that they can bullsh*t their way through a discussion of it.

I loved Stanislav Lem's novel for it's enigmatic mood, sophisticated humour and the thought-provoking speculation about conciousness and language. It's one of those few sci-fi stories where the techno-babble is actually interesting, rather than just a backdrop.The movie has very little of all that. Soderbergh basically takes one of the most intriguing sci-fi novels available, removes everything that makes it interesting and presents the viewer with a massively tedious love story. Instead of subtle humour, there's a comic relief techie. Instead of filosophic speculation, there are countless closeups on Natascha McElhones face.The ending really says it all. The novel ends with Kelvin sitting at Solaris' shores, touching the immense and silent gelatinous beast, feeling that some kind of understanding may be possible. The movie ends (surprise, surprise) with a spectacular explosion while the survivors scurry off to the rescue shuttle. That's right, standard Hollywood ending #1a. Aaargh!

reviews.review_title: Great remake and great film in general
reviews.content: Been meaning to write my thoughts on this film for quite a while now. And after recently watching The Midnight Sky, I finally got around to it.Really loved this film back when it first came out and after watching it again recently, I can say for certain that it is on par with the original for me. Now I know that's going to draw a lot of hate, but it's just how I feel and believe me, I absolutely love the original Solaris!

I thought Schizopolois was hard to understand. Solaris is a film that moves at a snail's pace and by the time something happens or is said you've forgoten what happened just before. Steven Soderbergh is by far the most over rated Director in Hollywood. He's had a few good films, but he's definitely no superstar. Stay away from Solaris unless you've forgotten to refill tour sleeping pill prescription and you need something to put you to sleep.

(spoilers)The music is awesome.  Very calming.  But thats about all it's good for.The movie is so wacky, you don't really know whats going on.  Everytime you think you understand something, they blow it away.  I'm not sure what the original is like , but it's probably better than this blob.  I myself probably won't watch it again.  Sure the movie makes you think,  but 9 years from now I'll probably still be thinking.  Score I might buy, but I'd tell others try to stay away.  Not because the acting sucks (it doesn't..  in fact the acting is better than Monster)  But the story/plot is so darn short and the movie flies by so quickly, You are left wondering if you got ripped off or not.4/10Quality: 2/10 Entertainment: 4/10 Replayable: 1/10

Solaris 2002 is completely underwhelming. I did not watch the original Solaris from Tarkovsky and am not familiar with the literary original. I can only rate the film itself. And honestly, the only thing that attracts attention here is the acting of George Clooney. There is nothing else to watch here. The plot is so generally delusional.

The trouble with trying to film Lem's story ( rather too short to call a novel ) is that the events are all "internal" and subjective. There is almost nothing "external" or objective to depict. Why then try to make a movie of it? I am of the opinion that Tarkovsky ( you'll pardon the spelling ) did it because he wanted to make a science-fiction movie to compare with Kubrick's 2001 of four years earlier. In that he undoubtedly failed, producing a sprawling undisciplined behemoth that compensated for the lack of action with a surfeit of to-camera monologues. That he unconsciously aspired to the KJubrickesque is revealed by his preoccupation with the circular motif that was the visual signature of 2001, the space station depicted in Bob McCall's poster for the movie. Yet, whereas that wheel in space corresponded to the engineering requirements for the centrifugal simulation of gravity, in the Tarkovsky version, the circularity of the space station has no meaningful relevance whatsoever ( the floors are perpendicular to the direction in which gravity would be simulated ). It is, rather, a kind of stylistic Freudian slip, echoing the influence of Kubrick's masterpiece on the Russian wannabe.Why would Soderbergh choose to re-make the story? Possibly, by relay, there is an echo of Tarkovskies motivation, in that the Russian's movie, for all it's inadequacies, has been hailed a classic in the west. Maybe Soderbergh was drawn to that. But maybe he was also interested in those very themes which make the story so challenging to enact. Maybe he also falls into the same trap. But, whereas the earlier version relied on talk, here the drama is conveyed entirely in another medium, also not visual, yet entirely cinematic: the score.Cliff Martinez' score is undoubtedly the star of the movie without which it would be almost nothing. The music is an accomplished pastiche of compositions by John Adams, Philip Glass and, appropriately, Gyorgi Ligeti. I had not noticed Martinez' music for Sex Lies and Videotape or Traffic. I really cannot remember it. But I love the monumental quality of John Adams' music, and here Martinez has copied that to breathtakingly emotive effect. In particular, it is the use of gigantic floating chords that characterises John Adams' most dramatic work,a kind of aural surf repeatedly breaking in a suspended, ever imminent crescendo like a musical tsunami. This technique Martinez borrows in a number of scenes, even introducing wind instruments into what is a predominantly string sound-scape. The effect is to paint in the drama of shifting emotions that no one can either see or make visible. This he couples and juxtaposes with the excitement provided by his bright, high-temp rhythmic line. The effect makes the movie.The supporting star of the movie is the design of the sets. The steel and alloy effects are highly technical, impersonal yet not harsh or intrusive. However, we again find a further continuation of the circular motif echoed down the decades from Kubrick's 2001. Here those circles are every bit as meaningless in engineering terms as they were in the Tarkovsky version. And in all the various other sci-fi movies where spaceships are designed in the circular by people with no grasp of engineering or any understanding why the structures in Kubrick's timeless vision are that way.The movie at hand seriously lets itself down at the very end when it seems to trip into some kind of superficial religious cliché: "Everything is forgiven" indeed!

Soderbergh delivers again.  It helps to be in the right mood to watch Solaris.  If you are, take the journey.  Soderbergh is aware of the right mood to strike, from the music and visuals of the planet, down to the restrained editing and spare use of visual FX.  This isn't a movie for idiots or those looking for the next "Terminator". Some movies aspire towards something more, and this movie is one of them. Thank God for Soderbergh.  He writes, directs, edits, and does the cinematography.  You don't need an army to make a great film, just a sober, mindful, skillful artist.  Also, I'm glad Clooney has decided to take on harder projects beyond films such as "Dusk to Dawn".  I want there to be as many different kinds of film as there are different kinds of books, and Solaris is a different kind of film indeed.  It's the only sci/fi film since 2001 to truly share a sense of the infinite.

Solaris is the story of a psychologist who encounters what appears to be his dead wife on a space station near an alien planet. The story was brought to life by Soviet director Andrei Tarkovsky in 1972. I saw Tarkovsky's version for the first time recently, and it blew me away. I actually prefer it to its Western counterpart, 2001: A Space Odyssey (1968). So I was curious about how a remake of Tarkovsky's film would hold up.Steven Soderbergh's 2002 version of Solaris doesn't have a lot wrong with it, but throughout I kept asking why the remake was necessary. The original is good enough, why do we need a new one? A desire for a shorter film? A preference not to read subtitles? An old inclination to boycott communism? Such reasons sound lazy or silly to me.
