This movie lacks a plot, suspense, interest, and anything else that a movie needs to hold your interest.  The movie is very predictable with a poorly written storyline -- no romance...no sci-fi...no intrigue.  It was a total waste of time and money (as was noticed by others who walked out during the movie).

I can remember watching the original Tarkovsky adaptation of Stanislaw Lem's "Solaris" many moons ago. Despite its length, lack of space battles and its massive longueurs, I was mesmerised.When I saw that Hollywood was gearing up to remake this classic Russian film, I was sceptical. I waited until the film was shown on TV rather than go to the cinema to see it. Now I wish that I'd seen it on the big screen instead.Stephen Soderberg has managed to turn in a movie that broods, shocks and entrances as much as the Tarkovsky version in a more viewable 2 hour running time. DO NOT go to see this movie if you like space battles and simple story lines. "Solaris" is a tale of love, loss and general weirdness, not "Star Wars". Not all Sci-fi has to be driven by special effects.

Where do I start? What a secret hit this was for me, saw a poster on the wall at the cinema's for this and thought George Clooney? No way I will ever watch this, I don't care for him at all, but how wrong I was. I found it sitting at the local video store and there was nothing else so I gave it a go, well I have watched this film nearly 20 times, and every time it grabs me, every time I try and work out that ending. Best sound score, and it is the most visually stunning sci-fi movie ever. I don't care for romance, but this film hits the spot! What a mind twisting story. I don't care for George C but I think he was perfect for this role. The cinematography was fantastic, the rain, the surroundings, the colors and so on. Like I said I never ever get enough of this film. I gave this film to my older brother and he loved it, my younger sister did as well, but the so called love of my life at the time canned it! But hey we are all different and sure it's not every once cup of tea. 10 out of 10 and the best film for me ever.

reviews.review_title: Metaphors aren't always clearly explained, I see.
reviews.content: Steve Martin clearly said it right in the Academy Awards, two years ago: "The trailers give away to much of the movie". Indeed. Solaris was wrapped up in big expectation: the reported George Clooney's nudity; Steven Soderberg writing and the return of James Cameron. The story goes that a mission to the planet Solaris, in an unknown future is on the verge of jeopardy. Security teams have been sent and have not returned, and the crew has lost contact, aledgedly insane. Dr. Chris Kelvin is sent in as a specialized psychiatrist, whose head is shaken up by the recent death of his wife. When he arrives he has to deal with the strangeness of the remaining crew as well as the visits of her dead wife that abound in his thought. As producers said, the movie is all about second chances, as well as choices, being the whole thing just a metaphor. However, Soderberg messes up in the writing passing everything on the directing. The trailer suggested something different. The trailer came out as one of the best - as long with The Two Towers and X2 - of the year. Cliff Martinez's score although present wasn't there. It was needed something powerful and striking, whereas what we get is almost none. George Clooney and Natasha McHelone's performances alternate between sublime and dull, coming as a result dull, the supporting Jeremy Davies does it all on what acting is concerned. The planet Solaris, the mysterious identity that runs the whole movie only gets atractivly creepy in the end. What Solaris needed was Science Fiction atmosphere; it should make us believe that we were really in space, something that the 2000's worldwide hated (guilty pleasure to me) Supernova, had to have and to hold.4 out of 10.

reviews.review_title: Not a sci-fi. It's a slow, dull romantic drama
reviews.content: I have both this and Tarkovsky's version of Stanislaw Lem's novel. I found both of them to be somewhat of a trial, although for slightly different reasons. Both are slow, and unless you are easily confused and generally clueless, they don't actually have much of a mystery to them because the secret of the "mystery" is kind of obvious very early on. Where this one fails compared to the 1972 version is that the science fiction is merely a shallow vehicle for a rather stodgy and slow treatment of a doomed romance. There's no actual science in the story at all. It's full of rather obvious logical flaws which distract from the story. There's also little to no science fiction in this version, since it revolves almost entirely about a lonely man's inability to deal with the loss of the difficult and rather fay woman he loved; the science fiction, such as it is, merely provides a pretty backdrop and an excuse for a series of dull flashbacks to the highlights of their relationship. Where the modern remake scores over Tarkovsky's film is that it's about an hour shorter, which means you can get it over and done with that much quicker. On the balance I found the modern take to be more accessible, the only problem being the lack of interest in what you are able to access.To sum up: if you're a science fiction fan rather than a fan of romantic drama, don't bother. If you're a fan of slow, dense, intense romantic dramas with troubled characters who sit staring into space for unreasonable amounts of time, and with stories which have pretensions of being intellectual, then you will probably enjoy this.The seven points I'm giving it are for a good cast who put in decent performances despite the stodgy material, and for fairly decent production values. I feel like I'm being overly generous and it actually doesn't deserve more than 6 points, but what the hell. At least they tried hard.

This 96 minute film seems twice as long as Tarkovsky's 1972 version, which was indeed profound and moving. Save your money and see the Tarkovsky version on video or DVD.  Better yet, wait for it to come to a revival house near you, if you live in a big city.  If you don't, it may be a long wait.

reviews.review_title: Absolutely the best movie to take a nap by
reviews.content: I just bought a big screen tv and rented a few DVDs to use with my progressive scan DVD player.   The first movie was Solaris.  After about 10 minutes I felt like washing my truck or cutting the grass. My wife even went into another room and did some knitting.   I struggled to about half way and fast forwarded to the end.   All the people involved with this movie should have realized that most viewers would hate it.  From now on I will check out the IMDB with a list of DVDs I plan to rent before I spend my money.

reviews.review_title: The Big Star and the Comedienne
reviews.content: Would have had to seen this eventually: Lem, Soderbergh, Clooney. Saw it sooner, though, mainly to discover whether Soderbergh, working apparently from the book, would somehow hit on the shot from Solyaris that's stayed most assuredly with me. It may be the very last shot in Tarkovsky's film. His camera draws back from the memory event on the planet's surface, until the phenomenon looks like a scab and the planet like flesh. It may look a bit, as well, like a sunspot or Jupiter's blemish, but the scab metaphor yields more: a wounded orb, spontaneously healing itself.Soderbergh's planet's blue, constantly spewing and drawing back to itself gaseous tendrils. Key to embracing Solaris is to forget, as much as possible, Solyaris. Clooney's a huge romantic star, with huge star baggage. Cary Grant stricken humorless in a spacesuit. Imagine the only sort of film that could have put Grant in a spacesuit. I think maybe it's the romantic comedy lurking beneath that makes Clooney's George Kelvin's tragic resignation as affecting as it is. Beneath the tragedy in Natascha McElhone's face is a big-mouthed, pouting clown.The thing about Rheya (McElhone) is her situation is actually that of each of us, not excluding George Kelvin. Each of us, in one sense or another, is imagined into being by our parents. Even the worst cases imaginable, battlefield rapists and worse, if there is worse, I'm sure somehow image offspring, imagine life created. But parents raising children, foster parents raising others' children, continue imagining, imaging, lives, just as Kelvin continues imaging Rhea and even Rheya 2 after that early plot turn. Each of us imagines and is imagined by our lovers. Each of us arrives in a world that existed with myriad complications before us, and leaves, too soon, long before it will end.Yet what Kelvin engages in, as his crashingly sane colleague Gordon, played by Viola Davis, implies, is a sort of necrophilia, a sort of onanism. See the really dark coda to A.I. in which David resurrects a sentient yet rigidly terminal manifestation of his "mother" (mistaken by many critics for Spielbergian pap).Maybe this is a film for those who experience or temperament has never led to Lem or Tarkovsky, but it's not a bad way to go.

reviews.review_title: Traffic, grocery lines or dentist anyone...?
reviews.content:
Anyone accustomed to living in a large metropolitan area is familiar with the agonizing delays of traffic and waiting in long grocery lines; Universally, everyone has probably had some experience waiting for the dentist to finish his/her job......These my friends, are far more interesting than waiting for something to happen in the 2002 remake of Solaris. In fact, if you happen to be stuck in traffic on your way to see the movie and you only make it in time to see the closing credits.....you have most definitely seen the best the movie has to offer.The concept is clearly an intriguing one. The exploration of the depths of the human mind, heart and soul....The possibilities that may exist in the after-life and within the unexplored portions of the Universe as we know it...These thematic elements skillfully woven and executed, could have made for a masterpiece. Sadly, what you end up with is akin to having a 1000 piece jigsaw puzzle, only the pieces you are given are from ten different puzzles and never come close to creating a whole picture.
Not even worth watching on cable.

reviews.review_title: Soderburgh's Intimacy Takes Over, Lem/ Tarkovsky's Existential Examination Fades Away
reviews.content: Thanks to Steven Soderbergh's audacious attempt to make an updated version of Andrei Tarkovsky's profound but dated sci-fi classic, the contemporary spectators can easily take a look at the Polish author Stanislaw Lem's planet Solaris, which communicates with the Earthlings via physically presented human figures who appear in a space station. However, Soderbergh's signature intimacy takes over in the film; while the confusing nonlinear sequence towards the end allows the audience many different interpretations, the sensuous last scene may leave the viewers a feeling that the film's argument is romance, rather than the existential examination of Lem and Tarkovsky.Aside from Lem/ Tarkovsky, as one independent piece, the film showcases the excellence of Soderbergh's one and only intimate atmosphere, distilled by great acting from the great casts (especially George Clooney and Jeremy Davies), simple and subtle art directions for the space station and the space landscape, and quiet and pop computer compositions that are reminiscent of Terry Riley and Carl Stone.

reviews.review_title: I Should Have Waited for the Video
reviews.content: Slow beginning...slow middle...slow ending with just one twist.  No suspense...no action...no real romance.  I couldn't wait for the ending to see the only possible outcome for a mediocre sci fi tale.  Do yourself a favor and wait for the video.

reviews.review_title: Do Human Spacefarers argue? No Candu Breeder Few shun
reviews.content: Solaris is a big mindgame that makes the viewer think of the film 2001. A holodeck could account for the anomalies of people appearing. I got "Hide Dad" from my Daughter Julias Artificial Intelligence computer again. I am beginning to miss Tim Hortons, Chapters books, Starbucks, theatres, the malls, libraries, Brock University and church already. It is nice to know that for power sources the Creator of Humans Moonfleets have Candu and Breeder reactors Fusion and Solar power. I was just thinking about primates and "Heres Lucy shes choosy bout who calls her on the phone shes from a very richborn family but displaced because of rivalry for homes." came to mind based on Max Websters The Party song. In the future there will be less house smoking because toke home maxed direct. George Clooneys acting in this film is OK.

Ok, now I knew what I was getting into when I went to see this movie. I knew that it wasn't going to be a 'happy thug with a gun blows stuff up' Sci-Fi movie. I knew there weren't going to be chest bursting aliens, I knew it was going to be a very talky movie, I knew that this movie was supposed to make you think.That being said, I have to say this movie failed on all accounts. George Clooney is expressionless through most of it, except for a wide eyed 'deer-in-headlights' look, Natascha McElhone (Recently of the terrible Feardotcom) is about as animated as a pencil, and they way they have her staring into the camera sometimes is downright creepy, and some of the plot holes you could drive a truck through. Example: at the beginning of the movie, they mention a military team being sent in to assess the damage and rescue the survivors, if necessary. After Cloony steps onboard the station, Zero mention of them. You would think that Gordon or Snow (the stations final survivors) would have said something about them, or if they turned up someplace, maybe a message would have been waiting for Clooney when he came out of hypersleep. But nope, it's as though they never existed.The Movies symbolism and messages are about as subtle as getting hit on the head with a hammer. About halfway through the movie, the audience is practicly led by the hand into the analogy of Solaris = God. The soundtrack is overpowering, going for shrilling notes when you get views of the planet. And the 'psychological' aspects of Clooney losing all perception of being clinical and unbiased is hamhandedly and unrealisticly handled. I'm sorry, I don't care how much I want my dead wife, friend, whoever back, I'm going to be a little skeptical when she suddenly appears in front of me out of nowhere (twice). I was told when I got my movie ticket that people were getting refunds left and right from this movie. I can see why, as only the super pretentious would even try to find something remotely resembling entertaining in this movie.I cannot recommend this movie at all, not as Sci-fi, not as a study in psychology, nothing. Avoid, and if you feel that you HAVE to see it, wait until it's out on video, then find someone who rented or bought it and borrow it off of them.

I expected so much more from Steven Soderbergh and James Cameron.  This movie was slow from the first scene and never picked up speed.  I felt there were several holes in the story and the ending was confusing.  I hope Clooney's next movie is better.

It's a remake of a Russian film, so of course snobbish "purists" out there will tell you it can't possibly "be as good as the original." Whatever. I never saw the original, and I'll go with the prevailing wisdom that it's a good film. Okay. But I can only judge what I see, and I've seen Soderbergh's "Solaris", and it is a thought-provoking and rich film that manages to sell itself in a short running length (just over 90 minutes). I believe the original was much, much longer, but I don't believe the short running length is bad for Soderbergh's version. If anything, it leaves you wanting more.

reviews.review_title: Henry and Kristl traveled to Solaris(2002) with George Clooney
reviews.content: "It's a George Clooney movie, so I bet we get lots of women wanting to see this," Henry grinned, "Clooney smiling; Clooney sleeping; Clooney talking; Clooney looking hurt. Women will get a meltdown watching this movie.""Unless you're a hardcore lesbian, I guess" Henry continued and glanced at Kristl, with her short cut spiky white hair, her firmly built shaped, her roughened black leather jacket, covered with buttons from demised eighties punk bands, worn black jeans, a tank top with some anti-establishment shout written across it, "Or a nun.""All this because of Clooney? Like you like to watch kick-ass babes in scanty clothes waving swords about?," Kristal turned towards Henry, raising an eyebrow."You know, Kristl, a movie is eye candy, why else watch a movie? If it's not eye candy, you better of reading a book, or listening to an audio play. Make up your own images. Have your own Clooney version.""It is not all about eye candy.. I mean it has to have something going for it, like a gripping story and characters that you care for, or at least are interested in. What is the expression: to root for?""Sure, but movies have a huge eye candy factor built in to them. Just like television series like CSI, filled with these eye blinding pretty people. Not one ugly, fat, old or decrepit person around. Who wants to see ugly people if you can watch pretty people. You suffer though, knowing you never be as pretty as they are.""Like the female lead, Natascha McElhone. Eye candy too? With her vaguely British accent, her slender frame and her bedroom eyes. Although aloof and distant at the same time.""I was guessing you would mention her ," Henry smiled."Well, there aren't that many people in the movie. About four and two are women. ""It's why it's a George Clooney movie. You can see it even on the poster: George Clooney's name is above the title, almost in the same large and bold letters as the title. Heck, they could have scrapped the title and called it Clooney."" Would that work? I wouldn't go to a movie just because Clooney is in it. Although, I would also not not go because Clooney is in it.""Not not go?""Stay away.""Right...""But maybe you are right, maybe it's a Clooney movie, for it hasn't got much else going for it. I vaguely recalled having seen the first movie and even read the book and these were things filled with mystery and longing. Like they attempt in this movie, but the actions of the people are so odd," Kristl said."Like killing his wife?," Henry said."That scene is strange. You meet your long dead wife and the first thing you come up with is putting her in escape pod and ejecting her into space. Like who would ever do such a thing? You must be a complete cold hearted bastard to do that. Maybe that is why he is called Kelvin in the movie: as in cold? It is like someone remaking Solaris, but with some action movie in mind. Instead of wondering, you kill, cause it must be malevolent. Ejecting her into space.. is kinda cruel, " Kristl said."Whatever floats your boat, eh," Henry grinned."And the reason why they send Clooney to Solaris is so contrived. We need you to go to the space station at some planet called Solaris, because we lost contact with it and the military team we send, but we know that you have special skills to deal with the situation. So we send you, one guy, off to take charge of a situation that a group of scientists and a group of soldiers could not handle. One wonders what those special skills are." "Well, he is a looker, that is what he is.""And then they ruined the movie at the end. Of course, they couldn't let a mystery be a mystery, they had to put in some kind of closure. So in very blunt scene George is absolved of all he has done towards the fake Rhye and the real.. Do not worry George, all is forgiven.""Why is that bad? I mean..""Because it's totally at odds at the idea. Solaris is a mystery, nobody knows what is going on. Solaris does something to the people, for good or bad. It puts our humanity in the front, it is not something specific to absolve people of their sins.. Soderberg basically took the idea, twisted it about and then made something that resembled the previous movie and the book, but diverted from the essence by trying to take away the mystery, the strangeness. And he finally kills it by having the Solaris created Rhye expressing forgiveness.""I still liked the movie, actually.""Well, it's not a bad movie, really. I think that it is just not a good remake. Had it been called Clooney, a movie inspired by Solaris, it would have been a good movie.""Hmm.""You know, you resemble Clooney," Kristl said."Really?" "Just add some more muscle, add some more weight, shave and cut your hair shorter and properly, then you do.""I shall take that as a compliment.""Whatever makes your boat float.""You were waiting to say that.""I bet I do.""No worries though. I won't hold it against you..""Thanks. Want to take a look at my brand new escape pod?""Offering me a free ride?""A grande tour de l'espace.""Sounds dandy.""It is, but it's no trouble at all. Just have to find the eject button."

reviews.review_title: Stunning visuals and excellent acting make Solaris a very memorable film!
reviews.content: I first saw this film while on a 747 en route to Hawaii. I used to refuse to rent headphones on the principle that the price of the movie would be included in the ticket price. Since I was using my own headphone, I only got 1/2 of the soundtrack, and only when the flight attendant wasn't walking by.It sucked me in...the love story, the tragedy, the mystery, the whole package...absolutely compelling! While I question a lot of the technical issues, I can overlook that while watching this beauty of a film.See it...you will not be sorry!

reviews.review_title: A decent remake for those without the patience for the original
reviews.content:
With remakes, there's always going to be a comparison to the original. I think I would have liked this movie a little more if I had not already seen Tarkovsky's 1972 original. The first question with remakes I suppose should be why? I can see the reason for this film being to bring a really good sci-fi story to the younger generation that probably won't be seeing the 165min Russian original. I heard some comments that this movie was too slow or too boring. Well, in that case, I'm sure they wouldn't have had the patience for the original. I've also heard some sci-fi fans who really appreciate Soderbergh's version...in those cases, I'd consider the idea of doing the remake a success. I'm sure some of them would definitely appreciate the original, but I'm sure a certain percentage wouldn't be willing to sit through the same slow-paced story when the running time is nearly twice as long in the original. Soderbergh did a fine job with this movie and did fairly well at capturing the feeling of the original in a quicker time. If that was his vision, then I think he succeeded. He didn't really add anything new to this story. This movies is pretty much an exact, but compacted, copy of the original Tarkovsky film. The actors were adequate, but I didn't get the emotion, albeit subtle, that I got from the Russian original. I personally feel the gratuitous shots of Clooney's butt were unnecessary. In my opinion, Clooney's lead character may have been better with a lesser known actor. He plays the role fairly well and it's one of his more subtle performances to date, but you can't help but see certain Clooneyisms come out from time to time, especially when he gets upset. Though I feel Soderbergh did well to cast lesser knowns in the supporting roles. All in all, it's a decent remake bringing a solid sci-fi story to modern day fans of the genre, but I'd recommend the original to those who can make it through the epic length Russian version of this story.
**1/2 (Out of 4)

Wait a few years and this will be on Mystery Science Theatre 4000.  This movie tried to be intense, deep and thought provoking but in the end was just boring.  Ideas and characters introduced and left behind.  We meet Gordon who is terrified to leave her cabin but in the next scene she is seated with Kelvin and Snow discussing how to get off the station.  After more intense moments of Kelvin dreaming his wife back into existence, Gordon gets on the escape pod and leaves.  This first rescue team is mentioned and forgotten.  His friend, who asked him to come to the station, makes another appearance but gives nothing to move the story along.  His friend's child, who apparently the friend dreamed into existence, runs around the ship. The deep discussion at the dinner table of the existence of higher intelligence sounds like a bunch of junior high kids.  At the end Kelvin and his wife are being absorbed into the higher intelligence, and Snow get to stare, mouth wide open, up at the ceiling.  So, we have a man sent to space to find out what is going wrong (stealing from 2001 A Space Odyssey?) and then because of his great emotional turmoil, brings his wife back to life and they live happily every after in another plane of existence.  All at taxpayer expense.

SPOILERS!! There was a guy.  A doctor-guy whose wife was dead.  He lived in the future. He was sent back to a planet called Solaris.  He'd been there before, I think.  Strange things were happening there.  The guys who asked him to go back were out-of-focus, enigmatic, those kind of guys.  In orbit around Solaris he found a woman locked in her room, a guy who was seriously wacky, and a kid.  Some or all of these people should not have been there.  It didn't take long for doctor-guy to start going as crazy as everyone else. Or did it? Or was he?  Crazy, I mean.  See, the doctor-guy's wife, dead as a door-nail, came back.  To the space-ship. The one in orbit around Solaris. Our hero sent her away again, in a scene of painful simplicity: he got her into the module, locked her in, and she was gone, sliding out of the frame, a look of awful realisation on her face, staring at her husband, who had turned his back on her.  But she came back again.  See, the planet was doing this - creating apparently real manifestations of dead people.  Why?  To paraphrase Kinsgley Amis, the only sensible answer to this question is, "Yes, that's right, why?"  The people on the spaceship (a downright strange brew of real and created people) sat down to see if they could sort things out.  The scene that followed was weird and slightly laughable, one of two in which the film's grip began to falter (we'll get to the other one in a moment).  They couldn't sort it out.  But they could destroy the creations of Solaris using some contraption.  This had been proved to work on a previous visitor.  Our hero's "wife", fully aware that she was a fake, was quite keen on the idea.  In fact, she begged for it to happen.  It did happen. Then it turned out that one of the people we thought was real was fake too.  Our hero was pretty well gone by this point, as were most of the audience - a Hollywood movie set in the future and there's no lasers or chases or fights or gadgets?  How very strange. Our hero first met the woman who was to become his wife at a party.  They exchanged glances, they flirted ("Don't blow it") they quoted poetry.  On paper it all sounds pretty awful.  On film, as realised by that master of popular cinema, Mister S. Soderbergh, it is magnificent.  The camerawork, the lighting, the editing, the sound, the performances, all combine in the earth-bound flashback scenes to paint a languid, seductive picture of two people falling in love.  The only things I can compare these scenes to are, perhaps not that surprisingly, the two earlier Clooney/Soderbergh classics, "Out of Sight" and "Ocean's Eleven".  All three films contain sterling work by Clooney, oozing charm and creating a fizzing chemistry with his leading ladies. Meanwhile, back in the future, back in space, our hero has to make a decision.  Should he stay or should he go? Back in his apartment on earth he is chopping vegetables.  He cuts his finger.  The cut disappears.  His wife is there.  They embrace.  And this is the other moment in which the film falters for a second, almost loses it, and us.  The doctor-guy stands there, in a faintly ridiculous pose, his arms slightly outstretched, his face expressing a weary surprise.  It looks odd and, again, slightly laughable.  The film recovers, just about, and fades to black, and to the titles. The end.  Discuss.

reviews.review_title: Love the Scenery and Atmo of this Tape
reviews.content: Calm and fascinating sci fi with an amazing George Clooney!

reviews.review_title: Like staring off into space for two hours
reviews.content: One of the biggest problems with Solaris is that it is being marketed incorrectly.  Perhaps this is because it doesn't even know what it is. It is NOT a romance.  I'm not sure to call it a sci-fi or not.Perhaps my preconceptions have simply become too shaped by Hollywood. Initially the movie reminded me of Event Horizon (another mismarketed film) or Alien.  Consequently, throughout most of the movie, I kept on expecting tentacles or claws to pop out of Rheya's head.  Mind you, I'm not saying that I WANTED this to happen.Herein lies one big problem.  There are plenty of thriller moments throughout Solaris.  It builds expectations and tension in the audience and then proceeds to deliver NOTHING.  Imagine a typical slasher movie in which the protagonist slowly approaches the door at the end of the hall, reaches forward, opens the door...and then the scene fades and cuts to the same protagonist eating Cheerios in the kitchen a week later. Solaris is NOT a slasher or thriller but many times it pretends to be.About 60 percent of this movie is people staring blankly into nothingness. Another 30 percent consists of the trippy swirls of Solaris.  This leaves about 15 minutes for something to actually happen.You'll hate this movie if you like closure and a plot that clicks.  I call this the "Sixth Sense" syndrome.  Ever since the S.S., audiences have become accustomed to tolerating long-winded movies that seem to wander aimlessly with the promise that the ending will deliver a magical twist that pulls everything together perfectly.  This is definitely NOT the case with Solaris.  I understand that uncertainty is one of the primary points of this movie, but I think it was a poor choice to use the movie itself as a means to demonstrate this.Even as a pure sci-fi movie, Solaris is nothing special.  There isn't a single idea or concept that hasn't already been explored more eloquently by countless other sci-fi movies.  And there's no need to present these ideas in such an unconsumable-to-the-masses form as Solaris.  A typical Star Trek episode has better sci-fi than this; plus you save 45 minutes.Throw in awful film editing and immensely annoying characters who always mumble their lines, and you end up with a frustrating movie that's generally pretentious and not very interesting.I would recommend this movie only if:A) You love movies that are so abstract and vague that you basically need to write half the movie in your head to fill in all the blanks.  Perhaps this may be considered "clever" movie-making for the thinking viewer, but I think it just boils down to bad storytelling.B) You love George Clooney, and you love his butt.  (No and No, for me)All in all, I give Solaris an imdb 4/10.  Oh and another thing. (SPOILER??):  This movie ends by flashing its title, SOLARIS, in big, bold letters across the screen.  I hate it when movies do this.  As if we might have forgotten which movie we were watching?

reviews.review_title: "I see dead people from outer space... Are they real?"
reviews.content: This film had me really upset.I generally like Soderbergh's movies, especially his daring ones. So I was expecting something outstanding.He sadly missed in this movie every single opportunity to give the potentially moving story a chance to touch the viewer. To be moved by this, one has to be so sensitive that he/she cries when viewing "Dallas".Yeah, the spaceships look good. Yeah, the cinematoraphy is neat. Yeah, the woman has touching eyes (the "Emily Watson effect"). Yeah, Clooney has a nice butt. So what? This is just another of this modern and uninteresting movies which, instead of using cinematic narratives, just **illustrates**, "nicely" and "cleverly", a story like if we already knew it before... and expects from the viewer to be immersed in the story just because it's a good story. Bad news, Steven, a director's work is not only showing what he can do, using creative editing and cool cinematography... He actually has a role to play in the way the viewer relates to the story and the characters! Have you forgotten this since "Sex, lies and videos"?We know nothing about the characters, and we are asked just to deal with what happens, and the way they behave. I don't mind to feel far from the characters if a philosophical purpose is cleverly exposed or evocated, or if the audiovisual narratives incline to meditation, like in 2001. Here it's almost impossible, as the whole movie is drawned deep into a stubborn musical score that makes each scene "feel" exactly like the one before. This music seems to tell you: "nothing is happening, don't worry, you shall not be moved, or scared, or even interested, just be patient and the film will eventually come to an end"... Zzzzzzz** - the only meditation allowed is to think of the shopping list... result: people who already don't like that much slow-paced movies will HATE them after seeing Solaris. Well done, indeed, Steve, well done!There is no real emotional drive in Solaris, though the director seems to think differently. Good for him. To feel concerned by a character's emotions, one must get close to him/her. The flashbacks in Solaris are an inadequate way to fill the gaps of the early narrative, and they give only flat explanations, not meaningful inner motives. A touching love story is not made out of mere facts, neither is a good SF story.The whole thing looks pretentious and utterly empty, far too clean, intellectual and desincarnate, and the many nods to 2001 only make me think that Kubrick seems to have really traumatized directors, even talented ones like De Palma or Soderbergh, who have both been completely unable to come up with a "space opera" of their own without basically mimicking Kubrick's work, and fall into every obvious trap that lead to make boring SF movies "in the manner of 2001".When will a talented, artistic director have the guts to make a really creative, independant and meaningful new movie about the meeting of man with a cosmic intelligence, without desperatly trying to compete with 2001? Is there such a lack of imagination and creativity in the movie industry?Solaris was, for me, as interesting as a mix bewteen the worse aspects of "Star Trek", "Sixth sense" and "A.I.". How does it sound? Not very good. "I see dead people from outer space... Are they real?"The good thing about this movie is that it made me want to look at Tarkowski's original movie, hoping that the potentially excellent story was not, like in Soderbergh's movie, buried under the will to show off...

One of the most boring movies I've ever tried to watch. I initially put it on mid-afternoon one day and found myself asleep within 17 minutes. In fact, it was so tedious and exhausting that I slept for the next 12 hours straight and still I awoke feeling groggy and disoriented. I tried watching it again the next day and was unable to pay attention to the story or the characters. That's the key problem of this film, the entire cast could suddenly die and it still wouldn't matter. It's just a horribly boring film with boring, undeveloped characters and nothing going on. I made it about 40 minutes through and then had to turn it off.

reviews.review_title: "I hope you don't suppose those are REAL tears???"
reviews.content:
Tweedledee and Tweedledum were trying to persuade poor little Alice that the Red King was dreaming her and if he awoke, poof! she'd be gone.  She protested that she was indeed real, and began to cry.  "You won't make yourself any realer by crying," one Tweedle remarked.  "If I weren't real," replied Alice, "I wouldn't be able to cry."  From the other Tweedle came the above punch-line.  Not directly related to "Solaris," of course, but that basically is the movie's theme: How can we be sure we're real?  And does it matter?And will anyone care?  Up until about the mid-Seventies there was a market of sorts for quiet, contemplative character-driven stories, often with some quirky humor and without the traditional "happy ending." Some of these stories even took place in outer space, e.g. "Silent Running."  Then "Star Wars" came along and blew all that out of the water.  This remake of "Solaris" harks back somewhat to those times.  Most viewers will probably be reminded of Kubrick's "2001," which under it's then-state-of-the-art SFX and metaphysical baggage ultimately was a traditional tale of Battling a Menace. (Be honest, "2001" fans: once th e sinister supercomputer had been disabled,  did the rest of the movie make ANY sense except as a series of pretty cool visuals, especially if you were smoking something at the time?) With "Solaris" some viewers may keep expecting a Menace to turn up. Well, I feel it's my duty to warn those undecided on seeing it: if that's what you crave, seek elsewhere.  Mr. Soderbergh has other fish to fry.  This comes as close as has any outer-space movie I've seen to being a "chick-flick." Well hell, look who's starring in it.As I'd expected, Mr. Clooney does a great job here.  In too many film roles he's fallen back on the Doug Ross (from "ER") charm and twinkling eyes and even the semi-hesitant line readings.  Mr. Soderbergh seems able to reach inside and extract a kind of unguarded element from him, an edginess that I spotted way the hell back when he played Rose-anne Barr's boss on her TV show.  Here as the disaffected psychiatrist paralyzed with guilt over his wife's suicide he lets us get a peek at the bleakness and fear behind his bland facade.  Follow his reactions as he explores the (possibly abandoned) space station, there's not a false note.  Later he shows us an intelligent character turning his back on his intelligence, rationally choosing the irrational.  He makes it all seem natural, even inevitable.  Ms McElhone (who showed great promise in "Ronin" and soldiered bravely in "Feardotcom") does what she can with basically two roles to play, one as a memory and one as the manifestation of a memory.  She has the most enormous eyes I've seen in a while and certainly made me wish she'd had more screen time as a "real person" in "real time."  The other cast members have very little to do but do it well, although the guy playing Snow started so many sentences with "Yeah..."  he reminded me of the unctuous suspenders-wearing boss in "Office Space."I was really rooting for myself to get emotionally involved with the story here, but I guess I should have remembered that Soderbergh (like Godard) seems to go out of his way NOT to let his audiences get hooked.  He holds us at arms' length.  He spends just enough money to convince us this really is a space station (the original fell woefully short in that regard) even showing it spinning to explain that it generates it's own gravity, so the characters aren't floating inside.  The planet itself is gorgeous, pink and blue and pulsating, almost like an enormous jellyfish.  He throws in hints of plot like splotches of dried blood everywhere.  But bottom line, so far as I could tell, he wants us to think about his ideas.  Does he succeed?
SPOILERS ***  SPOILERS ****  SPOILERS ****   SPOILERS ***  SPOILERS ***The Russian original from 1972 basically drowned us in verbiage but to it's credit, made a much more compelling case for the copy wife's human-ness. Thus the shrink's dilemma seemed more wrenching: go back to his sterile "real life" on Earth or stay on the ship for a chance at happiness with at least a facsimile of his wife.  When the copy wife also killed herself and he did go back home, there was a real sense of loss, enhanced by the famous closing shot with the camera pulling back from the shrink's house until it was obscured in clouds, to emphasize the isolation of not just him but humanity.  Soderbergh keeps the remake a lot more streamlined.  To an extent that's a big improvement, but it also imposes a kind of by-the-numbers quality on the proceedings.  Almost immediately after the copy wife's appearance--or rather her second appearance, because Soderbergh retains the original's sequence of the shrink blasting her off into space, an example of being overly faithful in my view---she's proclaiming her need and desire to be killed; we're not given the chance to "take her side," in fact the black female scientist (a Soderbergh touch) asks Clooney "Whose side are you on?" Well if all she is is some alien freakshow, why should we care that much? Remember way the hell back on the first "Star Trek" series when there was a horrible salt-sucking monster that also could look like somebody's wife? Why's it even an issue?  It makes the shrink look petulant or even foolish for arguing with the black chick.  Soderbergh also inserts a scene that may or may not be a dream, with Clooney talking to a suicide scientist who chides him as "a puppet dreaming he's real," which merely reminded me of a much better existentialist sci-fi flick called "Bladerunner," from which "Solaris" also borrows for it's futuristic crowd scenes.  Then at the end of "Solaris" Soderbergh's train of ideas really seems to get derailed.  The shrink is back on Earth---OR IS HE?----and just as the old guy in "2001" knocked over a wine glass, here Clooney cuts himself while chopping a cucumber (as he had done earlier) but notices this time there's no wound,which prompts him to remember that maybe he never got back home after all, next thing we know, voila, there's his wife--a ghost? a clone?  an alien? ---reassuring him that all is well, all is "forgiven"---so what the hell, was the planet Solaris supposed to be God or something?   So we get our "happy ending" after all.   What supposedly is it with Americans, if we don't get a happy ending we're going to burn down the cinema or something? I found this the biggest cinematic disappointment in endings since "What Dreams May Come," which should have ended when Robin Williams went back inside the little hell-cottage and slammed the door shut.  So ultimately what's Mr. Soderbergh telling us?  "Never mind your life, never mind trying to deal with stuff or behave in a way that would do somebody some good, don't even give blood or anything, just inhabit your own morose little universe and if you're lucky, maybe some day you'll get to inhabit some other little universe, only happy not morose."   But in fairness to Mr. Soderbergh, I'm exhibiting some personal bias here; whenever I hear about the desire for an "afterlife" of some kind, I'm reminded of the line "There are people who crave eternity who don't know what to do with themselves on a Sunday afternoon...."I didn't even recognize Elpidia Carillo in a brief dinner-party scene. Damn, she was such a fox back in "Predator" ....

Solaris is the second movie based on Stanislaw Lem's sci-fi novel, the first one being the 1972 Soviet film (which I haven't seen, so can't give any comparison insight). It follows the trip of a psychologist named Chris Kelvin to a space station in orbit around the planet Solaris. The visuals of the planet, station, and equipment is great. The atmosphere that the special effects create feels perfect for the movie, invoking a sense of mystery and uncertainty. When Kelvin arrives, he finds that there are only two surviving members and proceeds to investigate. Ironically, he turns out to be the one that is effected the most by the planet. In short, the film revolves around the subject of memory, dreams, and emotion.The music is excellent. The dialog could have been better, but the acting was solid. George Clooney does a respectable job as Kelvin, although not outstanding. Since there are only four main characters, there is a special focus on each member of the team. The majority is centered around Kelvin and the memory of his wife, which is an interesting relationship that covers a wide range of emotions. The plot gets a little jumbled (mostly due to the constant switch between present and memory) and has several unexplained parts. Even so, it is easy to get immersed into and gives a satisfying conclusion.Solaris is a must-see for sci-fi fans or broad thinkers. It is visually beautiful and has intriguing content. Despite a few technical problems, the plot will absorb you for the whole time.

reviews.review_title: "Love in Outer Space"?, Yes, but Actually, Not Bad!
reviews.content: Don't know why so many low ratings for this film. I have read Solaris, really this film is a riff on Solaris, and not a true adaptation of the book. It takes one aspect of Solaris and goes with it for the whole film, pretty much ignoring the planet altogether. Which is what the book Solaris is really about. But as a stand alone film, it is great. I was moved, there are some very emotional scenes and there are some uncanny creepy scenes. The acting is great, the sound, sets, colours, all great. A good bit of cinema, but not a great Solaris adaptation.I think it is a good film, but I also agree with Stanislaw Lem (author of Solaris) who called this film "love in outer space", honestly yes, it is, and it's good!

I'm sorry, but in my opinion, this Soderbergh film was utter tripe. Tarkovsky's original was masterful, haunting, and left me feeling stunned. And how anyone can say the music score in the Soderbergh version was better than the (albeit altered somewhat) Bach chorale prelude, in the Tarkovsky film, just baffles me. The haunting melancholy of the F minor piece perfectly matched the feeling of the story. People also complain about the extended car journey through the city. But that was making a point. When it cut, suddenly, to the scene of the beautiful, tranquil countryside , it was a tremendous contrast to the noisy, ugly, polluted cityscape. That, I feel, was the point the director was making, and with such force. To me, Soderbergh's version is a dumbed down, Hollywood love story, with a pretty boy lead, and little substance. If you can't handle the slow pacing of the original, then I guess the subject matter of Solaris is really not for you, anyway. In which case, why not stick to action blockbusters and the like ? I am not meaning to insult anyone, I'm just saying that weighty themes such as those dealt with in Solaris are unsuited to the Hollywood treatment and cannot be done justice by substituting gloss, glamour and special effects for great cinematography and direction. Reading this back to myself...I guess I sound like a bit of an elitist snob. Well...I'm sorry if it appears that way, but there is just something that separates great films, like Tarkovsky's Solaris, (think also: "The Third Man" and Pasolini's "The Gospel According To St Matthew") from the average, run of the mill stuff. And whatever that is, it makes them truly great, and puts them in a class of their own. Soderbergh's movie cannot hold a candle to the 1972 version.

reviews.review_title: Not as bad as some of the reviews suggest
reviews.content: This will never become one of my favourite films, but it is certainly not as bad as some of the reviews on here suggest.Yes, it has quite a slow pace, but to say that it had to be watched in three parts (as one reviewer said) because it was so slow (ie boring) to me screams that the reviewer had the brain/concentration  of a gnat.The plot is not hard to follow (as another indicates) if you are of average intelligence, so I can only assume that these people were expecting the shoot - em -up space antics of Aliens.A cerebral film, well photographed and with a good performance from all the centrals. Enigmatic yes, but the worst film ever made (see one of the comments posted)...Pleeez...!!!

Technical performances are well done u can connect emotionally with the scenes wich are painting like photography. Technology was presynchronously accurate with the forecoming gadgets, u can even see a person using a táctil phone, and mechanical buttons are a future comeback, believe that!. At the end what u have are painting like scenes, well sequenced in a non linear structure but easy to thread with a rather interesting philosophical point of view. As with any good philosophy in the end there are just questions, interesting or boring questions that's ur choice. At the same time there is not worse question than that one that was not made so enjoy this masterpiece at ur earliest convenience.

reviews.review_title: Slow but it gets better if you keep watching.
reviews.content: This movie has an annoying, sluggish, artsy pace reminiscent of Kubrick's space turd called 2001: A Space Oddissey. Fortunately, it's slightly better. Instead of just raising questions what the hell the plot is all about, the movie is more about universal questions. The plot is more clear but there's still enough to make you guess. Is Solaris some sort of heaven were souls come back from? Is it a giant alien able to create hallucinations and read minds? What is death and what happens afterwards? Is there a god?The movie looks good and has overall fine acting. What I didn't like however was the offbeat, overly weird acting by the two male supporting actors. They were trying too hard to be different and were whispering the entire movie. It had this overly artsy feel to it like they desperately wanted to have as much weirdness in the film as possible. I would say it is better to have more identifiable characters in a film, otherwise you estrange your audience. I guess Soderbergh is to blaim, a director willing to try anything can be faulty. However, I did like the female doctor and Clooney and the other actress were fine (sorry, names....). I'm not sure about the clinical style the movie has because it makes you care less about the characters and identify less with them, while their emotions have an enormous influence on their actions and inactions in this story.So, there's plenty of flaws to this film. Still, I liked part of it. I love SciFi in general and this is true SciFi, I also liked the visuals, and the ideas behind the story. The movie is worth discussing afterwards, especially the end will have you wondering...what happened? I thought Clooney was not Clooney anymore but a "clone" created by Solaris. That would explain him feeling unfamiliar with earth when he came back. As for a more universal theme the film raises questions like is there an afterlife and what does it look like? Like one of the characters says there's no answers, only choices.In the making of, James Cameron stated you won't see a movie like this in the 70s, 80s, 90s or in the near future. He looked kind of angry too, probably feeling people underrated this film. Tho I would agree Solaris has a unique quality I still think it was a bit of an arrogant statement of Cameron, as much as I admire his work. I think, if you look well enough, you'll find plenty of thoughtprovoking, intelligent, offbeat and non-action scifi out there, like Silent Running, Logan's Run (70s), Brazil (80s) and Dark City (90s). And the original Solaris was a 70s film as well, I haven't seen it so I can't tell if it's that different.Overall, still an interesting one to watch. 7 out of 10.

I've never really enjoyed any previous work from the director- _Erin Brockovich_ was fluff and _Traffic_ was just horrible- but _Solaris_ is really quite good.The film itself is beautiful.  I and others have accused Soderbergh of a bad Kubrick imitator in the past, but he seems to have fixed that here.  The style still very much Kubrick, but Soderbergh has taken it and made it his own.  The film reminds one of both _2001_ and _The Shining_, but comes from a different place emotionally and is thus very satisfying.  The lack of audio-visual sychronization, signifying the fragile nature of human memory, is very slick and works well here.The script can only be described as high-minded. Admittedly, the trailers are a bit deceiving, leading one to think that this will be a love story. It IS, but probably not in the way that you're thinking.  For most, this will be a big disappointment.  For those such as myself, it will be a welcome reprieve from current popular films that severely underestimate the audience.Clooney is as good as I have ever seen him- this is probably the most intellectual and challenging film he's ever done.  McElhone (most recently in the underrated _FearDotCom_) shows that when she's given good material, she can really shine.A minor complaint which is becoming more and more common for me these days: can we please have the credits at the front of the movie again?  It's not a time issue, obviously- in this film, near the beginning, I saw numerous opportunities where they could have at least done a "Twentieth Century Fox presents" schtick.  Just tell us the title of the freaking movie already. You can take five seconds and do that, can't you?Overall, this is a very, very good film.  Just be warned that thought and reflection are required.

reviews.review_title: Odds are you'll hate this movie unless....
reviews.content: Okay first off I consider myself a reasonably intelligent guy. I love movies with lots of dialouge and would take quality acting over explosions and special effects any day. This movie does have some quality acting in it too and I thought to myself before I saw this that the movie couldn't go wrong with someone like Soderbergh at the helm. I was wrong.First let me tell you what I like about this movie. I thought the soundtrack was exceptional. I also thought Clooney did a great job. That's it.You see, I don't require my movies to have all the answers but I do like my movies to make you at least curious as to what the answers are. This movie has no answers, ends unresolved, and honestly, I didn't give a crap what the answers were. To say this movie is slow would be the understatement of the year and I think the people on Imdb saying how extrordinary this movie is are simply trying to show how "smart" and "sophisticated" they are by going against the majority of movie goers. I usually think the public doesn't know anything about movies (Godzilla, Wild Wild West, etc.) but this time I am going to have to agree. I have never seen so many people leave a movie FIFTEEN minutes into it! I made myself sit through it hoping that something would happen but nothing ever did.So, in my humble opinion you might want to skip this flick. Unless you are one of those people who like arguing with your everyone and "showing" everyone how evolved you are and how dumb everyone else is...........sit this one out

I've tried to watch this film all the way through 3 time. Fell asleep every time. Finally, on the 4th try I made it...unfortunately. This movie is why I intensely dislike outer space sci-fi. Too many people trying to make a 'meaningful' movie in space. A little too Camus for me. No...a LOT too Camus for me. I didn't care about these people one way or the other. I didn't care about Clooney's fantasy, reality, or anything in-between. I didn't get it. I'm not embarassed that I didn't get it. I'm GLAD I didn't get it. This movie is the epitomy of a director masturbating on film...and not very well. This is MORE than ten lines. They've got to change this rule. Some movies, like this one can be summed up in ONE line. It stinks.

I like my sci-fi to be less horror, and more psychological. Solaris fits the bill. The movie starts like a Twilight Zone episode. We see Chris Kelvin, played by George Clooney, looking forlorn while hearing the voice of his wife. Shortly thereafter, he is summoned to take on the task of investigating anomalies on an earth spaceship that has gone somewhat rogue while orbiting Solaris. He finds himself in a bind because he is confronted with a reality that doesn't fit the reality he has come from. Is he "here"? What is "here" from "there"? His objective reality is shattered by subjective reality, which is as much known as unknown. He is tortured by this psychological enigma. Viola Davis, Jeremy Davies and Natash McElhone deliver fine performances. If you're looking for blood and gore and aliens galore...look elsewhere. This is a thought provoking piece.

Although this film took a while to sink in, I finally came to the conclusion that it is probably the best film I've seen in the last five years or so. It encompasses the melancholy, the beauty and the metaphysical intelligence I am obsessed with and it got me thinking about the themes of love and death more than any other film could ever manage. Although I think that Clooney was miscast on this film (he's a bit too bourgeois to play in a mind-disturbing film like this) I think he did a very good job. Natasha McElhone was beautiful to look at and I was surprised to see Ulrich Tukur in it (who is well known here in Germany but probably not famous enough to be cast for a Soderbergh film, or so I thought). Anyway, when I saw this movie in a French cinema, looking at the poster, I expected one of these typical sci-fi movies where people in space are confronted with some kind of monster and try to fight it. To my surprise, this was not the case. Chris Kelvin (George Clooney) works as a psychiatrist. He recently lost his wife (she committed suicide) and Soderbergh within the first scenes establishes the fact that Clooney is devastated and rather disillusioned. He is still working as a psychiatrist, but he looks as if he was just faking interest in his clients' problems. Then, one night, two members of a space agency called DBA knock at his door and show him some video footage of his friend and astronaut Gibarian (Ulrich Tukur), who is on the planet Solaris. Gibarian asks Kelvin for help, but he doesn't say what is happening because he is frightened and because the walls have ears (or so he claims). Kelvin, who has nothing too lose, since his wife is dead, agrees to fly to Solaris and identify the problem. When he reaches Solaris he finds Gibarian dead (suicide) and two members of the crew dazed and confused. One is acting all weird (Jeremy Davies) the other female member locked herself in and refuses to come out. When Kelvin asks the Davies character what is going on, the Davies character tells him that he'll find out soon. At night, Kelvin goes to sleep and dreams about his wife (who, as I already mentioned, committed suicide). When he wakes from his dream, he finds that his dream has become reality. His dead wife is lying next to him, in the flesh. And this is what Solaris is all about: It resuscitates the dead friends and relatives of the crew aboard the ship. Chris Kelvin tries to deal with it by sending his wife away. But the next night, he again dreams of his former wife, the same thing happens. Because of his dream his wife materializes again, and this time Kelvin decides to stay with her. Now on Solaris, he knows that he can keep his wife who he still loves dearly, but he also knows that she is just a copy, a counterfeit model of his real wife who is dead and buried. This plot is, I think, a stroke of genius (conceived by Stanislaw Lem and his novel Solaris). On a metaphysical level it tells us that we sometimes are so haunted by things that happened in the past, that these things become more than just memories: At times, they are so real, that they define us to such an extent that they become part of our reality. If you have lost somebody, because they died in a car accident or committed suicide, you have not entirely lost them, because at times, you will still catch yourself thinking about them. So whenever we meet somebody and take a liking to them, we will also never lose them, because they will always be there even when they are dead. So, Mr. Soderbergh, congratulations again and thanks for this excellent flick. It made me read the novel and I also watched the first version of this film by Andreij Trakovski. I liked the novel, I was bored by the Russian version of this movie, but I enjoyed this film and it had a great impact on me and my writing (Oh, I forgot to say, I am a writer).

This was the most boring movie I have seen all year. The soundtrack was brutal! It was reminiscent of an early 80's attempt at suspense. It barely kept me awake, in fact I had to watch it in 3 sittings just to slog my way through it. God, what a snoozefest. And to top it all off, all of the characters were utterly flat and two dimensional. The deliberately weird and delusional crewmember, the one straight-headed clear-thinking person, and "I still love my dead wife" caricature. And then the most obvious ending imaginable. As soon as I saw his wife heal after she drank the liquid oxygen, I said to myself "I bet that is why they showed him cutting his finger". Sure enough, he cuts it at the end and it heals. Oooh, he is some sort of alien but doesn't know it, just like the REAL version of Blade Runner. HOW BORING! How UNORIGINAL! And la-dee-da, they get their "second chance" at happiness..... barf. How HOLLYWOOD! How could Soderbergh stray so far from "Traffic"? He was the only reason I bothered to watch this movie!! What a disappointment, honestly just about the most boring movie I have ever seen. What a piece of tripe, I couldn't wait for it to end just to see if it ever picked up. It didn't. You are better off watching reruns of The Facts of Life.

reviews.review_title: At least I only paid to rent the DVD
reviews.content: This movie was one of the worst I have ever seen. I think the other people who rated it a 9 or 10 must have been watching something else. reviews.content: Except for some footage of spaceships and the planet itself the movie is rubbish. The basic theme is phenomenal but Soderbergh succeded to crap it out for some reason. Pity.

reviews.review_title: Boring and bad acting don't mix
reviews.content: Clooney was dull all throughout this movie.  His quiet tortured role was mesmerizing in a hypnotic kind of way.  I found the spaceship buttons, all bright and shiny, to be very annoying.  The visuals were good though throughout and even the first 45 minutes of the story were interesting.  The last half started to drag.  This is like Event Horizon meets Blade Runner in the most boring atmosphere imaginable.  4/10, because I like romantic endings.

Solaris represents a place where mistakes are forgiven and mystical reincarnation may allow new choices to be made. But the film itself is tedious, slow moving, and lacking any vitality. I assume it's a think piece, and it does have some impact, but somehow doesn't quite work.The beginning of the film is poorly conceived. A psychiatrist is asked to board a space station where a rescue team has disappeared. He alone is supposed to find out what's going on. He travels there alone--no pilot, no crew. It's way beyond belief here.And then a strange assemblage of characters greet him, some of whom are "visitors" or creations of the nearby planet, Solaris. We relive his sad love relationship, which turns the film into a sci-fi romance story (an unusual one to say the least). This is a very difficult film to watch, and even though some questions are answered, by the end you wonder whether it was worth all the time and effort to make this movie. In all fairness, I think I need to watch this again before rendering my own final judgment.

A criticism of the film `Solaris' (2002) By Christopher Manning 8-3-03Ahh Science Fiction, that most marvelous of film genre. It can be used as a vehicle to the wonderful or the terrifying. It can take you to distant uncharted planets or a nightmarish future. On the surface `Solaris' appears to be about the former. Chris Kelvin is solicited by his friend to journey to the space station that is studying the titular planet. His visit will be the last attempt to solve the rather ambiguous problems plaguing the station. We soon discover that this film is much more than a space journey filled your typical sci-fi raz-taz. It's no less a journey to the very nature of how we as humans relate and perceive one another. When one considers the apparent hero of the films profession is that of a psychiatrist as apposed to say a cop or soldier. This alone should tell the audience that this film is certainly not run of the mill. `Solaris' is most certainly an exercise in minimalism. A style that perfectly suits the films subject matter. The audience is not spoon-fed a bunch of pretentious psychobabble. The story is told with raw images and raw emotions. It is both a departure from the majority of science fiction cinema and a return to what the genre is capable of.The films mages are eloquently photographed using a combination of static and handheld camera. A beautiful color palette is used to communicate to the audience where they are in the time line. Cool greys and blacks for the Solaris station. Warm earth tones for the terrestrial  flashbacks. The emotions are that of a man who has lost his wife to suicide. He is then confronted with her apparent resurrection. This being the afore mentioned problem that was troubling the resident scientists of the station. It seems that every crewmember has their own `visitor'. The origin and purpose of which is unknown. Chris has to deal with facing a woman who looks and (almost) acts exactly like his deceased wife. On the surface it would appear he is being dealt a second chance. But he and his facsimile wife soon discover that this chance is fleeting when her true nature comes to the surface. The performances are superb all around. Mr. Clooney as Chris is called upon to display a wide range of emotions. He dose so with a subtle elegance that matches the rest of the films mood. All of  the supporting roles are played nicely as well. Jeremy Davies disjointed and appropriately odd ball character plays as a good harbinger to things to come. Ultimately the overall experience of `Solaris' is a satisfying one. I havnt any real complaints about the film. It in every way represents what I love about not only a good sci-fi movie, but good movies in general. I feel the film demands a patient audience, but the reward is worth the wait.

reviews.review_title: a modern 2001: a boring space oddessy.
reviews.content: Unlike most sci fi fans, I was incredibly bored out of my mind with 2001. I found it long and boring. Much like this film. George Clooney plays another bland character that has ruined his life or had it ruined by external forces. The plot is pretty much given away in the trailers and the ending is almost never in doubt. Unlike 2001, however, this movie hasn't been considered a marvel and advancement in sci fi picture making. Quite the opposite, people really hated this film and found it very derivative. While I can see why people would say that, it really isn't that bad. Disconnected from all they hype and reviews, this movie is boring yes, but mildly interesting. It is hysterical to me, that the documentary about the film on the DVD is more action packed than movie itself.   Still, if you can divorce yourself from any hopes of excitement, this movie will be fairly entertaining.

I was really looking forward to seeing "Solaris." The moment I saw the trailer and read a few reviews I was all for it. That kind of surreal movies with flashbacks, dreams, flash-forwards really get me and I have to say I was not disappointed with this one.This movie is about a planet (Solaris) that providers its visitors with people they have lost and miss. These beings are "created" by the planet based only on the memories of its visitors-no more no less; and once evoked from the planet these creatures seem to carry on with their free will. George Clooney is quite convincing in his role as one of those visitors. 
"Solaris" elaborates over phenomenon such as the nature of life, the importance of memory, and most of all the power of guilt; or maybe: the power of regret. I like this tag line: How far would you go for a second chance? 7.5 stars out of 10.

reviews.review_title: George can act i just know he can
reviews.content: This movie would have been tolerable if it was to have a convincing main character. George is a fairly good actor but in this film you cannot take his character seriously. The overall sound of the movie contained some of the best atmosphere I have ever heard, and the special effects could not be flawed.But in a nutshell this is a half an hour film that had been stretched out thin to fill 2 hours, sorry Steven better luck next time.

reviews.review_title: Oh, my god! This is terrible/depressing/confusing...
reviews.content: I must have done a lot of horrible things in my previous life to deserve this horrible movie. People say the silent scenes in the movie were dreadful, but compared to the boring conversations, it's really nothing. Let me just tell you this: after seeing solaris, I really wanted to kill myself.

As the first person reviewing this movie suggested, this was remarkably similar to being a remake of 2001 Space Odyssey. When I first saw 2001 I thought it was the strangest movie I had ever seen .... until now. Solaris was extremely slow to start ... in fact slow all the way through. Most of the audience verbally complained during the movie and all had the same feelings as they left the movie when it finally put us out of our misery by ending ... "That was the stupidest movie I ever saw!". I understood the story line but the constant flashbacks and the continuous shots of Solaris just about put me to sleep. Clooney is one of my favorite actors .... but he is human and he showed it by picking a dud for a movie. Come on George ... you CAN do much better than that. Your acting was fine ... as usual ... but the script should have warned you how bad this was when you first read it. I did manage to find something good in this movie ... my wife had to work and I didn't have to waste $6.50 on her also seeing this.

That's right, it's absolutely remarkable that 8% of all viewers have given this movie 1/10 (at the time I wrote this). Nearly 1 in 10 people think this movie is as bad as movies get. That's insane. People are stupid.

reviews.review_title: Don't waste your time ... rent the original
reviews.content: I had high hopes for this movie. I had hoped to find a good version of Stanislaw Lem's novel. I had hoped to see a good version of the original movie, with up-to-date special effects. And, strangely enough, I had even hoped to be able to see a performance by George Clooney that could be called "good" (actually, I really just hoped for "watchable").My hopes were dashed on all counts. I guess Soderbergh figures he's a bigger name than Lem or Tarkovsky, and so all the groundwork they laid is inconsequential. This was a very bad film. We're talking "Highlander 2" bad here. Here's another film that makes that most unforgivable of errors in science fiction, as it made it all pretty damn boring. Jeremy Davies and Viola Davis are the only ones who don't seem to have phoned in their performances, though with this stodgy script, there isn't all that much difference in anyone's acting.Rent the original 1972 movie. That's one of the best science fiction movies of all time, right up there with 2001. Get past the subtitles and watch a vastly superior and much more intelligent science fiction opus than anything George Clooney could have possibly acted in.

I dreaded seeing this movie.  Even though I find Steven Soderbergh one of the most interesting contemporary Hollywood directors, I don't find him particularly gifted or with an affinity for psychologically probing movies, at least since his 1989 movie "Sex, Lies and Videotape."  Indeed as he's settled into his career as a director Soderbergh has become primarily a competent stylist, and an uneven one at that.  His most celebrated movie, Traffic, is an almost shot-for-shot copy of a BBC television miniseries, and most of the changes Soderbergh introduces to Americanize the movie are not for the better.Thus the thought of this director taking the strange beauty of Andrei Tarkovsky's 1972 Russian science fiction art film and building a George Clooney vehicle around it only brought forth a sense of foreboding, that these Americans were surely biting off more than they could chew and would embarrass themselves -- and Hollywood by extension -- with a ridiculous effort.I'm surprised to report that in visiting Solaris Soderbergh has made his best movie, and arguably the best English-language science fiction movie since 2001: A Space Odyssey.In fact the only negative comment that leaps to mind minutes after leaving the theater is that Soderbergh's Solaris is perhaps a little too similar to Kubrick's masterpiece, and thus lacks the sense of awe, surprise and discovery that we look for in science fiction.  (Since precious few science fiction movies of the last 15 years contain any of these elements one is forced to measure Solaris against a theoretical mean rather than its contemporary competition.)Like 2001, Solaris is really a meditation on the human condition, in particular a consideration of the limits of what can be defined as the individual, as human, as sentient.  It is a simple, minimalist movie that doesn't have any interest in space opera, and conceives of action not as a matter of resolving conflict, but only as a necessity of making inevitable choices.  It's "Waiting for Godot" where Estragon and Vladimir are forced to flee the stage or perish at the end of the second act, where there is no option, as in Beckett, to simply ride out the calendar.  "There's no solution," says a character in Solaris, "there's only choices.  And unless you realize that, you're going to die here."  In Soderbergh's Solaris, the demand for solutions is a flaw, an artifact of the vain human ego that wants credit for "being smarter than them," as Viola Davis' character asserts early in the film.This is not a film that is going to please the average American moviegoer, both because of its slow (but certainly not dull) pace, its focus on the psychological, and its disinterest in the notions of heroism that drive the bland balance of our moviegoing fare.  The film is paced slow not because the director is trying to drive home a point.  It is paced such in order that the viewer has time to consider, speculate and imagine himself in the philosophical position of the characters on board the spacecraft.  Viewers who would rather not figure themselves into the equation are indeed going to have some extra time on their hands watching George Clooney toss and turn in his dreams at night.  Nevertheless this is simply his best performance on the big screen, the first one where he's able to use his limitations as an actor as part of his character rather than battle (however valiantly) against them.Solaris is not the most fun movie you are going to see this winter, but it might be the best.  It's certainly a welcome change of pace from the increasingly vulgar and stupid drivel that Hollywood tries to pass off as science fiction, and perhaps best of all it suggests that Steven Soderbergh may have a higher gear that he's ready to shift into as a director, able to produce films that stand tall in the broad context of film history, and not just against the diminished stature of his contemporary competitors.

reviews.review_title: .....did I just dream this? Hell I know I liked it whatever!
reviews.content: Steven Soderbergh, it seems to me, can direct just about anything (book, play or just an interesting idea) and make the best of what it has to offer. Solaris has a lot to say and maybe a little too much for some us. It is never just entertainment, it has much more to offer. Sometime ago I read an article about dream states. The main idea of this article was that we are all of us living in a dream; and all living matter is in a dream state peculiar to it's own species and indeed peculiar to each individual within that species. Something of this idea is being worked out in Solaris. Death does not end the existence of an individual but simply transfers him or her to a different dream state. One of the questions which this raises (if you accept the validity of the 'dream' state idea) is which of these dream states may, with authority, consider itself to be the ascendant state; is any of these states entitled to consider itself the one which is the sole arbiter of truth regarding the nature of existence. Solaris, somewhere out there - where doesn't matter, is a planet which has the power to allow individuals in different states of 'being' to see and contact one another with all the attendant confusion that this obviously brings to all parties on both sides of the existence/dream barrier. This moves on to pose many more questions and dilemmas e.g. does time continue upon changing states? If it does is it synchronous with all other dream states? Etc. This film isn't really just a sci-fi flick or for that matter, a romance it's in a category that's other than that. Decide for yourself what and where it is. Soderberg floats my boat. Always has. If you're a fan too this one's for you.

reviews.content: This movie sucks. There is no music and the acting is bland. I don't understand the story and the characters have no connection. I could have got more out of a Spanish soap opera. This movie is so bad, you won't want to see any of George Clooney's other movies. Georgie shouldn't even be an actor. Syriana sent me to sleep as well. His gay ass should be thrown out!! THIS MOVIE SUCKS!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

reviews.review_title: Waiting to be entertained? You're missing the point.
reviews.content: There's an old maxim about music that goes: "All music is sound, but not all sound is music." In a way, what this says is: one should remember the intent of something before judging its worth. In the case of cinema, it can be re-written as, "All movies are films, but not all films are movies." By this, I point to the distinction of 'movie' as a piece of filmed entertainment and 'film' as a work intended more as a creative expression with less emphasis on entertainment value. So enters Solaris.Firstly, Solaris is not a re-make of the Tarkovsky film. It is merely another interpretation of the original novel. Comparing the two films is like comparing two brothers, not a father and a son. This may seem incidental but is important when justifying the originality of each film and the lineage. Soderbergh's Solaris is, to me at least, a pure meditation on loss. It is slow but only so slow as to let the viewer react to the events, place them in their own lives, tally their effects and then place themselves back into the film. It pulses slowly and quite intentionally. To call it boring is merely to admit a lack of connection with it.Solaris is a work so specifically personal that it either destroys you or bounces off like a ping-pong ball with little ado. This is probably why Solaris is consistently either the most profound film many have seen or the most boring film many have seen. Either reaction is justified because what you get out of the film really depends on what you bring into the film.If you've ever had anyone close to you die in a way that left a mass of unresolved issues, this film addresses what is likely your greatest fantasy: what if they could come back? If you have had a great love that simply ended and you were never sure why, the film presents an allegory for what it would be like to have that again.
