It's nothing more than a rather strange and uninteresting love-story, instead of a mind-dazzling sci-fi movie. It is not intriguing at all and you will only be left witch a sense of profound bore after seeing it. It does not engage you, you don't care about the characters, and nothing really happens at all worth mentioning or worth your time (or mine).Don't bother watching it, it's a complete waste of time!/Linus

The movie was great. Soderberg made a great film. I love the eeriness and the slow movement of the film. This movie has done a very good job of capturing the mood of the novel. I read quiet a few reviews here that are crying about the movie being slow and hard to understand. If you want an easy to watch sci fi film , go see Nemesis (not to say that Nemesis is a not a great movie, it is). Then there are those of you who start dissing the novel. Solaris is considered one of the greatest sci fi novels of our time, so to call it second rate sci fi is just plain stupid. As for the film, this movie did something that I hoped it would, it took a portion of the book and adopted it into a fantastic, artistic film, full of psychological twists, great acting and spectacular cinematography. To recreate the book to the t is simply impossible. The genious of this book is that for the large part it happens in the mind. So no two people will see this story in the same way. It is also wrong to say that Soderberg was trying to compete with 2001 some how. Just because this is a psychological movie that happens in space does not make it a rip-off of 2001. This movie was about half the book, and i understand why. If the whole book was to be made into the movie, the film would be way too long to show in a theater. Overall, this movie was done very well, I love the book and I love the movie. To those of you who haven't seen this movie I advise the following: if you're looking to see another installment of 2001, don't go, if you're looking to see a Trek type film, don't go, if you're looking to see a picture that is nothing like you've ever seen before and which will seem different every time you watch it, while being very uncommericial, mesmorising and brilliantly made, GO SEE IT !!! 10 stars.

This remake of Solaris is ultimately unengaging and cold.  Whilst the look of the film is good and Clooney's performance is strong, the script is wholly inadequate.  Soderbergh claimed that he had "gone back to the source novel" for this film - he has categorically not done so, unless he read a very different translation to me.  The book was NOT about "a second chance to correct a mistake" but about Man's inability to understand himself or the universe.Even though it's 90 minutes shorter than Tarkovsky's snail paced treatise, it feels even longer.  Whilst it is a laudable attempt to produce an intelligent, non-mainstream science fiction film, it is ultimately a big disappointment.

Ok I am not one to tear apart movies but this movie is so boring and pointless. It has little to zero plot, no structure, no life. The scenes jump around and it does not follow any story line. All it involves is Clooney (him being in every scene) walking around confused and saying random lines of dialogue and having pointless flashbacks. George Clooney can do so much better. The best thing about this movie was the fact that Clooney was in it other then that bring a pillow.

reviews.review_title: This one's for Outer Limits and John Edward fans
reviews.content: Sorry, sci-fi and Clooney fans, but this one seems silly to me. Byline: Astronaut visits space station and soon his dead wife, friends and fellow astronauts show up one after another. Makes us wonder if an alien intelligence has read said astronaut's mind and is tricking him into returning said station to Earth for its own inscrutable purposes.For 1985-92 Outer Limits fans, this is familiar territory. Humans in outer space typically see lost loved ones and/or have their minds taken over by aliens, who, having no "lives" of their own, just hover in space, waiting for human victims to come by to be victimized. Not that The Outer Limits doesn't have some good stories, but rather that the writers pepper their young audiences with aliens getting inside their skins or inside their minds, to the point where we've come to expect these once-novel, now-tired sci-fi clichés.Fans of "clairvoyant" John Edward, who "connects" fans to their deceased relatives, may also find this kind of thing rewarding, as it perpetuates the dead-coming-back-to-visit-the-living idea. I wouldn't call this sort of film "science fiction," as there is no science and it promotes the idea that when humans go into space they see not what the universe gives them but what they want to see - lost loved ones and fanciful and tantalizing vistas that have nothing to do with the mind-boggling universe that actually exists. I thought Robin Williams' "What Dreams May Come" explored this territory much better and more imaginatively, even if it was meant to represent the after-life and is not "sci-fi."

If u are looking for a science fiction blockbuster. I advise u not to watch this film as u may become bored and disillusioned with the format this film takes. However if your looking for a film that really stimulates the mind and can be a bit of a head trip. This is the film to watch. The acting is top notch and the chemistry between Cloony and McElhorne(who easily provides one of her best preformances to date) is electrifying. Some people may feel this film is slow-paced and the director (Soderbergh) doesn't really get his message across. But i feel the silences (used alot in Solaris) tell a thousand words specially when describing the complex relationship that exists between the characters played by Cloony & McElhorne, and at the end of the day the film lets u come up with the answers as to what Solaris truely represents. One of the many questions the film asks is whether one man would give up life as he knows it for true bliss and happiness with his loving wife(even though it may not necessary be his wife) and even made me wonder whether in the same position if i would carry out the same decisions he eventually makes given the choice? Solaris overall asks more questions than it answers (which it leaves to the audience to figure out) is a gem of a movie that is highly underated.

Every so often a movie comes along just like this one, a movie that hits some people deeply while causing others to scratch their head in boredom and confusion. For me, I know I liked the movie. Although I can still not figure out everything that went on, I know that I liked it. For me a movie is good if it stays with me beyond the theater. This film, and other recent films like Mulholland Drive, Memento, Fight Club, Punch-Drunk Love, and Donnie Darko has taken up much of my thinking time out of the theatre.Although in most of those movies events occur that sometimes do not make much sense, the overall movie draws you in to its complexity and makes you think outside of a theatre. The film evolves from being a simple escape into an experience, sometimes that might change the way you think about a certain aspect of your life. Such is Solaris. If you are capable and willing to lend some of your time outside the theatre to think about what went on in the movie, give it a try. It'd recommend it highly. But if all you need is a quick escape, go see Bond. **** out of *****

Solaris is a sci-fi, futuristic, romantic existentialist flick that tries to challenge the audience and the main character's (George Clooney as Dr. Chris Kelvin) ideas about life, death, heaven, reincarnation and life after death. It is wonderful goal for a film to have, but it was a noble plan that failed horribly.Dr. Kelvin is a therapist sent to a space station that is orbiting the planet Solaris. He is supposed to find out why the remaining crew won't come home. Or is he there to figure out why most of the crew was murdered? Or did they commit suicide? Actually, I'm not sure why he is sent there. Solaris creates facsimiles of the crew's dearly departed, mainly Kelvin's late wife, from their memories. I am not sure why the planet Solaris is doing it and neither does the crew. I'm not sure why many things are happening in this movie. The plot isn't too convoluted to be followed. There just isn't any plot at all.The best part of this movie was seeing George Clooney naked-not once, but twice. My favorite nude shot was of Kelvin and his wife sharing a bowl of Ramen noodles in all their post-coital glory. (Clooney is proof that people can look better as they get older!) Clooney also does a great job of doing that charming, soulful, caring, subtly sexy thing he does so well. He perfected it in the other Steven Soderbergh movie he starred in-the wonderfully subtle and sexy Out of Sight. In fact, the flashbacks in Solaris are very reminiscent of the hotel and love scenes between Clooney and Jennifer Lopez in Out of Sight. There's a feeling of invading on someone's intimate moment and memory. With all that, the movie was a colossal waste of time. Wait for it to come on television. Better yet, just rent Out of Sight.

Soderbergh pulled a slow one with "Solaris", and there's nothing wrong with that !! The mood in this film is hard to describe... A kind of meditative state, slowly growing, perfectly complemented by the lush soundtrack. This is also one of Clooney's best roles (especially compared to his wishy-washy performances in blockbusters aka ocean's eleven, peacemeaker,etc).And when the weirdness kicks in, the movie just gets better... But PLEASE don't rent this puppy expecting Alien or Star Wars !!! It's a slow paced adventure, more akin to Gattaca or code46, you have been warned ! Far out - 9/10

I cannot believe the length of commentary attributed to this movie.  It was the most boring movie I have seen since Sleuth.  It made absolutely no sense.  The characters were wooden, the script was obfuscated.   George must have been embarrassed by it all (except that he picked up a paycheck for it).  The only pluses are:(1)  I had some wonderful sleep that was desperately needed.(2)  I did not have to pay an admission charge.  I was on assignment to evaluate the quality of the print, sound, etc., which was very fine--thanks to the theater projectionist and equipment.(3)   The movie was only slighly more than 1 and 1/2 hours in length.Watching the grass grow created more of a stir than did this movie. I can only pray that there will not be a sequel to this.

reviews.review_title: Siralos. It's all backwards. A screensaver of a movie.
reviews.content: Say 'Solaris' out loud but backwards.  "Siralos" sure sounds a bit like "sure a loss".  There, you got it.  Don't waste your money on this . . . er, thing.  It looks alot like an '80s computer screensaver and has about as much content.  Space is empty and this film tries to prove it.  A space warp in Clooney's career . . . or a black hole?

reviews.review_title: Technically excellent, but oh so dull
reviews.content: I was expecting great things after reading a review of this.  It started off well enough, with a lot of slow or static shots rarely focussed on the person talking, making you think about the consequences of what was being said for the person in shot - mmm, arty, I thought!  After that, this artiness got a little tiresome, with continued use of very slow pans and lingering shots of nothing happening.It wasn't long before I realised Solaris was a would-be "2001: A Space Odyssey": the lingering shots, nothing much happening, even the style of music.  I was never a fan of 2001 because of that slowness (yet how did Alien manage to go slow but keep the audience engaged?), so Solaris trying to mimic that wasn't endearing.  I sat and tried to work out what kind of a movie it was.  Exciting?  No way.  Tense?  Nope.  Thrilling?  Funny? Humourous?  No.  Emotional?  Surprisingly, no.  Interesting?  No, sorry, not at all.Having watched plenty of other films (and TV series like Star Trek!) make the same kind of story much more engaging, I found I really didn't care what happened.  They even tried a couple of twists, but these just came off as "let's-add-a-twist."I suppose the acting was okay given the limited material, but in the end the movie just seemed rather pointless, contrived, dull (which I may have mentioned already), and unbelievable.  There was the promise of much, with exciting possibilities set up, but the promise wasn't delivered, unfortunately.(As a slight aside, it never looks good when people are sitting in the cinema with their eyes closed, and worse still when people walk out 15 minutes from the end; both of these happened when I saw Solaris.)

Why bring up this argument, you may ask?I was scamming through imdb.com and a quote, that is in my subject field (by Steven Soderbergh, director), is presented in the trivia for Solaris (2002)..I had an ENORMOUS problem with the remake, that refers to the said comment.
Here is goes:
I like Steven Soderbergh's films. I find his work lively and fresh, and also respect that he can adjust his aesthetics/style toward the films he makes. Most of his films vary wildly in content as well; also from commercial to artistic-like. Most of the films in his lap (Sex, Lies, and Videotape (1989), Schizopolis (1996), Limey, The (1999), Erin Brockovich (2000), Traffic (2000), Ocean's Eleven (2001)) have one numerous awards and accolades and are even considered modern masterpieces in certain circles.Considered the most famous Soviet filmmaker since Sergei M. Eisenstein, Andrei Tarkovsky (on the other hand), was proven as one of the most idiosyncratic director's even now, after his tragic death. Despite his films being considered a part of world cinema's history (and being a big influence to some directors, note: Soderbergh), they fail to reach critic and commercial success. This is largely due to the same idiosyncrasies mention previously, they include affecting-yet-deliberate (Most Northern Americans read: slow) storytelling, blatant religious references (even as far as making them a part of the story and sometimes the story itself: The Mirror (1975), a biography of Tarkovsky) and ideas, Classical scoring and use of Classical Paintings within the films themselves, and last but not least: strong character development/psychology with references to each scene.Solyaris (1972) had every bit of Tarkovsky's vision of film making down to a science (easy argument; all of his films are highly respect, if not appreciated), no pun. Due to his highly eclectic form of storytelling and aesthetics; the atmosphere within the film is so dense and rich it begs for repeated viewings on that alone. Space is dirty. It is not a safe place to be, and not everyone is beautiful that goes there. Also, there is much more than a love story that is brewing in this film and it allows you to follow that major plot's course to the fullest (with 165 minutes running time). This is where I believe that Solaris (2002) suffers most (a meager 99 minutes running time).Solaris (2002) attempts to find middle ground with mainstream culture by eliminating subtleties and pushing the story into a faster momentum. Director James Cameron (of Titanic (1997) fame) was set to direct, but was said to have opted for a Producer credit instead, because he felt he couldn't portray the story completely. It's possible that even after James Cameron sidestepped, it still hurt the film, but I doubt it.
This was Soderbergh's first attempt at melding art film with mainstream; it is evident even during Pre-Production (I began following the film, when he received the green light). It rode on a form of endeavor, but ultimately failed for it's lack of follow-through and inspiration. We needed more conflict and more underpinned suggestions for it to ride, but he wanted the mainstream to watch it. This is all shown through the perspective fades from George Clooney's character and Solaris itself, it's bland and adds very little or sometimes nothing to either the story or his psychology. Sadly it even becomes annoying. Solyaris (1972) includes similar transitions, but they play very differently.All of this to say that Solaris (2002) is a movie I shouldn't watch? Not exactly.It is a movie that disrespected the original film. And, after watching it I got to thinking that this movie was going to make everyone that watched it, not care to even check up on a great film that is: Solyaris (1972)Oh yea, and I believe that the quote mentioned above was cut-off, it should read: If the audience does not enjoy the first 10 minutes of the film, then they might as well leave and go watch the better version.

Movies where half the audience gets up and walks out are automatically Champions. This is a spectacular film, and were it not for Equilibrium finally being released this year, this would be #1 for 2002.Were I God, there would be a special section of heaven reserved for those who dug this film.There is a sequence near the end revolving around Clooney's possible return to Earth from the station that may be the most beautiful thing I've seen on film.

reviews.review_title: This film is half the length of the first Solaris film but it is infinitely more boring.
reviews.content: Visually this new adaptation of Solaris is simply dull, as is the plot, the cast and the dialogue. Tarkovsky managed in his version to create stunning imagery which I found extremely thought provoking but this film is just so plain that when I had finished watching I had to wonder why I ever wasted an hour of my life doing so (I say an hour as I had to resort to fast forwarding through most of the painfully irritating flashbacks). Of course I am biased; the reason why I watched this film was to see how it compared to the Tarkovsky film and to be honest I never thought Soderburg and Clooney were up to the job, the best I was hoping for was a film which didn't try to be too clever and instead came up with a few neat innovations for science fiction. Instead the film turned out to be simply the most tedious dialogue I have ever experienced set against endlessly plain futuristic style backdrops broken only by a tacky sex scene featuring an unwelcome view of Clooney's buttocks. Nothing in this film is profound, nothing in this film is entertaining and I can't think of a single reason to recommend anyone this film unless you happen to fancy the leading actors rear end.

All I can say is those that walked out halfway though (and there were a number) missed out on a beautiful experience.Visually wonderful, with excruciatingly beautiful moments of silence, and a great supporting sound track .Visually, I was reminded of 2001 : A Space Odyssey, with the atmosphere of Mr Soderbergh earlier Sex Lies & Videotape.A credible attempt at bring to the screen, what was a wonderful book. (I can't comment on how it compares with the 1972 Solyaris as I have not seen it).For those into that kind of thing you also get a good long look at George Clooney's butt.I will definitely be buying the DVD

This is a beautiful piece of work, rather i should say a piece of art! It's very moody, dark and quiet ; like a poem...pure genius and an excellent job from the film makers. I can't really see what's wrong about you people who don't appreciate it! Why do u have to be so shallow and empty??thanks, Demetris Christodoulides.

This film started out in a 2001 lookalike kind of way, but at least when 2001 was made the Special Effects were just that, Special. Here it just looks tired and re-trodden and completely unoriginal.The only interesting thing about this film was the question "if you could have what your heart desired, how far would you go to keep it?" with the main character's wife reappearing after dying.I can only assume that Steven Soderbergh had developed an interest in mind-bogglingly strong tranquilisers before making this film, which explains the somnambulant pace of the whole darned thing.Being really shallow, the only redeeming feature of this film is the utterly gorgeous Natascha McElhone.Rent this one only if you're having trouble sleeping. It's almost as disappointing as Donnie Darko.

`Solaris' could have been much better had it stayed closer to the intent of Stanislaw Lem's original novel. In Lem's novel, Solaris is a planet totally covered by a gelatinous sea that may or may not exhibit sentience. Humanity puts a station into orbit around the planet to study this colloidal ocean, this strange blob that may or may not be an alien life form. Strange things begin to happen. Geometric shapes appear and disappear in space for no discernable reason, followed by purposeless contraptions, and finally by physical manifestations of people from the scientist's own pasts. The reasons for all this are never determined, and never CAN be determined. Solaris, then, represents the human subconscious, which is not amenable to logic, analysis, or definitive `explanations.' The subconscious generates impulses, dreams, and creative variations for no `purpose' other than to express. To approach the subconscious with mere logic is like asking why circles are round: they just are. Yet man (Western man especially) will not hear of this, for he fancies himself a rational being. He likes to think that his logic dominates his instincts, a delusion that distorts his reason and causes him untold suffering. He insists that he can use the surface of his mind to delve into its own depths, which is like trying to understand a computer program while being controlled by the program itself. Result: one goes in circles that are fraught with obsession, tyranny, and hypocrisy. The surface of the mind can only deal in dualities, in definite things, in hard edges and sharp corners, in actuality. By contrast, the subconscious is the realm of formless, vague, and dynamic potential. It is as amorphous as the strange ocean that covers the planet Solaris.   Such was the intent of Len's novel. The film itself comes closest to this point when a character remarks that, `We don't want other worlds, we just want mirrors.' This concept is pursued further in the film when Chris Kelvin, a psychologist who is sent to the station (George Clooney) grapples with how he related to his dead wife, who suddenly appears to him out of nowhere. Kelvin gradually realizes that he had mostly been in love with a mirror of himself. It dawns on him that he was married not to a person but to his projection, just as the physical manifestation of his wife on the space station is a `projection' from the planet Solaris.  Kelvin's failure to understand this about himself while his wife was still alive on earth is made all the more poignant by the fact that he is a psychologist -- someone who supposedly appreciates the vagaries of mind. Indeed, it is his very talent at seeing into the human mind that thwarts his wife's attempts to communicate with him as a conscious being with her own profound feelings. After all, as a psychologist, it's Kelvin's `job' to dissect, analyze, and `figure out,' not to submit to another in the interests of intimacy, even though Kelvin craves intimacy as much as any other human.
Meanwhile, regarding art direction, technical details are de-emphasized, which supports the story's message that human technology can never lead to an understanding of a truly alien thing. This is a refreshing change from tedious attempts by special effects people to show off their computer skills. The space suits, however, are unforgivably hokey. They look like silver overalls worn by oil derrick workers, not something that provides raw life support in the most hostile environment there is: space.    Among the film's more fundamental problems is its apparent attempt to satisfy today's demand that a storyline must revolve around a `love interest.'  With just a few more minutes of running time, a few more lines of dialogue, and a few more hints at the overall meaning of the planet Solaris, the movie would have retained what it has, including the `love interest,' while also including themes that are more clearly universal and profound. The film's biggest flaw, however, is wrapped in its primary strength, which is its over-reliance on mood and ambience. At first glance this may seem a refreshing change. Today, Hollywood rarely budges from hackneyed storytelling formulae because moviegoers turn up their noses when presented with anything too fresh and original, anything that is too much of what they ask for. Nonetheless, a director must balance mood with plot. He must counter-foil ambience with action. He should start with a forceful story, pithy dialogue, and purposeful action, and intersperse these with scenes that have no plot, dialogue, or action at all--just photography accompanied by memorable music that fleshes out the story's `feel' and `spirit.' `Solaris,' however, is nothing BUT `feeling' and `spirit,' a pastiche of glances, gestures, and snapshot scenes that occasionally approach brilliance, but, taken as a whole, demand more than they return. Thus, `Solaris' loses its balance. This is why some people walk out of the theatre before the film ends. They appreciate that there may just be a profound message somewhere in it but, weary of its nebulousness, they resign themselves to asking friends what THAT was all about. Most of their friends will shrug their shoulders, and even when one of those friends offers a useful interpretation, the moviegoer thinks, `Oh. I see. Whatever.'
`Solaris' will flop commercially, but time will be kind to it. It is like a small coral atoll that breaks out on the surface of an ocean.  At first, people scorn the atoll, step on it, and dump trash on it. Then, as the water around it sinks-i.e., as today's awful movies continue to become even more awful-the atoll becomes an island, and finally a mountain that towers over the sinking sea. This does not mean that `Solaris' will one day become a `cult classic,' or any kind of `classic' based on its intrinsic qualities. It means that the film will eventually be somewhat more appreciated in the context of its time. Viewed from this angle, I salute the director for at least trying to do something different in a way that's constructive, rather than adolescent, vulgar, or gratuitous.

Solaris is a wonderful film.  Its funny how when people love a movie they'll go to any length to defend it, even to call people dumb who don't like it -- assuming that the reason they don't like it is that they don't understand it.Film can be like music when it comes to taste.  For instance, one can appreciate the musical prowress of a "jam" band, but be bored by the jam. 
Steven Soderbergh has taken on the role of jam band.  Solaris is a jam session of a movie.  It is full of variations on a theme, and false starts that don't develop and riffs that are repeated.  The film is deliberately paced, it is not slow.  And just like a jam session, when you least expect it Solaris comes back to the important riffs.The funny thing is -- that is the best description I can give of Solaris without spoiling it.  It does have very little "plot".  It is not a densely written thriller (I don't mean dense as in stupid, I mean dense as in LA Confidential -- a bunch going on).  It is well acted and well directed and well photographed.  An interesting link between 2002 Solaris and 1972 Solaris is that by the end of the 2002 film, George Clooney seemed to look more and more like the original lead actor, it was uncanny.If you liked 2001: A Space Odyssey, A.I.:Artificial Intelligence, and Contact (and even Magnolia) I think you'll like Solaris.  If you don't like at least 2 of 3 those of those movies, Solaris is probably not your cup of tea.  But that doesn't make you dumb and that doesn't make me a snobbish pseudo-intellectual coffee house beatnik, either.

I have read Lem's book and I consider it very interesting. Steven Sodenbergh's film is just boring. The plot is, generally, faithful to the original, but some important details are different, which makes the movie lacks tension. In my opinion, if there were no shortcuts, and some events were showed longer and deeper, as it was in the book, the action would, paradoxally, go faster. Besides there is too much romance and too little science-fiction in this movie. Half of Lem's book is about the planet Solaris and it's living, thinking ocean itself, and here? There also is very little about Chris' and Rheya's life on Earth in the book. I don't like that they changed names, I think that the old ones were good, but maybe they would sound too strange for Americans (Rheya's name was originally Harris, Snow's - Snaut, and dr Gordon was a man named dr Sartorius). Generally the film is too slow, too shallow, too boring and too little science-fiction to me. Maybe it's good as a love-story, I don't know...

Im giving this a 10/10 because this movie is right up my street. Solaris oozes coolness. Its a visually beautiful movie with great acting from Clooney, Davies, etc... I'd put this film in the same league as Vanilla Sky, not everyones cup of tea but definitely my drink of choice. The plot line stays simple throughout and the film uses it visuals to keep the story where its going. Its basically a love story in outer space - but its really nowhere near that cheesy! Although some might say it's nothing special I really think it takes a lot of input and effort to achieve a film of this calibre. For instance the quality of acting is heavily relied on unlike some Hollywood blockbusters these days that count on huge special effects and CGI to get the audience in. The soundtrack NEEDS to be spot on, that mellow psychedelic ambiance is perfect here. The visual effects must stay with reality, not too much CGI, which spoils so many films of late, stick to the basics of actual set design and real props instead of computer generated ones, it does this so well. And most importantly the Direction, Steven Soderbegh delivers!!! Watch this alone, without interruption, I mean really watch it - You'll love it.

One reviewer wrote that the basic plot is aliens appearing as human beings on a spaceship in the hope they will be taken back to earth. This is overly simplistic and displays a lack of understanding (midway through the film, when the main character wondered the reason behind the "alien" causing these people to appear on the ship, it was pointed out to him that his mistake was to assume that the alien needed a reason to do what it was doing). The "alien" is merely incidental to the basic plot of the film which is, in fact, centred around a man's struggle to come to terms with a personal trauma in his life and the desire to turn back the clock and have things turn out differently.I thought this Solaris remake was an outstanding film - even better than the 1972 original. My beef with the 1972 version was that there was no depth or explanation behind the particular apparitions appearing on the ship - who was the boy? Why did the main character behave in such a way towards his "visitor" and what was behind his "visitor"'s behaviour? The updated version of the film answers those questions by giving an insight into the background of the main character and his "visitor", and the film is all the richer for it. Some people might claim this background information makes the film slow-moving; for me, it's essential to the enjoyment of the movie.Don't let the appearance of George Clooney put you off either. OK, he overacts at times but otherwise this is his finest acting performance. The direction and the musical score are superb, all adding to the atmosphere.If you want fast-moving action, comedy or a "feel good" experience, go elsewhere - if you want to watch a stimulating and thought-provoking film, based on a struggle and desire that many of us feel but rarely discuss, watch Solaris.

this movie is an excellent example about how trying to create art can totally mess up a great story basicly the movie is a serie of incoherent sequences and at the end you still have no idea what the movie is really about, if you can call it a movieas a scifi loving person this movie was an insult for my eyes people looking for a romantic movie might like it but if you are looking for good scifi this is not a movie you like to see

reviews.review_title: One of the great sci-fi films
reviews.content: I think this is an incredible film, and definitely ranks alongside my favorite sci-fi movies as well as my favorite movies generally. What is so wonderful about it is its sense of quiet intensity, a feeling that only films of the caliber of "2001: A Space Oddessey" manage to achieve. Also akin to that film it also achieves this wonderful sense of isolation and really create Solaris, the planet, as almost a character in its own right.There is little more I can say except that this film is brilliantly directed and paced, shot with more then a nod or two to Stanley Kubrick and impeccably acted (particularly by Clooney who really defies expectations) But also and most importantly for a sci-fi it is thought provoking and engaging.

reviews.review_title: Welcome to real, classic science fiction!
reviews.content: In the annals of science fiction films, there are a few types:  horror stories transported to space (Alien and the assorted knock-off's), space operas which are nothing but Westerns (horse operas) transported to space (Star Wars, Star Trek lately, ...) and then, real science fiction, which usually deals with ideas and concepts (2001, 2010, The War of the Worlds, Planet of the Apes, etc.) in space or a futuristic setting.  Welcome to the latter.  Its' origin derives from the brilliant science fiction novel of Stanislaw Lem.  The almost three hour Russian version is an incredible film in its own right.  Steven Soderbergh has also crafted an excellent film from this material.  Although both versions utilize Stanley Kubrick's techniques from 2001, Steven's current film more directly pays homage to Kubrick with the setup of some scenes and music directly taken from the film.  This film is not for everyone.  If you are going to see this because you want to see aliens bursting out of chests, laser gun battles or even just George Clooney's naked butt, stay home.  You will be disappointed and may embarass yourself like the person at the end of the showing I attended, where a gentleman was talking in a loud voice about how the movie stank, in direct contrast to those who clapped at the end.  This is a sophisticated, psychological exploration into the human mind...and maybe not just the human mind.  Excellent acting by George Clooney and the rest of the cast. Congratulations to Steven Soderbergh!  You have kept the spirit of the original.

This film is a remake of a 1972 Soviet film, directed by Andrei Tarkovsky--although, Soderbergh wrote his own script, and he may have just been doing an adaption of Stanislaw Lem's novel--and while I like the original better, Soderbergh did a good job of updating and Americanizing it.Like the original, it is heavy on mood, character and concept (and yes, "slow" is not a bad word here) and light on story, but it works. It was originally a novel, and you don't get a sense of that in Soderbergh's like you do in Tarkovsky's. Kudos to Soderbergh for being willing to hack away at the material to make it more filmic.And in truth, the film is not that weird or hard to understand if you've ever done a psychedelic drug. The symbolism is obvious: George Clooney takes a trip and starts hallucinating, just like everyone else who's been within reach of the mysterious Solaris. (It's a nebulous cloud in space that shows signs of intelligence.) Soderbergh (as well as Tarkovsky) gives us a compelling visualization of a mental state, and he appears to accomplish everything he sets out to accomplish. Is there much more you can ask from a film?

Steven Soderbergh has created a tantalizing film that will haunt you long after you have left the theater.  This film raises questions like: What is the nature of life?  What does it mean to be human?  What is the nature of love?  There aren't any pat answers to any of these questions; this is a film that makes you fill in the gaps.The film is very quiet in places, letting a glance or an expression tell the story where words would only get in the way.  George Clooney gives an emotional performance that is matched by Natascha McElhone.  If you are looking for whiz-bang effects and nothing that you have to actually think about, go rent "ID4" for the umpteenth time.  "Solaris" is much more than that.

When i first rented Solaris i mistakenly rented the original Russian version which i thought was an excellent movie, full of atmosphere and emotional depth. I was surprised therefore when the remake, which usually doesn't do the original justice...did just that and more. Solaris is a great movie...Clooney's performance is outstanding, much better than batman and Natasha Mcelhone is just beautiful. There isn't much conventional exploding, hair-raising action in this film, which sets it out from the usual sci-fi that's out there. The closest correlation i can make is with 2001 a space odyssey...without the extreme confusion as to what the point of it all was. Watch this one with your girlfriend and she'll bawl into your arms for hours...an extremely deep poignant story and though a remake...definitely original in every other sense.

Before watching this movie I had gone through and read many negative reveiws, most claiming the movie was boring or non-sensical.  So I rented the DVD with apprehension and tried to watch the film with an open mind. About 15 minutes into it I was pleasantly surprised to find that I was really enjoying it.  Possibly it was my mood at the time but I found the tone, the lack of background music and the pace to be very soothing.  In fact, if I had to name my favorite aspect of this movie it would have to be the lack of a sweeping soundtrack or background wash throughout the movie. And I would not agree that the story jumps around too much or is non-sensical.  I thought the flashes from the main characters memories made sense, anyway it worked for me.I thought the character development, acting and writing were all average to above average.  The set work and visuals were very good and as I mentioned above, the tone and pace of the movie really worked for me.  I also liked the story and the fact that I could interpret it myself and that the writer and director did not cram the correct interpretation down my throat.
This movie has no real action at all, no explosions and does not portray a classic 'hero' vs 'bad guy' plot so many will not enjoy it.  I would not call it my favorite movie but I would recommend it to someone who might like something besides action/adventure movies.

We will wake up one day to discover that Steven Soderbergh is a great director. He is a true auteur working in an industry of philistines. A quick scan of his filmography reveals an artist not content with the ordinary repetition of craft, but one who dares to explore the edge from time to time. Like Kubrick before him, he does it all. He writes, directs, photographs, and edits. "Solaris" is essentially a one-man show. I don't think it is any accident that his best films are those single explorations of theme. "Solaris," "The Limey," "Out of Sight," "The Underneath," "King of the Hill," and, of course "Sex, Lies, and Videotape," are amazing in their delicacy, or brash in audacity. "Traffic" is, in this critic's opinion, the only true, large breakout film for him. "Ocean's Eleven" was unwatchable. "Erin Brockovich" the most overrated film in 2000. Soderbergh's heart is large but his filmmaking sentiments are more intimate.Now, "Solaris." I have seen the Tarkovsky version but I have not read the book. The '72 Solaris was long (almost three hours), very talky, and very Russian. Tarkovsky's visuals were in line with the cinematic experimental vogue of the time. Neither groundbreaking nor revolutionary in general terms, Tarkovsky's Solaris was his attempt to capitalize on and experiment with a medium that was finding powerful legs in the brave new world of anything-goes cinema. "2001" opened many doors, and Kubrick's "Clockwork Orange" was to come next year.Soderbergh's "Solaris is neither dyspeptic nor vacuous. It's colors are rich and saturated--which I find a curious style choice given its metaphor--its music evocative, and its actors engagingly human. Perhaps one could have wished for a film more antiseptic, more Spartan, more "Kubrickian," but that would go against the grain of the director's intent. If Kubrick was the director of opposites, so is Soderbergh, giving you a SF film without science, a psychological film without the psychology, whose inherent truths lie deep in the penetrating eyes of its stars--those of the actors and the star-like planet their ship revolves around. And what of Solaris? It's not so much a planet than a mass of neurons and electrical impulses that sparks and flares in resplendent glory not unlike our own brain. Tarkovsky's Solaris was made of water. Here, we are treated to phantasmagoria as psychic malevolence.Clooney and McElhone give understated but excellent, brave, performances. In their eyes we see their love, angst, confusion, despair. This is Clooney's 3rd film with Soderberg and one can see why. Clooney is becoming the great actor of age, honing his craft in small but important films. His role in "O Brother Where Art Thou" is nothing short of genius. As Clooney begins to embody the elemental force of the "everyman," to use Clooney is to suggest, through cinematic shorthand, as vast range of emotions in a short amount of time. His time has come.Soderbergh may never make the multi-billion dollar success. In fact, I hope he doesn't. I would rather him make more pictures like "Solaris" and less like "Ocean's Eleven." Small, in this case, is definitely better.

Worst movie ever made. Who writes this stuff and then somehow it gets a remake. As if remaking it with a good actor is going to change the type of movie it is. Its dull. Lifeless boring. I almost asked for a refund! The only thing good about this movie is that somehow George Clooney is able to act out his part of the movie well. Unfortunately for him its not his fault this movie is badly written and scripted. Wheres the action? Wheres the humor? Wheres the fear factor? Wheres the love? Wheres the war? Wheres the drama? For that matter wheres the plot? I hope there's no future remakes of this. If there is maybe they should get John McEnroe to play in it and call it YOU CANT BE SOLARIS!

Psychological brain twister. This movie will mess you up if you have been properly chilled. Emotions are tweaked, and information is given only on a need-to-know basis. George Clooney gives a above-average performance, yet nothing super special. If you love science fiction, you'll enjoy this. Blockbuster-lovers best leave it on the shelf.

reviews.review_title: Did we see the same movie? I loved it!
reviews.content: Okay, nobody actually chews any scenery in this film, and there are no big, loud explosions, shoot-outs or fist-fights.  Only one person screams or yells, and only for a minute or two.  By the hollywood formula then, this is a bad movie....By the standard of intelligent and stimulating film, however, this thing is a gem.  It's not about extremes of anger or violence, but about the ways people live and cope with tragic and even blameworthy events day-to-day. Lem, like a sci-fi Camus, has found surprising qualities in the life right under our nose, and, in seeing them, we find something more real and telling than any description of people in more overtly painful, but much less likely circumstance.Some critics have complained about the "artsy" Kubrickian style of direction, but they are, in my opinion, only noticing the similarity of the sets to those of 2001, and the quietness of the soundtrack.  Soderberg uses the camera as a recorder of events as they happen, physically present with the actors as some non-character point-of-view, and he lets his microphones record, essentially, the "found" sound of life in the space-station. Soderberg's style then is clearly descended, not from Stanley Kubrick, but Robert Altman, and such a direct style is anything but artsy.All in all, I give this film a 9.  I never give anything a 10....

I know there are rabid fans of this film, but I personally found it slow-moving and dull, driven by an attempt to make it very artsy. Believe me, I appreciate artsy movies that are not typical Hollywood, but this one just didn't do it for me. I assume the original 1973 Russian film is better than this as (from what I've read) also seems to put the people in a slightly different context.To me the pacing and cinematography was like a poor blend of 2001 and Blade Runner. The idea is interesting, but I would have been more satisfied with this film if it had been 45 minutes long rather than 90. Even though I'm a sci-fi fan, I am not surprised that I had not heard of this movie earlier, although it has such a well-known actor as George Clooney.

This is far most the best movie this year I've seen(it is in cinema's over here in Amsterdam in 2003), where the original Solaris was totaly boring, this 2002 version kept my full attention from the first minute till the last seconds.The music, the visuals, the sound-effects, everything is so good. It's not just SF, it's not just drama, it's so much more.But one advice, if you expect laserswords, pizza-da-Hutt-like creators, don't watch it. Don't expect to see a very happy movie, but one which leaves you with a lot of questions (at least, I had that). If you like intelligent SF, this is sure a masterpiece!And don't look at it in advance with thoughts about Clooney, Soddenberg, etc, don't expect anything, just look at it ... and perhaps there is a chance you see it like I saw this movie ...

reviews.review_title: There's a reason this DVD only cost me five dollars
reviews.content: Despite a big name for the lead role and a cool concept, this movie failed to hold my attention for more than 8 minutes at a time. So he's a psychologist, and somehow, somewhere, mankind has developed a space station orbiting a planet. Where is this planet? How did he get there in under 40,000 years? Are all psychologists qualified astronauts in the future? Why don't we ever get to see the alien-vaporizer doohickey in action? Why do we have too see George Clooney's ass and not his hot wife's? It's very likely one or all of these questions were answered during this movie, but I couldn't watch it without getting distracted. From the start, I knew at least one or more of the people on the space station weren't real.It's one of those movies where the director and writers make everything confusing so at the end you'll be like, "Whoa, what a mind f%&*!" and then you'll watch it again so the pieces fall into place better. However, with this movie, it's just confusing, and it was so dry and boring that you really don't give a crap to watch it again to see if it makes more sense.Somewhat cool camera work and decent ambient music where the only redeeming qualities. And why do a remake of a movie if the original wasn't that interesting to begin with?

An utterly intriguing sci-fi mystery conducted and performed withconsummate skill. There is a bit of everything in this film: atransfixing romance, an eerie sci-fi setting and a hypnoticdream-like sweep. The conclusion will, understandably, havesome people debating and leave others completely bemused, butthe journey is worth it. The dialogue wobbles slightly abouttwo-thirds of the way through but this is the only criticism of athoroughly rewarding enterprise. Think 'Event Horizon' meets'Mulholland Drive' and it's in there somewhere, although 'Solaris' isless flawed.

reviews.review_title: Does Not Deserve a TOTAL Bashing!
reviews.content: Sure this is not a great film.  But it is an interesting take on the original Russian novel by Lem.  Definitely worth watching for the cinematography and music (Cliff Martinez). I believe part of the problem is the mainstreaming of 'independent' talents like Soderbergh and Jacobs when they get access to big Hollywood wallets.  Also the involvement of a 'titanic' mush-maker like James Cameron is not going to help in the creative sparks department!

reviews.review_title: pointless, idiotic waste of money - Did I forget pointless?
reviews.content: As a sci-fi fan, I was surprised at how boring this film is.  The only thing I can remember equally inane was/is 2001: A Space Odyssey, which I saw in the 4th grade.  It bored me then as much as this one did (I'm now 43).This film has a deliberate lack of a musical underscore, which is usually made up for in dialog or suspense (as with Alfred Hitchcock).  Guess what? There is NO suspense; nothing whatsoever "grabbed" me and the dialog is monotonously plodding.  I even asked my wife, "Are they mumbling and whispering or is it just me?"  She assured me that they were mumbling and whispering -- THROUGH THE WHOLE MOVIE!!!!  The volume level was not just low in our theatre, either.  Some dialog and sound effects were just fine. But an INORDINATELY large amount was almost indiscernible.How did James Cameron go from "the top of the world" with Titanic to THIS?

Why is Hollywood so afraid of exploring intelligent science fiction (ala 2001, Alien, , Blade Runner, Matrix)?  Why is Solaris a ponderous,plodding, tale of obsession?  I know it's based on a novel, and a 70s movie, neither of which I'm familiar with.  I just can't comprehend why anyone would remake this material in this fashion.Don't get me wrong, Solaris is beautifully filmed; Soderbergh has obviously seen 2001 a few times.  It's just that the illogical turns, and unexplored possibilities, submarine the whole thing.For example, why does Clooney's friend invite him to Solaris, saying he's the "perfect" person to be there?  The illogic of this has to be intentional, but why?  Upon arrival, Clooney turns from a top-notch psychiatrist into an irrational fool.  No interest into getting to the bottom of what's going on, just indulgence of his own subconscious. And of course, no contact with Earth to keep him rooted in his mission.  The ending is too muddled and contrived to spawn any post-movie discussions.Yeah, I know, its intended to be a psychological piece, and it has all the trappings of an "important" movie.  But it's a failed attempt to be something more than what it is... ponderous eye-candy.

reviews.review_title: A more accessible version of Solyaris (1972)
reviews.content: I think Solaris is a very good film over the human mind, our longings, conscious and permanent state of not knowing. This version of Steven Soderbergh is more easily digestible than the original of Andrei Tarkovsky, it is more polished, and the long monotonous scenes of the 1972 are either cut or shortened. However, it is still a very interesting film about the human mind, how we mistake love for an attachment to previous memories of a person, how we project those feelings for some experience in the past on a new 'love', failing to see what it is: a product of our imagination. I would certainly recommend to see this version first, and if you like it, if it makes you think, then please, go and see the original of 1972 as well.

Any true fan of cinema will see right through this barely modified carbon copy of past science fiction works. The most obvious influence here (as even Mr. Soderbergh himself has stated) is Stanley Kubrick's milestone film 2001: A Space Odyssey. Being a huge Kubrick fan, I went to see this film hoping that it would pay homage to the late master director. Alas, I left the theater feeling disappointed and even angry. The directing was decent, the acting was at times very good, and even most of the dialogue was fairly intelligent, but the story, the true substance of the movie, was trite, muddled, and downright poor. At least Kubrick had a point to his great piece. Soderbergh, on the other hand, is attempting to be deep without having anything really to say. The premise reminded me of a guilty pleasure of mine, Event Horizon, though in Solaris, there is absolutely no follow through. I have never felt so detached from the characters in a movie in my life. Jeremy Davies provoked an occasional smirk, but other than that, I felt absolutely nothing throughout the entirety of the movie, until feeling very very upset as I exited the theater. Davies' mildly humorous performance upgraded this picture from a $10 root canal to a botched filling. Take my advice: for true sci-fi mastery, see 2001. For a fun and creepy b sci-fi flick, check out Event Horizon. Steve, you simply should not attempt what has already been done. Just because you left the fetus out of the sphere at the conclusion of the film, it doesn't mean I, as well as many others I'm sure, didn't see what you were doing, and as a Kubrick defender, I am insulted by your "movie". D. Davies saved this from an F.

This movie was boring, and I did not understand it!!! It was not entertaining at all and George Clooney could have picked a better role. This movie made no sense, had not plot and can't beleive that James Cameron had anything to do with this movie, especially after his hit movie "Titanic"!!!

reviews.review_title: I Wouldn't compare this to the Russian film
reviews.content: Rheya: What is that out there?Chris: Solaris.Rheya: Oh, my God, yes...I can't remember how I got here. Did I come here with you?Chris: I don't know how you got here.Rheya: What do you mean?Chris: I woke up and you were here.Suggestive of Adam and Eve, this, of course.Humanity is not ready, but we are also very nearly ready.This movie absolutely mesmerizes me, every time I see it. I'm not going to say how many times I have watched it, but ever so often I get this "I need to rent Solaris Again" feeling. I can't think of another extraterrestrial or alien or whatever you want to call it movie that I've been more affected by than this one ("Sphere" was headed in this direction, but got lost on the Interstate). This statement, in and of itself, is a spoiler of sorts, I 'spose.It's a remake, but, though I really enjoyed the original, I feel no qualms about saying that I much prefer this rendering of the story. Imagine a hauntingly beautiful woman who's very distant, versus a hauntingly beautiful woman who's way up close to you, but also quite distant. There are quite a few spots where it strikes the chords of old sci-fi themes a little harder than its predecessor does, but I believe that's a good thing. At the very least, it's great to have both treatments. The things suggested in this movie are not cloaked, over-much, in Mystery and they aren't lingered over. The look on Cloonie's face when he speaks those lines, though: "I woke up and you were here." It's like he understands that he's in over his head, but doesn't want to get away, really. Who, faced with the return of a lost Beloved (especially given the details of Chris' "loss" of Rheya), could stand flushing her into the Vacuum over and over again?Chris is clever and knows a bit about the psyche, but in his way, he's about as irritating and banal as the gum-popping Snow. He seems OK, for the most part, though. It was no fun, watching his Sophistry dismantled by Solaris.

reviews.review_title: Space Orpheus or; how i learned to stop thinking and love feeling
reviews.content: imagine yourself as a conductor supposed to play symphony of Mahler in front of teenagers. lenny bernstein might have done a wonderful job to translate the depth of (gestalt) emotions into personal touch.i was just amazed by the way steve soderberg could maintain the original movie's main frame and at the same time, get rid of the chunks of tarkovsky's fat. the way chris remembers rheya (1. their apartment doesn't have pictures 2. rheya hates chris' snobbish friends talking about metaphysical mumbo-jumbo) can justify his (or hollywood's) bias towards romance.visual style and music : A acting : Bjust a note, early in the movie, there are a few shots from the behind of chris (zoom in or still). once you can resonate your feelings with the character, you'll love this movie.

What can I argue that hasn't been mentioned in other users' comments? Basically it boils down to this.  There's music.   Beethoven, Mozart, Bach as compared to Eminem, NSync, Faith Hill.  There's literature.  Voltaire, Dostoevsky, Hugo as compared to Grisham and Clancy.  And there are movies like Solaris as compared to Eight Crazy Nights, the Sum of All Fears, and Sweet Home Alabama.  General audiences don't like Solaris basically because it's something foreign to them, they can't understand it therefore they don't like it.  I'm sure many of the audience members also couldn't sit through an entire sitting of a Bach concerto or even a Chopin polonaise.  it would bore them.  They just can't appreciate the complexity and richness of the work.  It doesn't entertain them like a rap or pop song with a strong beat does.  Same with books.  You think these people that walk out on this movie could sit through 1000 pages of Tom Jones, one of the best satires on aristocracy ever written?  Probably not.  Too bad American culture is being dumbed down.  American art and entertainment I feel aims for a more straightforward approach, resulting in a melodrama paradigm, granted that there are attempts to obtain a more esoteric approach to film as demonstrated by the overrated Minority Report (still a good film, just overrated), however Solaris just completely supercedes this and others.  A brave attempt on Soderbergh's part to develop a more "European" film technique.  I've seen the original Tarkovsky version and didn't like it as much as this remake, and this coming from someone who absolutely loves Andrei Rublyov and Stalker (go figure).  Why do American students find English and art classes so boring?  They have to study the classics, they have to read shakespeare, they have to listen to composers much more difficult to appreciate than Dave Matthews.  The same reason why many US audiences will find this movie completely boring.

Those who know Stanislaw Lem's Book Solaris will know how horrible difficult it is to create a movie based on it. As I know this book quite well, and I am a huge Lem Fan, I was especially interested in this movie.So I waited ... and watched it ... and I have mixed feelings.On the good side it is slow, very nice music, Cloney is well ... acceptable, the station is nice made, the Planet itself too ... but ... its too short.SPOOOOOOOOOOOOOILER !!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!I just give on example. In the book he has quite a lot meetings with his dead wife, a lot of time passes by before he puts her into the rocket and gets rid of her. In the movie it is like "Scene A: meet girl", "Scene B: get rid of girl". That hurts, hurts very much if you know the book.Another aspect is the change of the characters. Some who are old get very young. Male change into female, etc. It all puzzled me too much.Furthermore I missed the lack of the planet expeditions. I really wanted to know how Soderburg though of them and with the today technical abilities it could have been very spectacular.SPOOOOOOOOOOOOOILER !!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!Well, sadly I never had the possibility to watch the old Russian version. Thought I really have to do it.At the bottom line I ask myself who the target audience for this movie is. SF Geeks ? naw ... to mushy. Artist guys ? naw, too commercial, to Clony. Woman ? Naw, one time Clony ass, there are better ones...So I really don't know ...lg, cs

reviews.review_title: Good film. Good acting. Decent philosophy. Just not Lem.
reviews.content:
Clooney has class and is a real man (not the macho coward a-la Mel Gibson et al.), his range has grown dramatically and his emotions are believable.
Supporting cast almost steals the show (Davies!) but at the end Clooney is more memorable. Music was quite decent and so was cinematography. The movie deserves a couple of Oscars (2002 is a watery vintage...) but there is something unsettling about it. To put it simply: this is not the real Solaris. In fact, it is, once again, a distortion. Stanislaw Lem hated the first Solaris and left Moscow almost in tears. His novel ends on the Planet (Kelvin standing by the Thinking Ocean) with cathartic big bang: "I knew that the reign of scary miracles was over..."
Tarkovsky's overdrawn and self-important film ends on Earth: Kelvin kneeling in front of his father begging for forgiveness, forming a two-bodied incestual Uroboros. Lem complained that his optimistic message was negated and muddled. He was right. Solaris-the-novel is optimistic in that there is a triumph of reason over the "dark depths of the subconscious" and there is a feeling that scary miracles (a thinly veiled reference to the unshakable grip of the Idea of Supreme Being on the throat of human civilization) must be left in the past if we were to grow. Alas, the new Solaris, well-made and compelling it might be, is still a deeply theistic film. No need for spoilers (c'mon, go read the book!) but the final sequence has been seen a good dozen times before: from Michelangelo to the Simpsons. I am not going to criticize Soderbergh for not being able to answer the ripe question: what is there AFTER religion -- he is not the new Plato. And he certainly has the right to believe in Higher Powers. Still... Here's Lem putting in front of us both Creation and Resurrection as mere artifacts of supressed subconscious -- and here are Tarkovsky and Soderbergh turning it into an affirmation of forgiveness that we might gain from some source (Planet Earth or Planet Solaris -- does it really matter?)
Has the time of scary miracles turned into the time of viscous thinking?If you are a latent believer: 10/10. If you are a free thinker: 7/10. If you are a product of Saturday morning cartoons: 2/10.

reviews.review_title: A lofty goal, not quite achieved
reviews.content: I usually love the Soderberg/Clooney one-two punch, but I have to admit Solaris was a bit of a disappointment.  I think they were reaching for 2001, which, admittedly, is a stretch for any filmmaker.  It was however, one of the finest performances I've seen George Clooney in to date.  He was somber and tender and the grieving for his lost wife was very moving.  Ms. McElhone's performance was wonderful as well as Viola Davis'.  The edginess of Jeremy Davies' character did not quite work, though.  All in all, I didn't mind the unanswered questions, but although the direction and editing had the Soderberg stamp, it was just not up to normally high standards I'd come to expect from Steven Soderberg.

Four of us saw a premier showing of Solaris.  We all like George Clooney. We all were looking forward to this movie (he appeared to be a romantic lead in the trailers).  All four of us walked out of the theater with bewildered looks on our faces, saying "Huh?".  I never felt drawn into the characters, never felt much for what they were going through.  Clooney has those wonderful expressive eyes, but even the emotion there didn't resonate. Truthfully, I did not like 2001 and this movie seemed very comparable to that film.  Those who were fans of 2001 and particularly of this director, may take away more from this film than I did.  Our group were not the only patrons to dislike the film, at least thirty people walked out about halfway through.  I did not pay to see this movie and was glad that I had not done so.  I would not rent it or watch it again.  For every movie there is a definite audience, so I know that many people will enjoy the movie and the "messages".  I am just not in that target audience.

reviews.review_title: "Solaris" Is One Er, Uh, Unique Film
reviews.content: I figured it was time to finally make a comment on a film here on IMDB. After all, I use the comments of others to get a feeling for many of the films I see before I bother heading to the multiplex or video store.It's ironic that "Solaris" is the first film I've commented on because, as I left the theatre, I realised that it was ALSO the first time I've ever felt that the time I invested into the film was a complete waste.Oh, I "get it." I know the questions Soderbergh is asking. They're not new: What is the difference between being alive and being dead? Just how wide is the chasm between "reality" and our perception thereof? Did god create us, did we create god, or does it even matter at all? Who are we to define what it means to be "human?" I "get it." I just don't care, because we have no reason to. We don't care about Kelvin, we don't care about his wife, we don't care about this spaceship, or this planet.This movie was the retro-beatnik that sits in the local independent coffee shop and recites off-kilter poetry because he likes to hear his own unorthodoxy."Solaris" is a big fluff of cotton candy which, if it weren't laced with layers of "look what I can do" cleverness, would have been enough to satisfy me. Unfortunately, Soderbergh mistook "vague, disorienting and disconnected" for "deep"...and in the process, wasted an hour and a half of my life. "Battlefield Earth," for example, was a cookie-cutter, amateur recruitment video-slash-miniseries pretending to be a movie...but I was even able to find SOMETHING redeeming about it. "Solaris" is by no means the worst movie I've ever seen. It's just the most worthless and empty experience I've had the misfortune of paying for to date. And I've seen some really vapid films in my time ("2001" comes to mind)Consider this your warning. If pretension and psuedo-intellectualism is your cup of tea, you'll love this film. Otherwise, you'd probably do well to avoid it.

I love this movie, hands down. The music is perfect; among my favorites. True, it's a bit slow in the beginning, but then the movie just send you reeling. The story is captivating. On the surface, it's just a love story, but after watching, you'll realize it's so much more than that. Steven Soderburgh is an absolute genius. If you ever get the chance, watch the original Russian film, as well as reading the book. This movie is just a small part of a great story. In regards to the movie, there are some differences from the book, but I still count it as my favorite. Clooney does surprisingly well in his role, and Viola Davis (Gordon) takes to her role well, even though Gordon was a male in the original. however, Natascha McElhone's (Rhea) performance is particularly breathtaking. She captures the character in ways that can only be seen by watching the movie. I just...just watch the movie. Now.

I didn't see solaris in the theater and I am happy to say that I am sorry I didn't. Solaris is a thought provoking movie in much the same way as About Schmidt is. Its not heavy on action and special effects that some people would expect from a sci fi movie but relies more on interpersonal relationships between the main characters and the audience.Solaris is set on board a space station Im assuming in the not too distant future. Solaris is a newly discovered planet with some unusual characteristics... you see Solaris has the ability to reproduce anything your heart desires... or in the case of Gordon played excellently by Viola Davis.... fears. She says they are not human.. but to Clooney that doesn't matter. Its his WIFE... albiet his dead wife.. but still his wife.
I wont ruin the movie any more just suffice to say that if you can get past the fact that there isn't much action in this movie and it actually makes you think, then Solaris is for you.The photography and set design are well done- especially the docking sequence special effects. Highly remeniscient of 2001 A Space Odyssey.

reviews.review_title: A little too deep for most of us (I give it a 10)
reviews.content: There weren't enough loud noises. Most people wouldn't know when or if they should be scared or happy. Basically, this needed to be a cheap science fiction novel on screen to get more people to like it. Good acting and beautiful sets just doesn't do it for most of us.

reviews.review_title: Snorelaris: Or How I Learned to Stop Taking Steven Soderberg Seriously
reviews.content: I had reasonably high hopes for this film even though George Clooney was the star.   Imagine my suprise when by the end of the film that Clooney's performance was one of the only things to recommend about this film.Mainly this film doesn't work for the same reason that A.I. was predominately awful:  Kubrick's cold cerebrealism and Spielberg's sappy sentimentality mix about as well as oil and water.   This movie pays homage to both filmmakers in a variety of ways (anyone who has seen 2001 and E.T., will have no problems picking out the most salient ones) to let everyone in the audience know that Soderberg knows perfectly well he's trying to create some sort of classic like 2001 or Close Encounters and not just "ripping" off Spielberg or Kubrick.  Unforunately the movie DOES come off as a fourth rate 2001: A Space Odyssey.  The ending, like the entire movie really, mixes the worst of both Kubrick and Spielberg by being vague and open ended on one side and sentimental and predictable on the other.  The combination...is well just plain awful.And one last thing.  If I have to sit through Clooney's ass not once, but twice, I at least expect his female counterpart to expose equal amounts of skin.Do yourself a favor and watch 2001 over again or even Gattaca.

reviews.review_title: What if the Creator is me
reviews.content: --Spoilers below--The popular theme of `I am God' is taken to extremes in Solaris. The movie depicts a world built upon a nihilistic point-of-view. In the absence of objective truth, humans are left with only their subjective perceptions and the entire life experience becomes an object of humanistic creation. Therefore, human existence lies within boundaries of the greatest aspirations and the basest desires, yet; the existence is constrained by the finite capacity of the human mind. The philosophy can be summarized as, `We cannot create anything greater than ourselves.'The corporeal visitors in Solaris come from the memories of a human host. Solaris seems to analyze dreams during sleep then creates the visitors based on those dreams and memories. The central character, Dr. Kelvin, experiences the Solaris effect via the visitation of his `resurrected' wife. She has been dead for years but Solaris creates her exactly as he remembers her-and therein lays the rub. As an extension of his memory she is more automaton than human. The familiarity of her physical appearance and social responses are comforting and intoxicating. Yet the overall experience lacks the lightness of spontaneity and serendipity. Dr. Kelvin becomes trapped in a `heaven' of his own creation.There are many other themes depicted in the movie related too this central theme. If you enjoy movies that require the audience to feel and think about what they feel--then see this movie.Best Regards, Darth87 December 2002

reviews.review_title: Not bad, not bad at all (minor spoilers)
reviews.content: I don't understand the other viewers' comments saying this was a horrible film. Yes, I was expecting more and for the story to go deeper than it did. Yes, there was some confusing plot elements (who was Gordon's visitor? how did the other scientist die? what happened to the security team that visited? what drugs was Snow on?!) that become even more confusing when you look at the filming script available online which diverges greatly from what finally appeared on screen. Despite that, the film raises some interesting questions about what would happen if our memories became embodied and developed their own consciousness...do they have a separate existence outside of our mind? Can they grow or develop beyond the confines of our perception of the past? The film could have been much more and although people here say it was boring, I was dying for another 1/2 hour to go more deeply into some issues...things were wrapped up too quickly and neatly for my tastes. Guess I'll be hunting for the original Russian film next!Parting words: Go see the film and make up your own mind. Considering how many really awful movies are made (Pluto Nash, The Hot Chick, Sorority Boys, etc.) calling this a "horrible film" is completely unwarranted. It may not be a "10" but it won't be a waste of your time.

If you've ever been so captivated by something that you can't understand how anyone could feel differently about it, you can relate to my affection for this movie.The situation that Kelvin (Clooney's character) finds himself in soon after he arrives at the Solaris station is a dilemma as compelling and emotional as anything I've seen in science fiction.The music is hauntingly beautiful.The actors are all excellent, including Natascha McElhone, who also happens to be gorgeous in an exotic, slightly unconventional way.I don't think there's a word spoken that rings false or feels unnecessary.The third act does not disappoint.There isn't much more I can say without giving away too much, and the truth is the less you know going in, the better. Just ignore Solaris' box office and watch the first 33 minutes of this film. If you aren't absolutely hooked, well, I guess I'll accept it, but I won't understand it.

reviews.review_title: Solaris is a disappointment for me
reviews.content:
I feel Natascha McElhone (Rheya) just wasn't convincing in herrole.  Natascha McElhone is a very, very fine actress, but I feel shewas miscast for the part.  It doesn't make sense why GeorgeClooney's character, Kelvin, would feel the way he does aboutRheya.  I certainly did not feel that way, and for the movie to work,McElhone has to give the audience emotional reason for Kelvin tofeel the way he does.  Well, McElhone did not do it, for me anyway.Too bad, everything else the movie has is a 10!  That is; the actingof George Clooney, Viola Davis, and Jeremy Davies is superb, theSteven Soderbergh direction is first rate .  .  it does not get anybetter, the ethereal feel to the movie was right on with the story lineand it is wonderful, the script was the best, and so on, and so on. 
I also did not care for the nudity in the film, I feel it takes away fromthe movies' integrity.  Otherwise a 10 rating, I give it a 5.  Too bad, I really wanted to likethis film.

The reviewer who said it needed a script was obviously not romantic.He was correct: George's butt not needed, except in the the first full length rear shot, as it was aesthetically superior.  Later ones were just George's butt.The problems of identity and what constitutes identity, the problem of suddenly existing and the usual effortless achievement of being that is one's birth, and is as the birth of self awareness were nicely demonstrated and dramatized. It was a study in learning how to love and the fulfillment of our cultural saw: true overs will be reunited after death. It was good.

"Solaris" is not a film for someone looking for straight science fiction. Sodebergh goes back to his European roots to present a film that is slow, but (with a little perseverance) ultimately rewarding. The plot unfolds at a leisurely pace, the atmospherics are brilliant, the lighting (which surely deserves an award) keeps one peering at the screen. The plot elements are not particularly compelling - the philosophical elements are. However, the script examines the latter in not enough detail. The themes of death, mortality and memory intertwine themselves, but never really manage to work their way into the script. This results in a film that is visually stunning but one that fears to tread further into the philosophical debate it commences. Perhaps Sodebergh felt his script was too highbrow and didn't want to alienate the broader swathe of viewers he thought he may otherwise attract. The result is a film which is neither traditional science fiction nor High Art. Nevertheless, it remains one of the more intelligent films I've seen emerge from Hollywood for some time.

Solaris being classified as a Sci-Fi movie was enough to keep me from seeing it until now and ultimately I only decided to visit the Science Fiction shelves due to my enjoyment of George Clooney movies. I can therefore report my surprise as to how much I have enjoyed this movie. Chris Kelvin is a psychiatrist who when introduced to us seems to have a very busy but emotionally dissatisfying life. He is compelled to visit a space station following a mysterious plea from a friend. When he arrives at Solaris he finds that his friend is dead and he begins to discover why the crew has had trouble leaving the space station. This story is set in a science fiction surrounding, but is very much a story about relationships. In one scene Chris tells Rheya that he is the right guy for her, but we soon discover that he fails her. Ultimately Chris wants to redeem himself by saving her when offered a second chance. The movie is very slow paced, allowing for great character development. Solaris is refreshing in that it leaves many questions unanswered. It does not force feed the viewer moral judgements rather it leads us to the question and allows us to explore our own thoughts.

WARNING!!! WHOLE SPOILER!!!!!!!!!!!!!
Well... I feel I just can't describe my feelings to tell you how BAD it is. It is so EXTREMELY horrible that I just hadn't an opportunity to watch the entire film. I was watching this in the movie and by the middle of a film there was a crowd of people leaving the theater, including me. Absolutely terrible. Awful. Stupid. Horrible. Moronic. Let me say disgusting. Nothing in comparison with Tarkovsky's cult Russian classic! Believe me - it's really bad. (Can't believe Soderbergh and Cameron made it!)P. S. Still, there are two good things in this movie - Natasha McElhone and Clooney's buttocks!!!

Not only was this the worst Sci-Fi movie that I've ever seen, it was also one of the worst movies of ANY genre that I've ever seen. When it comes to movies, I'm really not that critical and I think I'm fairly open-minded. I sincerely cannot understand how anyone could find a single redeeming quality about this movie -with the possible exception of someone that could benefit from video sales. It was awful. Nothing exciting or even remotely interesting happens in this film. Basically, a guy goes to space to figure out a "mystery". Unfortunately, he doesn't figure it out and then the movie is over. Now, maybe the film-makers simply ran out of tape before they could film the actual ending of this movie, in which case I'd really be interested in seeing it. All in all, this movie would not be worth watching unless someone was paying you to watch it. Don't buy it, don't rent it, don't watch it on cable or VHS or any other form of media. You will never be able to get the time back that you wasted watching this movie. The thought has crossed my mind that perhaps this movie was a tool used by psychologists conducting some kind of test. Maybe they were measuring how much money an obvious flop could generate on one actors fame, i.e. George Clooney. Or perhaps the for-mentioned psychologists were attempting to test the "emperor's new clothes" parable in modern times. For those of you not familiar with this story, let me make the analogy of a notable wine connoisseur saying that a glass of urine was actually an exquisite white wine. Then, said connoisseur waits for other wine connoisseurs to either be honest by saying the wine tastes like urine or to agree out of fear of not having a discriminating enough palette to detect how wonderful the wine really is. Speaking of urine, if I could urinate on the director of this movie, I would.
