99 minutes to let you breathe and then take your breath away...99 minutes to let you think about what do you really need to be happy: the truth, the fiction, the memory remains or maybe just a moment would be enough...99 minutes to let you get loose into a planet only inhabited by yourself as the music takes you by the hand to hide somewhere really far away...the music, ohhh the music...

'Solaris' does get lots of things right. It faithfully recreates the cold, lonely, brooding atmosphere of the remote space station, rendered in cold colours, bare metal and harsh, industrial background noise. The characters are well played with what little dialogue there is. The soundtrack is subtle and complements the feel of the film. The alien planet is beautifully rendered, in fact it's visually the most colourful and complex thing in the whole film, with pulsating colours and strange, wispy cloud formations.The reason 'Solaris' probably invokes such strong reactions is that it doesn't insult the intelligence with explanations, but leaves the viewer to fill in the gaps, of which there are plenty.My main criticism of it (as a 'mainstream art-house' film) is that it is possibly a little too slick. Everything about it is visually perfect, from the planet itself to the gratuitous, crowd-pleasing Clooney butt sequence. I would prefer to have seen a little 'Alien' style grubbiness, given the dysfunction of all the film's characters. This is scant criticism for such an ambitious project and I think Soderbergh has struck a happy medium between philosophical musing and a good old-fashioned love storyI also found that the sparseness of the film doesn't leave much to be savoured on subsequent viewings.Open your mind. 6/10

reviews.review_title: But come on, who knows what "love" really is?
reviews.content: Steven Soderbergh's adaptation of Stanislaw Lem's novel is quite interesting and compelling. His directing could have been greater but the work still lands in the charts of good film-making and adaptations from a classical novel to screen. What is most intriguing about this particular celluloid version of the book is that there is no character development. There is no sense of particularity in the characters. You can actually even doubt the very existence of life. And what about the wife of George Clooney's character? Does she exist or not? Who is on board on this space vessel? The answer is a self-exploration of a psychotherapist for the main character, the one that George Clooney with the direction of Soderbergh accomplishes successfully. Magnificent acting, not over the top but just right. But the answer still is a contradiction. The final message of the film itself is a contradiction and there is no definite end of the story, or a beginning in the same sense.During the film you kind of accumulate the feeling of knowing the different characters but in the end doubt their even existence. This is symbol of mankind's development, evolution, meaning of life if you may - self-perspective, self knowledge and understanding.It's deep, it's chilling, it's bizarre and makes no sense at some point, because it is dreamlike. The whole film sequences seem like taken bits from a dream. don't get me wrong, it's a well-organized, well-directed, acted out to perfection and with a great score but in the end it stays up in the air. You have to feel it to understand it. Sense it to comprehend it. Let go any logic whatsoever and just ask yourself - what do you fear and desire most?And up to the point of conclusion - Love? Noun, no explanation. It cannot be enforced and it's existence is a mystery. That's what the novel is about. If you know what "love" is, you shouldn't watch this movie. But come on, who really knows what "love" really is?

No spoilers...I have the urge to go off on a tangent about the fact that Lem's novel Solaris was written BEFORE 2001: A Space Odyssey so that people might think beyond the basic, but instead I'll just get to the movie.As for this version of the story itself, alas it's missing something.  Like motivation for Kelvin's actions.  Whether it is the screenplay's fault, or if Kelvin's motivations are edited out, his whole demeanor is not convincing from the limited backstory we are given to begin with.  Add to that the sloppiness of subplots left hanging (mentioned quite well in other comments) and you are left with something that *could* have been great, or even good but which just feels empty.  Clooney's work is very good for what he has to work with, and Jeremy Davies is quite together for the not-all-together Snow.  But again, with a flawed production there is only so much they can do.3 out of 10.

The more I see this movie the more I love it. The best DVD  buy, can`t stop watching. The music, the atmosphere, the story jjust does not leave you after you watch it. I went to see this movie with such high hopes; I like both George Clooney and mysterious space movies in general.  But I could tell after about 28 seconds that this one just wasn't a winner.  I felt something was missing. It was like suddenly I was just sitting on a perch attached to the ceiling of a house inhabited by some certifiably crazy deaf mutes.  There was no explanations, very little talking, hardly any music to back the movie up ... and I was like what the hey.  I could tell the other people in the theater felt the same way.  At one point mid movie an old man got up and left and didn't come back. These were my feelings for about the first half-hour.  After that you start to get an idea of what's going on, but it still isn't doing anything for you.  First there's a lot of silence, you're just watching people who are doing little more than breathing.  Then the flash back come, and boy, are these fun.  A lot of flowery music, a lot of pretty smiling faces, no rhyme or reason ... After about 45 minutes you realize why you've got this void in your stomache like something is just MISSING and you don't know what it is ... there is absolutely no excitement in this flick.  Even after you start to get the gyst of things, you're still waiting for the bomb to drop. It never does.  And the scenery reminds me of some sort of 60's space show -- just a little bit to white and silvery, a lot of wanna be high tech that serves little purpose. I don't want to ruin the end for you but when it finally comes, you're going to be both disappointed -- like, that's it? -- and relieved that the stupid thing is just over.  It's like a bad episode of Star Trek. I recommend this movie for those of you who like a little poetic license, because more than once (while fighting the urge to just take a nap) a thought to myself that this was like a bad poem put on screen.  I think if you liked What Dreams May Come then you'll probably like this one too. But it just in no way fills your desire for some thought provoking "whats going on in space today?" feelings.  I hate to do this, because I do love you George, but this one just doesn't cut it.  The highlight of the entire thing is getting to see Clooney's very nice behind.  Then just leave, and don't look back.  Trust me, you're really not missing anything.

reviews.review_title: Slow, thoughtful, stunning, but not for the action freak.
reviews.content: I am a total sci-fi freak so judge this text with that in mind. Being a sci-fi freak i am constantly looking for new deep explorations of future human society and technique. The ones that affect me are really rare these days. This one did.This is a film for the more deep-minded SCI-FI fans. If you are looking for a swift action flick, just forget about this one. The only blood you'll see is the trails of earlier happenings leading up to the events of this film. The slow, moody pace talks to them who likes to make journeys in the mind and not deep down some robot infested spacehulk.So what are the keepings of this film? Well... First of all the music was awesome. It gave the film the perfect framing and together with the "outdoor" scenes it created one of the most stunning sci-fi experiences you will ever get. Guaranteed.The science/technique (as in sci-fi) in this film is secondary, which is rare in sci-fi today, the film is almost completely held up by the explorations of human psychology.The cast really perform a very fine job with this one here. I have always avoided everything with "Clooney" on the front but this has made me reconsider although he is still far down on my list. Snow and Helen are perfectly casted. Where have they dug up these two anyways?I wish i would have seen this at a movie theater. The good thing was that i could rewind and see the scene where the shuttle arrives at the space station as many times that i wanted. Awesome feeling! The scenery is just too much for a man who lives to enjoy the few moments of true science fiction.Lean back, have a beer, turn the volume up and drift away - in space and in your brain...

I disagree with most of the comments regarding this particular film.  I thoroughly enjoyed "Solaris" and thought it was a well made, thought-provoking film.  The acting also, by everyone involved, was excellent.  An earlier commentator I think, hit the nail on the head when he/she remarked that it is NOT a film that the average cinema goer would enjoy (i.e. those people who don't want to have to think for themselves and who don't find a film entertaining unless the music is at a certain level, that special effects have to dominate in every scene and all that goes with the usual Hollywood rubbish that we're constantly being fed).  "Solaris" was disliked because it is DIFFERENT.  Strangely enough (or maybe it is not so strange), this film was received more favourably in Europe and elsewhere - in other words, outside of the US.  Maybe this says it all.

Heaven.  No, not the feeling that I got when I came out of the movie, but the overall theme for me.  But even though I did not feel heaven, I did find myself provoked to ask many questions, listen to many answers, and ponder them both.  Surprisingly this movie is gripping, especially with all the warnings people have put out to the impatient about being bored.  In comparison to many of the action packed crap put out today that is utterly more boring with their fiber thin plots and ambiguous reasons for creation this movie rises above the rest although it admittedly has a more methodical pace than most films, and I liked that.  It gave me time to appreciate the film before the credits rolled.The acting was superb, just superb around everything else.  A key line for me was paraphrased here, "There are no answers, just choices."  I was impressed and bought into Jeremy Davies character of Snow too, which may sound puzzling to many of you as it seems the majority feels he was an annoyance but I liked him.  Oh yeah, and Clooney and Mchelone were excellent as well, but I think there performances speak for themselves.Another thing that is almost necessary for a film to become one of my favorites is atmosphere, and this movie has it like a five star restaurant. There is just this feeling that is in the air, like it has jumped off screen and into the theater.  The ideas that are contained in this film, interpreted in any opinion, are truly refreshing and purely amazing from any point of view.  I would have to say as a gauge, if you liked AI there are a lot of similarities that would increase your chances of enjoying this movie as well.Not everyone feels this way, but the religious overtones standout in the film for me.  Whether it was intentional or not, or whether I added most of the overtones myself the planet Solaris itself carries more than just scientific weight.  And still more, there is a thoroughly convincing and deep character study about human relationships and the need for communication.  I especially enjoyed the scene where Clooney has a flashback of his wife and himself walking down the street, there was just something hauntingly emotional about it.  Steven Soderbergh should be commended, AGAIN!! for his continued drive to express something and his ability to make us think.  His vision and talent to the art form of film is something to be cherished.  I also found Cliff Martinez's score to capture each scene exquisitely and his music to be emotionally resounding.  Look for his next great score in Narc and his last great one in Traffic.And does anyone have a clue about the doorknob on the train?

If you see only one movie this millennium, this should be it. The premise is unprecedented; the execution is exemplary; the undertones are overwhelming. If this sounds like the type of movie you would like, free free to watch it (unless you live in America).

I found this movie to be excruciatingly boring.  Clooney  typically wooden and the plot terrible.  Sounds like they were shooting for a "Event Horizon" theme but failed miserably. Characters were obnoxious. Still trying to piece together this discombobulated attempt at a sci-fi. Have no idea what these people were thinking because the story is not fresh, holey, and dialogue retarded.  I guess the target audience was 13 year olds hence the pg-13 rating.  While i did pay $4.95 on pay-per-view so see this garbage, if i had seen this in the movie theater i would have walked out and demanded my money back. Just another example of the movie industry's greed just to throw some garbage movie out to make a buck.awful . . . .

reviews.review_title: Mis-marketed, misunderstood -- don't believe the snype, it's one of Soderbergh's best
reviews.content: It's weird! It's slow! It was badly marketed with two different messages, as, A: A spooky sci-fi film! and B: A romantic love story! Problem: it is both those things, but at the same time -- you know, like a Reese's Peanut Butter Cup. No wonder no one saw it, and the few who did were bitterly disappointed. What Solaris is, is a brilliant and moody art film that uses sci-fi and romance clichés (A, something bad is happening in a far off space station; B, I miss my dead wife so much my life is empty without her) to weave a profound and fascinating parable of how people create the realities they believe in, and how that leads to a (chosen, not inflicted) life of suffering, a cross to opt to bear. Stanislaw Lem, who wrote the book in the 1960s and who was profoundly influenced by quantum theory, has written that he didn't want to see this version because it so much focused on the love story between Rheya and Kelvin, but that just seems completely misguided. Why would the theories he is talking about not address love and emotion? These -- like reality, consciousness, space, time -- are among of the defining forces of human existence, and they are perfectly at home among these more expected sci-fi concepts. Indeed, the parallels drawn between the love/sci-fi genres are what make this film such a brilliant, unusual and engaging endeavor.Here's hoping Soderbergh releases an extended director's cut, with more of everything in it (including the enthralling footage of the planet and station, together with Cliff Martinez's beautiful score). He wanted it to be short; understandable, but it would work much longer as well.
