reviews.review_title: This is definitely one of Soderbergh's best films to date...
reviews.content: SOLARISSteven Soderbergh's (Ocean's Eleven, Traffic) latest film Solaris, is not only entertaining and astonishingly gorgeous, but it also touches on many deeper issues of humanity in a way that few sci-fi films have done as of late.  The film runs at a slightly slower pace than what most general audiences are used to, however, the highly introspective film has many pay-offs and is definitely worth the wait.This is Soderbergh's second remake of the past two years, adapting Andrei Tarkovsky's Russian-language masterpiece Solaris that won the Special Jury Prize at Cannes film festival in 1972. Chris Kelvin, (George Clooney) is called aboard an endangered American space station orbiting the planet Solaris.  Chris is told that there are many strange occurrences aboard the ship, which cannot be explained and that he is the only one who has a chance of remedying the situation. Once arrived, Chris finds the space station rather quiet and desolate, with one of the passengers' dead and the remaining two near psychological breakdown.  Dr. Gordon, a physiologist, and Snow, a tech-nerd, have seen and experienced things beyond what they know to be reality.  After close examination of both passengers, Chris has trouble believing their reports, until he too, has a similar experience of his own.  Manifestations of the past come to haunt Chris and he must decipher between what is reality and what isn't.This is definitely one of Soderbergh's best films to date, stepping away from mainstream Hollywood films, (Ocean's Eleven) as he does so well, and producing a great combination of both art and entertainment. This is very thoughtful film involving heavy subject manner, which is dealt with great delicacy.  Kubrick's 2001:A Space Odyssey comes to mind, both in terms of great visual style and content.

reviews.review_title: Had to register to leave this negative review to serve justice!
reviews.content: First of all, if the dear viewer has not seen the Tarkovsky 1978 film - watch it first for the sake of cinematography at the very least and hopefully to see that the movie is not about technical details as described in the "FAQ" section for 2002 version. 2. The presence of the song by ICP (Insane Clown Posse) early on in the film gave me a huge relief. It helped to not take the rest of it with such pain, since the movie does no justice to the novel or the Tarkovsky's version. Someone was either genius to give the hint that film is garbage just as rotten as ICP or it was made by people who aim for a cheap hit that would make a big buck "on the shoulders of giants". This film will never become a classic

reviews.review_title: Serious waste of time, money and film material
reviews.content: This movie was a serious waste.  It moved at a snail pace from the start and never picked up the pace. The story had the potential to be a really good one but the ending....correction....lack of ending totally killed it.  We walked from the theater looking at each other and asking "What happened?"On a positive note, the cast did a fine job with their characters.  It wasn't their fault the movie was terrible.

I cant believe some of the comments I have been reading here on Soderbergh's "Solaris". And I'm sure that those people who have called it an excellent cure for insomnia are the same people who make all the Arnold movies box-office blockbusters. But there is no accounting for taste; and one must be kind to the blind. For my money, however, the movie is one of the most "mesmeric" to have come out of Hollywood in recent years; and extremely uplifting in its message of redemption through love....a rare message indeed in today's dog-eat-dog world. Visually stunning, with a highly-appropriate sound-track and passionate performances from the taut cast of six, this is a fine example of the art of movie-making. While it wont make my list of the ten best films I have ever seen, it is certainly something I wont forget in a hurry....and will want to see again and again.

Two words to describe everything about this movie: painfully boring. I'm not even one of those people who needs action in films to enjoy them. There is simply no psychological or intellectual stimulation in this movie for the basic reason that it goes so slowly. If this had been a 30-minute TV show (think Twilight Zone) it would have been more successful. I suggest if you want to see this movie, just go and rent the original.

This is a great sci-fi film that touches on many subjects. It's unfortunate that many of the people I speak to about this film find it boring. However, I can understand how someone who approaches this film as a standard sci-fi space flick would be disappointed. It seems to me that, more often than not, when an average American film audience sees something it doesn't understand in a movie it seeks to dismiss it as garbage rather than looking harder into what themes or ideas are being explored. I think this is a criticism of the trash that regularly comes from Hollywood rather than of the American public.Despite the restraints of the Hollywood system, there are still good films trickling out, and Solaris is one of them. Solaris, like The Limey, deals mainly with the theme of time, memory, and how they affect the way we perceive our relationships with others. The main character in Solaris, like the main character in The Limey, is trapped in a situation where he is forced to look to the past and consider what went wrong and whether he is responsible, and if so, to what degree.The style of the film, and the fashback, flashforward organization of both films gives the viewer the feeling of experiencing the film in the past, present, and future simultaneously (isn't that how we all live our lives to some degree). It can be confusing, but for anyone who has been in a relationship with someone who is a little unstable this movie will be heartbreaking. Too bad some people don't get it. Maybe if they looked a little harder they could see what I see.

When i saw this film on the big screen I walked out after fifty minutes. I wasn't enjoying the film and felt confused.Six months later, realising I hadn't given the film a proper chance, I rented it and found it to be breathtaking and was unable to stop thinking about it. But this film isn't for everyone.Who should see this film? People who like good cinematography, atmospheric films with little plot. This film is a feast for the senses.Who shouldn't see this film? Somebody who is expecting to be shocked, scared or told what is happening in a film.The score which seemed so cold and distant to me on first viewing is also one of the best ever written, both enigmatic and thought-provoking.The fact that Clooney seemed to be slightly lost playing a character of this complexity and depth only served to enhance his character who himself feels vulnerable on board the space station.Soderberg is one of the best directors of the moment - if only he could stop working with Julia Roberts!

This was nothing more than 2001 Space Odyssey meets Blade Runner, just another Si-Fi flick! After looking at over 70 years of movies, it's hard to find anything new or really worth watching. In the 1940's before we had TV my mom bought a 16mm sound projector used, we would rent films on the weekend, the number of movies these eyeballs and this brain have seen is hard to measure. So this is why it's hard for me to find something that I can really like. Every now and then something will come along and for some reason I just love it, example "Blast from the past", I watch that one every chance I get when it comes on TV, and then there's Zack and Miri make a porno, I (LMAO) when that ones on, but you have to see it on one of the services otherwise they will chop it up to nothing.

Besides the big hype about George Clooney, the movie didn't live up to expectations. The story was dumb all the way through (regardless of any remake attempt), wanting to be a European art movie but not getting anywhere near. The best part of the movie were the scenes with "Snow" who stole the show from Clooney in my opinion.

I really wanted to like this film but the overall story made it too difficult.The acting was very good but the script was too weak for the actors to compensate.The film tried to delve into George Clooney's character's mental degradation because his deceased wife came back to life. However, he almost immediately accepted her presence and began to defy normal convention--and he was supposed to be a brilliant psychiatrist? Ultimately this movie suffers from lack of script and directorial planning, not from the acting.See this movie if you want, you'll walk away thinking there was suppose to be something more.Still, it is an intelligent effort and well-acted.

Thoughtful, intelligent and touching, Solaris demands some patience although ironically one of its failings is that it is too short! It is almost as if Steven Soderbergh realised that this movie wouldn't be to the taste of much of the cinema-going public and didn't want to try their patience.I have not read Lem's book, but I am lead to believe that it deals much more with the nature of Solaris itself and less with the relationship between the two leads. This relationship forms the major plot of the movie and this is something of a problem - we are left knowing nothing at all about the nature of Solaris or the nature of the intelligence that it contains. Perhaps this is also true of the novel. I would have liked much more to be made of the idea of this as a "first contact" situation - how would one cope if an alien intelligence chose to communicate in this way? Instead, the story is reduced to a "rationalism versus faith" parable in which a man confident in his objective, atheist view of reality is forced to follow his heart instead of his head to exorcise his past.That said, there is much here to enjoy. Natascha McElhone is perfectly cast as the mysterious Rheya. She is just utterly captivating whenever she is on screen. George Clooney plays George Clooney as usual, but turns in a competent performance. Viola Davis and Jeremy Davies are less effective - I can't help get the feeling that Davis was cast mainly because she is both female and black and they didn't want a stereotypical male, white physicist. As a scientist, the Gordon character seems awfully keen to want to destroy phenomena that are both extraordinary and unique - falling back on primitive fear instead of cool analysis.The enigmatic Solaris itself is beautifully rendered. Living up to its name it looks like a movie sequence from the solar SoHo probe studying our own star. Prominences and what could almost be cascades of alien, intelligent thought sweep across its surface. We're not even sure if it is supposed to be a star or a planet or an alien being. Coupled with the sparse soundtrack I found the Solaris object to be hypnotic. And surely it was intentional that it looks like a human ovum in that final shot?8/10

reviews.review_title: Sometimes, you should listen to the people leaving the previous show!
reviews.content: While waiting in line with my wife and four children, plus one girlfriend, we overheard quite a few comments from the people leaving the earlier showing. Nearly all were negative. One guy even looked over and shouted "run for your money back!" I was never one to listen to others comments, having liked a number of films that others hated. We entered, found seats (the theater would fill to near capacity) and settled in.The movie began, slowly, and slowed down from there. Myt wife and I kept saying, "It's got to get better." It never did. It was too long, to slow, and lacked interest. When it was over, we sighed and wondered aloud why we didn't get up earlier and sneak into a different theater. (it would not have been stealing, after what we paid to see that stinker) The acting was okay, the scenery was appropriate, the music good. It just dragged like a slug on a leaf. I have never been so anticipating an end of a movie before.My wife maintains that I'll watch any movie, regardless of content. She was right, till now. I will never view this movie again.Sorry to say, but this film has replaced all others on my "Worst Film Ever" list. I don't fault the actors, it wasn't their fault the story lacked any interest whatsoever.

reviews.review_title: too slow, no plot, no development
reviews.content: This thing is incredibly, agonizingly s l o w. In some places, the lines just take days to get out while the actors look very concerned. If it's trying to be Kubrick it fails. It's a full length movie with the plot and character development of a twenty minute short. I would skip it entirely and see Event Horizon which is the same thematic ballpark but excellent and riveting.

This film is a mess, don't buy it. It's not mentally challenging or confusing, just boring and tedious. What a waste of money, mine and the drongo who made it. It would have been far better spent doing 2061 (the sequel to 2010).

Ok, this was just a bizarre movie.  I generally like "slow, talking" movies, but this was too much.  There were people who left the theater during the movie, and the conversations by most after the movie involved "can we get our money back?".  The love story portion was touching, but it seems like it was buried.  There were also alot of unaswered questions.  Not a movie for me, that's for sure.

reviews.review_title: On Solaris, will she still not like his friends??
reviews.content: I guess spoilers.This visually cool movie touted as more emotional than philosophical. Problem is, like much of sci-fi, its examination of emotions & relationships is shallow, and well, kind of juvenile. A second chance has to be more than just a chance to do it over.  It has to be a chance to have more understanding, and from that change.  So how did they go from starry-eyed romance to such coldness?   No one comes to understand anything any better; and the guys a psychologist!Sure hope there are marriage counselors on Solaris.

I tend to believe that movies should be judged on whether or not they accomplish what they set out to achieve. Consequently, When it comes to an adapted screenplay, I think one should try and determine what the Director and/or writer had in mind and then ask "did it work?" Well I may be breaking my own rule now, I have to admit that I don't know what was intended with this movie, beyond trying to make a film out of the novel Solaris. As a result, I can only conclude that they failed. The movie is far from awful, and movies (being the subjective beings they are) can be wonderful or otherwise, depending on the viewer. While I can understand and appreciate people loving this movie for whatever it is, it misses the mark completely when attempting to convey anything that Lem had in mind when he wrote the book. One might say that everything present in the book is in the movie, and this is essentially true, but content isn't all. The book is structured to give the reader a realistic sense of what a truly alien encounter might be like, but the film glazes over this and seems to focus on something else (to be honest, I'm not entirely sure what). Without trying to undermine anyone's interpretation of the movie, I must say it really isn't Sci-Fi at it's best and fails to give any meaningful insight into the infinite possibilities of the genre. Skip this if your a fan of the book or of Sci-Fi in general. See it if everything I just said means nothing to you.

Personally, I have nothing wrong with movies that have no action, so had no problem watching the first few min of solaris. Well, to me it looks like nothing happened. Lets try again, another few min. No, still nothing. Personally, I admit that I may have missed the "Cruicial Element of the Movie" in those few min, but if it was there, it would only be there for the most attentive viewers.Solaris drove me to a state of madness where I continually fast-forwarded parts of the movie trying to figure out what was going on. The end scene said it all, what I originally took as flashbacks from a clinically depressed guy appeared to be in correspondence to reality, and what you really have is a love story with a sub story embedded inside.This type of movie would have been better left to story. To those who disagree try actually reading. A book can offer a more driving story then a movie can, it can better reflect on the emotional aspect because words can touch multiple senses. In that regard, the emotional transition between the movie and yourself would be better facilitated in words then by sights and sounds.

reviews.review_title: Can Clooney smile without forcing it?
reviews.content: A solid attempt at energizing the "been there, done that" of science fiction lore.  Soderbergh might have started a road to revival in the genre of Stanley Kubrick without Stanley Kubrick.  Clooney shows anguish and pain far better than he shows happiness, satisfaction, or pleasure, so he was perfect for the role.A 6 out of 10, with considerable room for improvement.

reviews.review_title: Honestly, no idea how it got such a high score
reviews.content: I'd watch any genre of films, as long as it's a quality film. Solaris isn't that, wonder how could anyone score it higher than 5, boring, mundane and the whole movie could fit in 10 minutes rather than hour and a half.

Typical "intelligent" film from Hollywood. How come it seems that Europeans do these types of films much better? Movie had some strange mood in it, but mainly of stillness. Leave out action and violence add mystical music, but don't change anything. There's a way to make "psychological" hollywood-flicks. Anyway 7-/10(maybe the absence of small-talk confuses some American directors) I'm not arguing that it's always the case.

reviews.review_title: Lonely and lost out here in the stars (very minor spoilers)
reviews.content: Solaris is a throwback to the kind of film that Hollywood made for a time in the 1970s, but hardly makes anymore.  Although movies from the genre of sci-fi/fantasy have dominated the pantheon of blockbuster movies, this is not one of them.  Solaris is more like the anti-blockbuster; its commercial prospects are grim.  It's being marketed as science-fiction/romance film, but fundamentally it's about the human condition, guilt, regret, forgiveness, loneliness, the existence (or non-existence) of God, and our attempts at connection with our fellow travellers.  It reminded me of the Kurt Weill song "Lost in the Stars" about how we were created by God, but He's left us, abandoned us to drift in space.We find out during a dinner party, that the lead character, Chris Kelvin, is an atheist and doesn't believe in God.  Human relationships should be very precious for people like him, because once it's over, once you're dead, that's it.  A lot of believers are comforted by the prospects of being reunited with your loved ones in an everlasting afterlife.  Chris Kelvin doesn't have that luxury.  The movie suggests that human relationships are very fragile and also touches upon the fundamental impossibility of really knowing another person.  The best we can really hope for is knowing ourselves.  But we should try our best to look past ourselves and get out there and make connections, to alleviate our loneliness, and not take them for granted.  After he threatens to leave his wife Rheya in a fit of rage, she commits suicide.  Many Christians believe that suicide causes your soul to be lost and damned.  So whether God exists or not, Chris and Rheya are pretty well screwed.  One of the taglines for the movie is "How far will you go for a second chance?"  Well, if you're Chris Kelvin, I'm guessing pretty damn far.I found Solaris to be similar to these movies:Vertigo (romantic illusions and not really knowing another person)Last Tango in Paris (as above, plus the suicide angle)A.I. Artificial Intelligence (meeting your maker, redemption, mortality)Blade Runner (as above)The Remains of the Day (regret, loneliness)If you liked any or, better yet, all of the above films, the chances are good that you'll appreciate Solaris.  If you hated those movies, Solaris is not for you.  This film is one challenging piece of work, "slow" and filled with "intellectual" themes and may bring out uncomfortable feelings.  If you're looking for action, don't go to Solaris.One of the year's best. (9/10)

reviews.review_title: A thoughtful sci-fi movie, creepy, but without horror (spoilers)
reviews.content: Solaris is a strange, beautiful world, remote from Earth, which is being investigated by a survey team to assess its economic potential. However abnormal occurrances have plagued the team including the suicide of the team leader and the appearance to the crew of persons from their past experience, who cannot possibly be physically present (some are known to be dead) in the survey ship.Enter psychologist Chris Kelvin (George Clooney), charged with dispeling the problems/"hallucinations", only to be beset by them himself in overwhelming measure when his dead wife appears, not once but twice (the first he ejects from the ship in an escape pod).The presence of physicist and hard rationalist Gordon (Viola Davis) does much to prevent the crew (and plot) from disintegrating into a babble of mumbo-jumbo mysticism. There are no detectable psychotropic agents which could be causing the crew to imagine these occurances. The beings rather, are constructs from the memories of the persons who knew them, created somehow by Solaris itself. As such, they are what the person who knew them thinks they were, rather than the original person. But very real enough. They exhibit an almost indestructibility (if injured or killed, they shortly self-resurrect), though Gordon develops a method of dispelling them using exotic radiation.While all understand with their minds that the appearance of these beings is undesirable ("What if this was to spread to Earth" screams Gordon), emotion overwhelms reason and Kelvin is determined to hold onto this remnant of his wife, however imperfect. There are tense moments between Gordon and Kelvin.The ending is anti-climactic and enigmatic. It is Gordon who makes the decision to return to Earth carrying the rest of the crew with her (they seem incapable of any making any significant decisions). The crew don't fall into a senseless slaughter of each other, nor do the beings suddenly turn hostile. In the deja vu sequence near the film's very end, Kelvin finds himself on Earth and cuts himself (again) while preparing a meal. While attending to the wound, he is arrested by the sudden appearance of his wife. He asks, "Am I alive... or dead?" She assures "We don't have to think like that anymore. We're together now. Everything we've done is forgiven. Everything." They fall into a long, clinging embrace which dissolves into the image of Solaris, now very reminicient of an embryo.

Solaris is a beauty to watch, and holds your attention with its apprehensive tone. Starting as a sci fi movie and crossing over into horror before submitting itself to a love story, Solaris uses multiple genres as tools for creating an overall emotional response to the storyline.Attempts to easily define this film will lead to frustration and possible irritation with the film itself- Comparisons to '2001' are unfair:  "2001" was resolved with sheer sci-fi wonder - that took place in an almost inhumanly cold and detached narrative. "Solaris" is the sum of such wonder coupled with a love story, and a deeply internal treatise on some difficult to answer questions. Some have accused it of being slow, and despite the repeated use of slow, still shots of the stillness of the space station, the film is only an hour and a half, and solves its first mystery in 20 minutes.This answer to the question, "What's going on at Solaris?" only provokes mutliple new questions, some of which are unravelled by the movie's end. Even if as a viewer you don't hang on every shot you'll be more than occupied thinking about the significance of the ideas presented, and providing answers where there simply aren't any. Repeated viewings rewarded. I usually don't dig films like this. Ebert's review is dead on.

SPOILER!! This movie presents that well worn chestnut of a storyline: boy meets girl, boy loses girl, boy finds girl again in the heart of a weird pink planet in deep space. I mean how many times have we seen that? It's practically a genre in itself.

reviews.review_title: The movie tries to be intelligent and thoughtful, but in that it fails
reviews.content: It is highly amusing to see how this movie polarizes the critics on IMDB. Other critics were bored to death, others seem to have loved it. I  will take a more balanced approach.In my opinion, the movie could have been much more but some clear flaws make it mostly incompatible with the expectations of most people. Also the advertising and trailers made me believe I would see something much better than this movie actually delivered.The visual appearance of the space station orbiting Solaris (the planet or neutron star or whatever that may be) is great. This was definitely somewhat inspired by Kubrick's 2001. However this image is used too often in this movie. The soundtrack is unconventional and fits the mood and slow pace of this movie.Unfortunately the plot development is truly banal and in many aspects unsatisfactory. Here I have to agree with those critics who found those movie boring and uninspired.We get to see Clooney enter a space station where people have previously gone mad. Some committed suicide, others have been murdered. Obviously there have been violent fights on this space station. This is a promising lead-in and setting, similar to the movie "Event Horizon".So the audience is led into expecting a continuation of this violent theme. But there is no continuation of this. Not at all. So why did the movie show us bloodstains in the first place?There is only very few surprises in this movie. One being that everyone on the station is haunted by a mysterious visitor created by Solaris. This mysterious visitor is a construct of every person's most intense memories. So our antagonist's beloved wife reappears in physical form. By means of flashbacks and dream sequences the audience learns that his wife is long dead because she had committed suicide years ago.This unnatural visitor acts human and even experiences human emotions herself - yet she cannot possibly be human because there is no rational explanation for her existence. Also when she gets injured or killed she magically heals or reappears hours later. Slowly realizing that she is not a true human being she is getting desperate and suicidal.Still the antagonist played by Clooney misses his wife so much that he decides to embrace and accept that thing which looks like his wife. And all that is neither particularly credible nor logical. At the end of  the movie you will keep asking yourself "Why? I don't understand this character. I don't see why he acted this way.".The other two remaining characters living on this space station hardly contribute to the plot development. This movie could have delivered so much more if this story had not focused so much on the banal love story element. The director should have replaced the banality with a bit more suspense, mystery and maybe some violence. Catering for the audience's expectations is a bare necessity: Either deliver what people expect or present the unexpected! This movie does neither.The movie tries to be intelligent and thoughtful, but in that it fails. All that remains is a terribly slow pace where people actually expected to see some terrible mysteries revealed. Overall the movie presents no answers to a lot of open questions.  I don't see how this movie got funding in the first place and was marketed like this - given the uninspired script.Rating: 4 out of 10.

reviews.review_title: thoughtful visual film - oh and it's got George Clooney in it!
reviews.content: Solaris,Well I had no preconceived idea of this film - just I like Sci Fi and I like George Clooney so it should be good.I liked the film and enjoyed it visually. It is as people are describing it as "Slow" but that's not a bad thing. Slow is good - if the film calls for it, and it does. I felt slightly irritated by some of the editing - I mean the scene with George Clooney's butt - What the hell was that in aid of?It wasn't artistic it was just daft! Anyway I didn't let that spoil the film. The film unfolds slowly and methodically posing questions along the way - flashing back to his past life while he sleeps. The whole film is dreamlike.As for the Acting well George is great and does well. Jeremy Davies is awful and frankly let's the whole film down. Whenever he's in a scene he overacts and is painful to watch. The other actors do so well - how the hell did he get into the cast?I must say when it ended I didn't have that open question on my mind that I've had when watching "2001", "The Shining", "Jacobs Ladder" You know the feeling I'm on about - I know exactly what the film was striving for but sadly it didn't quite hit the spot. Not a bad try though - certainly worth seeing.Artistically and directorial are both done to a very high degree. This was not the problem - it's a little like the storyline of the film. It seems to have lost some of it's soul in the memory of the film!I didn't want to be too negative as these types of films should always be encouraged and made. For this it gets a higher mark from me. Anybody trying to break from the norm of Hollywood deserves full credit.Go see it - make your own mind up.7/10Russ

Solaris is slow and pointless, but full of painfully long scenes and confusing plot points.What else can I say. Steven Soderbergh attempts to turn an interesting idea into a 2001 style film. Unfortunately, throwing together a bunch of slow scenes and mystic images does little to make a great film.None of the actors involved are that bad, in fact, I felt them struggling through the material to try and pull it off. I am not a huge Clooney fan, but I felt that all involved gave it their best. The DVD even alludes to the fact that the actors did not understand what Soderbergh was doing, but trusted that it would be great. If you are still interested in this film, I suggest staring at a rock for 99 minutes as a good warm up to how it feels to watch this film.

When someone sits down to watch a movie, there are usually always expectations before it begins, I mean it's difficult not to have them. Critics and friends have opinions that can help shape our expectations of a movie and sometimes the title alone can give off connotations that put you in a certain mindset about the film. Solaris is science fiction and this genre of film probably lends itself to the most preconceived ideas of what a movie should deliver so it's no wonder so many people were disappointed. Solaris would definitely get full points for set design, acting & mystery but it is not an action movie nor is it an `effects' movie, although the effects that it did have were well done. I would classify Solaris as a 'thinking' movie. Considering myself a true sci-fi fan, I very much enjoyed Solaris, although I'd heard it was boring, I still wanted to see it and knew what I was getting into. That being said I thought it was great. I particularly liked the performance given by Viola Davis who played Gordon, she gave such solid believability to the role that it makes me want to see other films she's done.

I should point out that I didn't see the whole film - I only caught the second half. But what I saw was extremely intriguing. Two things in particular struck me. First, the pace, and accompanying music; it's a film that creeps over you at an invisible pace, and the hypnotic music does a lot to keep you sitting there. As said by other users, the pace we're used to in films, particularly sci-fi - crash, bang, wallop, atomic explosion - makes Solaris a challenge until you settle into it, but the mesmerising, haunting music has a way of fixing you where you sit, while the film's essence seeps into you.Second, the film's interesting exploration of ideas about reality: the reality of the world and people around us, and of ourselves; the part our memories play in defining and historically preserving reality and the form of our lives. It's not a theme that could have been well explored in a sensational, typically 'Hollywood' film; the effect would have been crass and not a little superficial. The pace of Solaris - what I saw of it, at least - allows one to think about the ideas present while the film slowly unfolds. A line towards the end - I don't know if it constitutes a spoiler but I'll assume it does - particularly intrigued me: "I performed all the millions of gestures that constitute life on Earth. But I was haunted by the idea that I remembered her wrong... that I was wrong about everything." It's a film that takes patience and concentration, and rewards you with moving, understated performances, a feeling of quiet unsettlement, and hours of afterthought. I'd like to see the entire thing... as well as the Russian original, and Lem's novella.

Spoiler!What if we sent a ship out and parked next to heaven?  In a cocktail party conversation, the protaganist and his friends don't seem to have a grip on what is the afterlife, except that it doesn't exist, which is a cop-out. Gordon, the main scientist left on the ship, is fighting crossing over to heaven, but our hero, Kevin, finally embraces it.  The final scene is of Kevin and his wife in heaven, as conceptualized by the author.  All is forgiven.  Lovely space philosophy; I'm glad to see mysticism in science fiction.  I plan on viewing the 1972 original Solaris.  Ain't those Russians contemplative!?!

reviews.review_title: What did this movie remind you of?
reviews.content: Spoiler alert!I read the book by Stanislaw Lem and it is a real heavy-duty sci-fi book. He gets lost in long sections of scenery and techno-babble but forgets about the "heart" of the movie.  This story is so character driven - and to call it a "romance in space" is no insult.  The movie is better than the book because of what Lem doesn't do, and Soderbergh does do.Rheya - Natascha McElhone's character - finally realizes she's not a real person but a "creation" of the sentient planet Solaris.  She committed suicide years ago and the planet creates her from Chris Kelvin's (George Clooney) memories.  The heart of it all is that she says to Chris that she is suicidal because that is how she remembers herself.  The great wisdom in the movie is when he realizes that he remembered her wrong, though he never stopped loving her.The great twist that they add to the movie is that Snow (Jeremy Davies) isn't a real person but a "creation", and right from the start of the movie there are little clues to it.  Sort of like "The Sixth Sense" but you only see it after you've seen the whole movie.  This one bit just blew me away.This movie is great - even for those who never read the book - and I think it would have had better reviews if it hadn't been George Clooney.  He's good, but the story really is the winner here.10 out of 10.

reviews.review_title: Had potential but is let down by a dull and tedious pace
reviews.content: MINOR SPOILERSThe premise for Solaris is an excellent one. This is a futuristic science fiction scenario (something I am always attracted to) directed and readapted (this is a remake I believe) by Steven Soderbergh who has been on a excellent roll with the great films such as Erin Brokavich, Traffic and Ocean's Eleven. George Clooney stars as Chris Kelvin, an astronaut/scientist who has lost his wife, Rheya played by Natascha McElhone (Ronin, The Truman Show).The film begins with sad, depressed Clooney struggling to carry on in life without her. As the film continues, he regularly has happy dreams of being with her. Eventually, he is called up to travel to and board a space station orbitting some distant yet eerily beautiful planet called Solaris where he has to investigate some strange phenomena. When he finally gets there, he discovers that not only are the crew experiencing apparations of their own past and memories but so is he, of his wife. As baffled and surprised as he is, he tries to come to terms with what is happening. Are the crew hallucinating? Is Solaris inducing these hallucinations? Are they hallucinations at all or are they real beings mirroring their memories? Clooney tries to consider all these question with the crew while at the same time getting reaquainted with his wife and trying to right the wrongs of the past.However, a quarter of the way through the film, I just couldn't care anymore. The film wasn't that long (about 1 hour 30 min) but it seemed much longer. The film is beautifully shot with some nice set and FX, and the score is soothing and appropriate for the film. The acting is adequate. I particularly like quirky, oddball scientist, Snow played by Jeremy Davies (Saving Private Ryan). But these are the only merits I can honestly bring up. I was bored, really bored, watching this film. It dragged on and on with slow, dreamy flashbacks of Clooney and McElhone. I tried to believe that there was actually a point to the whole film, some explanation of the unexplainable. Questions are raised such as the meaning of life, religion and the universe mixed up with a story of love, loss and redemption but I could not find any answers. Although I usually like McElhone, her character somewhat annoyed me with her whining and mood swings and, well, she seemed to be so boring and an effort to spend time with and so I couldn't really see anything attractive about her. I find that her character actually lends strength to the dullness I experienced. On the whole, I regard this film a bit of a mess with no direction or purpose. The sci-fi distant planet setting is simply a background for this story which could easily have been set in any place where weird things happen (ie. a spooky archeoligical dig). Whenever technical jargon is mentioned it feels like it was ripped off some Star Trek TNG episode. I get the feeling that it was trying to match the mystery (if not the grandeur) of 2001: A Space Oddessey which is also another long, slow sci-fi film with mysterious goings on but on the contrary is actually captivating and revelating.I may be wrong though. Perhaps there are explanations or answers somewhere in there but I was too bored by then to care and I couldn't be bothered to think about the meaning of the film as I usually do with other films that aim to stir thought and intelligent discussion. Soderbergh, an excellent director, has misfired on this one and no amount of special effects, cast quality or score is really going to compensate for the tedium he has presented us with. Disappointing really as I was rather looking forward to this one.Overall Rating 5/10

i have seen bad movies and then there is Solaris. this is the most boring film i have ever seen. the plot falls flat on its face. the theme stinks. there are parallel plots/themes/and story lines running that never reach a resolution. what led me to rent it? i heard that this movie was done in 'kubrick style'; and i love kubrick movies, so i gave it a shot. what an insult to stanley! stale stale stale! i've seen 80's movies that didn't bore me this much. by the end of the movie, i was dumbfounded with the fact that only an hour and a half had passed, and yet i felt as if i had sat there for 3 hours.

reviews.review_title: Soderbergh channels Kubrick and pulls it off!
reviews.content: Solaris is one of those great, true Sci-Fi movies that most people who believe they love Sci-Fi will hate. Because they usually associate the genre with heavy action scenes loaded with explosions and the like, these fans will walk away from this movie wondering what just happened to the 90 minutes they spent in the theater and will review it to their friends like a bad Action movie instead of a great Sci-Fi movie.The movie itself is gorgeous and set at the same quiet pace usually found in Kubrick films - slow, controlled, and mysterious with touches of eerie music in the right places to cue the audience into a change.  I can see already how some of my fellow reviewers, even those that do this professionally, will walk away claiming that is boring or confusing, when in fact it is one of the more simple Sci-Fi movies I've ever had to explain.The thing you have to ask yourself at the end is, would you go as far as the main character did to be with the one he loves?I give it an 8 out of 10.  See it on the big screen to get the best effect.

reviews.review_title: Either love it, if tune into it,
reviews.content: Or you will hate it, if you don't catch its wave. As for me, it stirred me up to the bottom of my soul. Good test: if you didn't like "A.I.", don't bother going.In some movies knowing the plot ahead of time spoils everything. Here enjoying the movie without knowing the plot ahead of time would be a serious impediment (I was lucky to have red Stanislav Lev story beforehand). I can imagine myself watching this movie over and over, and definitely plan to buy it on DVD when it is out.This movie made me think what is real in life and what is not, what is of value in life and what is not, what is a true life, what does it mean to be human, if there is anything after death - then what, what is God, etc. The multitude of themes subtly collide at the unusual angles under the surface of the seemingly slowly developing movie, which makes it difficult to get into. But if you will get into it, you may end up thinking about it - and about values in your life - for a long time, finding source of strength and inspiration.Most people in the theater hated it. I think it is one of the movie you hate the 1st time around and love more and more with each consequent time. The tempo, presentation, polyphony of the plot - everything is so unusual, that the ideas of the movie may go "under the radar screens" when you watch it the 1st time around

Have an open mind going into this one! It's fantastic but you've got to be thinking -- don't expect explosions, sex, and violence. This is a thinking person's film.It will leave you questioning reality for weeks!GO SEE IT

As a big fan of the original book I thought this had so much promise to be a true classic, bringing sci-fi and philosophy of the mind together. But I was greatly disappointed, feeling only that a great opportunity had been missed out on. While the book had a hidden depth of discussing human perception and belief, the film seemed to gloss over this, focusing rather more on the love interest, which to me(in the book) was a path for a more philosophical look at human belief. How can we believe what we see? can we truly understand our universe, or will it always remain a mystery to us?Read the book, it will tell you more than the film(and is also a damn sight faster no matter how slow you might read :P )

On a "college art and cinematography student final project" level, this film succeeds in raising a little curiosity. The only saving grace is the soundtrack. (And possibly, Natascha McElhone, if she is your type. . .)The film is reminiscent of 2001, Sphere, Event Horizon, etc. without the clarity of direction of the former three.The trivia section of the IMDb page for this movie says that this version is an hour shorter than the original. That missing hour must contain the plot.I didn't like it after the first 10 minutes. I guess I should have left (returned it to Blockbuster) as Soderbergh suggested.Maybe he should offer a rebate for watching this turkey.

reviews.review_title: It's a shame that more people don't stop to smell the roses
reviews.content: This is NOT the sort of science fiction action film that has made the genre popular with the masses, it is the sort of science fiction film that makes the genre complete - about people dealing with the world around them and coming to grips with the universe that we are stumbling around in.  THANK you to the film makers and to George Clooney who delivered a solid performance in this off-beat yet thought-provoking love story.

reviews.review_title: What in the world is going on here!
reviews.content: Straightforward opinion - this movie is a complete waste of time - I spent the first 45 minutes trying to figure out what in the world was going on while people began to walk out after 20, and the remaining duration of the movie, trying to keep myself from being bored to death! This is one of the worst made movies that I've seen in a long time with a plot that seems to have no direction, no noticeably decent score, and an immensely depressive presentation. If you're thinking about watching this movie, your time is definitely better spent elsewhere!

I watched this pretty much straight after watching 'The Hours' so that may be the reason I did not find Solaris as boring as many of the comments previously have mentioned. It's a pretty cute film that tries really hard to be clever but without being cheesy. It asks a few questions of life that make you think... Theres a lot of questions unsolved in regards to the plot which are slightly annoying, might reveal more in the book I guess.
Overall 6/10

When I was young and had teeth, one of the things I used to dread the most was a trip to the dentist. If I was to write synopsis of my dentist visits, I think it would be very similar to a synopsis of this film, to wit:Pay someone my hard earned money, followed by lots of waiting, interspersed with short painful periods of activity. If I was lucky enough to get gas and air, then I might be treated to a nice colourful light show.To fully convey the ennui and entropic crawl of this film I need to use the ancient Japanese poetry form, haiku.First nothing happens Something happens to Clooney Then nothing happensBasically the film poses some "interesting" philosophical questions, by interesting I mean dull.Personally I think I would feel quite freaked out if I was making love to my dead wife, for a start I'd wonder how she got out from under the patio.If you're tempted to watch this film, maybe you would be better off making a visit to your dentists, maybe for a nice polish, or gum clean.On the dentistometer this is Root canal treatment.

I think that this movie is masterpiece for the eyes. The whole concept is visual based. It is just so unique. I want to see it twice! I think that a closer look at the film is profitable. Don't blink, you might miss something vital to the plot. Very well done Mr. Soderbergh. It has been a pleasure supporting you, as it always has been!

quite simply the most boring film in the history of films. i would rather eat my own eyes than watch this film again. in fact i already scratched half my arm off in frustration while the movie was on. if you are a geek and enjoy watching paint dry, this film is perfect for you. if you prefer to watch a film and not have to worry about falling asleep, stay far away and never even think of this film. the most exciting thing to happen in this film is someone shouting at another person. it starts off OK, with the film building some suspense. however this goes nowhere, and you end up shouting at the screen for something to happen. the acting is lousy and no way George Clooney's best. the story line is just too plain as well. you have to watch George Clooney (who i think is is every single scene in the film, so you start getting fed up with him) as he starts having hallucinations with the rest of the crew of the ship he explores.how long can you sit and watch someone else seeing something that isn't there. this is only my opinion and you may actually enjoy it as others have, but this is probably unlikely since you can have just as much fun poking a cardboard box with a stick for 2 hours. you have been warned.

Very cerebral.  Begs the question of where reality lies within the conscience. Moody, atmospheric cinematography and decent acting and direction, albeit, slow-paced. If you're into a 2001-like movie that doesn't tie up all the loose ends, give it a try. I liked it, and recommend it.

First off I must say that this film was exactly what I thought it would be. A love story set in space with elements if sci/fi. What I didn't expect was the minimalist approach to the material. There is little talking, and even less musical cues to tell us what we should be feeling. In fact I think that this is one of the least manipulative films I've seen and that is what I really appreciate about it. So many films rely on a sweeping soundtrack and flowery emotional speeches in an attempt to manipulate the audience into artificially 'feeling' something. Not in this version of Solaris by Steven Soderbergh, and it's all the better for it in my opinion. This doesn't make it an emotionless affair. There are strong emotions here, especially for the Rheya/Kelvin characters. But in this case, we are seeing those emotions possibly like the planet Solaris would see and interpret them, in a detached yet fascinating kind of way.As the film progressed I became aware that, with the exception of the Jeremy Davies character, these people were acting in a very real, humanistic way. When you are deeply troubled and in emotional pain the first instinct is to hide it from everyone else. If someone asks us how we are doing today, the automatic response is usually "pretty good" even though we may feel the exact opposite. But, if we bottle those feelings long enough, others can begin to see the cracks in the facade. We start to look tired and empty. We may become irritable and withdrawn. This is how the characters in the film are. Carrying around their personal demons while trying to put up a good front.But Solaris apparently can see right through them. Is it toying with them, or trying to understand and sooth their pain by externalizing it and encouraging them to work through it? What is Solaris? Benevolent alien intelligence? A metaphor for the mind of god? A phenomena that, simply by it's own nature, mindlessly mirrors and reflects our deepest desires and regrets? In the end we are left to decide for ourselves. There may be no wrong answer as the movie is rich in symbolism and allegory which leaves it very open to different interpretations.I have a feeling that a second viewing might illuminate a great many things. All in all a very satisfying cinematic experience far from the usual hollywood sensibilities when taken on it's own and not compared to the book or the other Tarkovsky film.

I just can't understand why people have so much anger towards this movie. If you look at the voting graph, there's a huge peak at the bottom score 1. I guess these voters are the baseball-capped teenagers who waited the whole movie for Van Damme to come smash some faces in. Or Eminem beamed up to the spacecraft to write a rapsong about Solaris. Nowadays, a movie without a gunfight, drug use or pornography is worth nothing, I guess.
For me the movie was an unbelievable experience, where the set design, lighting and the music combined with fine acting of Clooney and McElhone formed an unbelievable eery atmosphere. One of the best movies ever. A true classic.

reviews.review_title: Give it a try, but do not expect much.
reviews.content: I did not see the russian version of Lem's novel, so I thougth it is a good chance to experience how someone else see Solaris. It was not. As for Solaris "himself", you see a planet of blueish light effects from afar (the novel takes you to the surface of Solaris), with absolutely no detail. As for the story, you get a love-story instead of something you can interpret the way you like. As for the ending, it has nothing in common with Lem's vision. And on top of all, it is a (very) boring movie. The novel itself does not contain much action, but when the makers of the film took the negligible side story and made it the main plot... everything gone awfully boring. And I have to tell you: Solaris isn't evil (or something like that), as you might feel in the end; and nobody knows what's "his" goal, but surely it isn't to make someone (or everyone) happy...If you want to watch a love-story in outer space, then give it a try, but if you want to watch a sci-fi movie, look somewhere else.

A nice try to compose between Solaris of Lem, Tarkovskiy and "Master and Margarita" of Bulgakov (I am talking about "All we've done is forgotten" phrase that sends me straight to Bulgakov' ending idea of "Master&Margarrita" novel). I am sure that You will enjoy this film more not seeing Tarkovskiy's one before. After all, I do not understand why Stanislaw Lem was angry with Tarkovski after the last one did his version of "Solaris"?

I don't care if it's a fierce remake. It's a very boring, dull, and dreary movie. I tried to enjoy myself, but it was hard to when all that was going on was sex scenes. First of all, the relationship between Chris Kelvin and Rehya is the weakest romance I've ever seen. It started off with them having sex, and then they talk on the streets. It describes the couple metaphorically, but I just didn't see a love their. Why did Chris push her off in space anyway? Also, Solaris. What is it? Nothing made any sense in this movie. Alive peoples bodies dead on the ship. Like it made sense. The planet is Solaris. But why did they make this? If they are doing it for sentiment then they didn't get anything in response. It was lively, but was senseless. It was very slow. Deliberation was slow and very pacing. It's very uneven. It wasn't confusing; I just want to know what Solaris did. But what was its purpose? It obviously did something to create a memory person. But how. The reason why I mostly hate it is because there are too many unanswered questions. And the whole premise and idea of Solaris is just dumb, not beautiful.

*****MILD SPOILERS AHEAD (not about the end though)****After having been through most comments posted here, I'm not really surprised to realize that, while some people loved the movie, some found it boring, to put it mildly.First, let me put it bluntly: I loved this movie. But depending on the mood the day I first saw it, I feel like I could have found a better way to spend my time. The line between the two feelings being a thin one.There are undeniable qualities to this movie: first, the music. I hadn't heard an original music that fit so well the movie since Requiem For a Dream. But unlike that of RfaD, where the music would become overwhelming, that of Solaris makes itself non-remarkable, being but another hint at the characters' state of mind, therefore brilliantly serving what should ultimately be a soundtrack's purpose (understand: compared to all those movies which just use the latest hits as loud as possible in order to sound cool, no matter if the songs actually fit what's going on). Secondly, and I know that some here don't share that view, but the visuals and the photography were stunning, and I loved the contrast between the colors used in the scenes on Earth and those aboard the station, which give most scenes this dreamy aura, again completely fitting the story. Also a word about the actors: they are very few speaking parts, but all of them have been cast well, with Clooney showing us yet another face of his talent and Natasha McEhlone simply excellent in the difficult part of Rheya, Clooney's Kelvin's deceased wife, who is the emotional core of the movie.Now about the storytelling in itself: of course, this covers only part of the book, or the original movie for that matter. But this is one of those stories where, unlike Lord of the Rings for instance, there is no real point of retelling the same story word by word. THAT would have been a waste of everybody's time. Instead, Soderbergh chooses to focus on some of the themes, namely the loss, the need for redemption, and the choices we make.But don't expect long and loud theories about all this. Don't expect moral judgments about the characters' actions. Instead, you are shown facts, the slow pace of the film allowing you space and time to put in your own thoughts and feelings.And this maybe for some the problem, and why lots of people have considered this film boring: they are times when no words are said, and little is done. Even at times, the music is completely gone, a kind of pace we're not used to in today's Occidental movie making (compared to Asian's cinema and animation)and that something that we tend to be almost afraid of somehow, like when at dinner when everyone run out of good words and pleasantries and all is left is silence. We always feel uncomfortable, because all we're left with is ourselves. Some days, we can face it. Some days, we cannot.This is exactly what happens with this movie, which, at core, is a mirror to some of our own basic human feelings, and not necessarily those we're always ready to deal with. Therefore, instead of getting dragged, we're are actually asked to participate to this emotional (and NOT intellectual) journey.But are you ready for it?*******************************Luckily for me, I was, and this is why I gave it 9/10, as I've been treated with one of the most powerful emotional journey cinema over the last few years.

reviews.review_title: Wish I Caught This One Earlier!
reviews.content: It is apparent, comparing the earlier comments to the later ones, that this is a film that needed more time to 'find its audience'.Solaris is a sci-fi masterpiece. Comparisons to 2001 or even Scott's original Alien are inevitable.All three films are so brilliantly and beautifully paced... drawing the viewer slowly (by the way, 'slowly' is NOT a bad word!)into another world...building the discomfort level....an eerie feeling that something is not right here. I was, to borrow a cliché, 'on the edge of my seat'.I remember seeing the original Russian film on a bad, grainy, bootlegged tape many years ago....and NOT being able to sit through it...but I will be looking for it again as I, and my tastes have matured, I suspect I may have disregarded something special.Like this film.

First of all i've seen the Soviet version and read the book by Lem. although it's sightly different from the original version the message it conveys is the same. Some accuse this movie of being bored and slow, but that is just its nature. The movie is confusing because of its flashbacks and ending, which i cannot truly understand. But i think everyone could understand it. I must confess that the movie left me without any sleep for a night, on the contrary of most people. I like somewhat Sci-fi movies, (that is why i saw it,) but the Future Space thing is just the setting. the movie in essence deals about Human nature itself, it present to us self evident question that might never be answered or that have no answer, such as "What is real and what's not? The movie shows the human natural tendency to destroy, but it also show us that hope, faith and love can overcome those, (wonderfull message) It is a movie that if you think about it, you will realize it's greatness. The character of George Clooney is the skeptical science man that looks for an answer and at the end is overcomes by faith, Gordon fears the unknown as we all do, and feels threatened by the presence of people who are suppose to be dead. She argues about the human quality of these people, but she does not think about her human quality when she overcome her fears by extinguishing the life of those who might or might not be humans, but still have the right to live. From my point of view they are as humans as we are since they are an in essence the same as those who died. We see that when Gibarian (the mission commander) Return to life and speaks of his mistake to commit suicide. Snow as hard to believe is the one that best understand the current situation, he seems mad because it is a very confusing idea. In essence the movie convey us the message that some things are beyond our understanding, we must just accept them. If Rheya brought happiness to Kelving, what does it matter if she was or not human, or if she was real, for him it was the same person, (not the person he wants her to be, if so she wouldn't have the suicide tendency.) She and the other as well seems very real to me, and can you define the limits of reality. Many other movies and books are just as inspiring as this one,(Sphere, Abyss, Blade Runner and many more), the idea of making your thought real is a frightening one. I hope you like this movie and that you cant sleep that day, the Russian version is worse in technology but good in its message, i strongly recommend it as well as the original Book. And nerve fear the unknown and the incomprehensible, just learn how to accept it.

All I knew of the movie in advance had been some short reviews and a brief look on the website. So I was really not expecting a science fiction spectacle like ID4 or STTNG. I guess I was hardly expecting anything at all. And this was good!I guess reviews and opinions have been somewhat controversial, I acknowledge that in several theatres people have moved out on the movie. Not so in the screening I attended. The cinema was packed with people (O.K. merely 150 seats), they were even sitting on the stairway! Nobody left during the movie, and at least half the people stayed until the very end of the credits. Now that is a scene I do not experience too often!I quickly agreed with my girlfriend that this movie was truly a piece of art - some 30 seconds into the movie. And we were not at all disappointed. I might compare it to `Out of Sight', another Soderbergh/Clooney feature that I like very much but actually many people do not. And of course some comparison to 2001 imposed itself. I liked very much how this movie challenged my spirit and provoked my thoughts.I am not going to recite the storyline, but I have to say I was deeply touched by the tragic of `new' Rheyas consciousness. Her urge to know what and who she was. And the sudden realization not to know whether anybody was `himself' anymore. Finalized by Chris' concern not to have remembered Rheya rightly.In no means this movie is fast paced or swift. It takes its time and gives the viewer time to orientate himself or - more likely -  to experience the disorientation of the characters. I was a little afraid the movie might conclude in some action feature shoot-out or similar. Fortunately this was not the case. The movies draws the complete circle back to the beginning and eventually leaves the viewer in awe.Finally I would like to express my sincere appreciation for the movies photography and editing. The focus/blur effects really contributed to center my attention. The choice of camera angels also did involve me so much more than the usual depictures of scenes. And the edited sequence of shots and scenes built just the right tension.A 9 out of 10! Really great, great cinema!

It is a film you should lose all expectations of formulas so common in most movies. It gives the feeling of watching a play where there is a stage but also intimacy that is difficult to find on film. Don't expect the film-makers to hold your hand and guide you through the plot they have, thankfully, given you more credit. You meet the characters in a time and place in which life is in progress, in other words, events have taken place and they are moving into another stage of activity. After the movie you will have questions in your mind of not just the movie but of reality and perceptions within your own life. You will think about it for days and will ponder such things as God, gods, universe, reality, hope, and what is truth?

This was about as boring a movie as they come,talk about watching paint dry. You may have to get the vivarin out when you take this one on. I like Clooney but this was a poor job(all those involved also) and can see why it bombed at theaters. Some sci-fi films make you think, this one makes you comatose.

My husband, our two teens and I viewed this film when it appeared on a cable channel one Friday evening. According to the review in the television guide, it was a three star movie. And given that it sported George Clooney, we expected good things. All the better that it was science fiction, too.The sets are very convincingly done, the sound and lighting are interesting, and the acting excellent. Few complaints about the cinematography except for one scene with fast panning that could have been skipped - that effect was annoying. The movie has one fatal flaw, and that is simply a bad storyline that is slow to the point of being arduous and so lacking in substance as to border on being stupid. The best sets, lighting, music, and acting cannot cure a film with essentially no plot.Don't rent this one.

reviews.review_title: I thought it was very thought provoking...
reviews.content: ********Warning Spoilers Ahead***************I'm taking it to be a message about our existence--what is god?  why are we here anyway?  what is reality?  There were obvious parallels to our own circumstances in that Rheya ponders her existence--knows she has been created by the planet--but doesn't for what purpose and cannot communicate with her creator.  I thought it had a 'spirituality' message--I even think I saw the old "God in the Sistine Chapel" shot at the end when Kelvin reaches out to the little boy.Also, maybe it was also a closer look at the human condition.    Juxtapose Kelvin's reaction at his wife's abortion, and later, shooting wife copy no. 1 into space. The message being your morality can and will change, depending on your circumstances.  I also like that Kelvin is human--and not one dimensional.  Its refreshing actually to see a bit of weakness in a "hero". I think that whole 'don't tell copy no. 1' stuff is hilarious.I liked the Kubrick-ey space shots--what else can you do? I'll think of them as 'tributes'--of course, the space station was the best and most realistic ever.  The soundtrack was good.I like that there are questions unanswered.  Like the 'formula' isn't that dead people from your past come back to life--cause Snow makes a copy of himself...we don't know what Gordon's visitor is, and doesn't Gibarian's son exist on earth?  Kelvin copies himself--so maybe he was a copy already when he got there?  Who knows?I always like sublety and get annoyed when I am hit on the head with the 'answers'.So for me I took away alot from the movie--the who are we and what are we doing here anyway theme.  They didn't attempt to answer the question--the whole point was to pose the question.  As individuals, we have to answer that one ourselves in our own way.and like the characters in the movie--its probably unanswerable.

This is a film that deals with a variety of philosophical issues in enough depth to provoke thought and discussion, without doing all the work for the viewer. The relationship between the two leads in convincing and very well acted. As for the philosophical issues, it looks at the nature of personal identity, the boundaries of what can be known and what can't, the existence and nature of God and whether those topics can even be addressed by humans, and of course, what happens after death. What makes the film interesting is that it sounds out the questions without in any way seeking to supply the answers, except to suggest that those answers cannot be trite. It cleverly references 2001 A Space Odyssey. I think it needs two or three views to get the full benefit, but it does re-pay repeated watching.

reviews.review_title: Lets not call it sci-fi shall we?
reviews.content: When did Steven Soderbergh start imitating David Lynch? George Clooney's character goes to a far away space station in response to a distress call from his friend. Apparently the planetoid that the space station is orbiting has the power to create a faux human being that exists in the minds of the astronauts. For the protagonist Chris Klein its his wife.Although, the camera work is competent, there is nothing all that awe-inspiring about the concept or the performances for that matter. The story (if the movie has one) is so predictable that you would literally doze off.Solaris falls into that class of movies which are so vague that only Film School 'pseudo' know-it-alls would like to sit and analyze every inane frame just to show off how much more perspicacious their understanding of the fine art of film-making is. Thankfully most movie goers do not have to go to film school to realize what cinema is about. They just use their brains.

I have not seen the original...yet. So no comparison here. The whole movie I was thinking "this is flat" "this has no depth". Great visuals, score is only so-so. Acting was subdued, on purpose no doubt. Then came the positive but detached feeling afterwards. The is a mildly uplifting movie but in a out-of-body-feeling way. Watch it. Hang with it until the end. A nice job all the way around and a movie the feels like nothing else I've seen.

To say that this movie surprised me more than any I have ever watched, is an understatement. Solaris is one of the best films ever made about the power of memory, the ways we deal with pain and the unknown, and how real love is transcendent.The music and visuals (especially of Solaris itself) are hauntingly visceral in a way I can't even completely convey. The cast is dead on perfect. The story is a very simplified, economic version of the original (which in this case works just fine) and deals more with the human factor than the science. It's a shame that more people couldn't get into this movie and disliked it because it didn't meet their expectations of what a science fiction should be; Solaris dealt with consequence, love, perception, fear, reason, spirituality, and death in a way that some of the most brilliant pure dramas have never even come close to capturing. This is one of the best sci-fi films ever made and hardly anyone seems to know about it. To call it underrated is an insult to an underrated movie. Solaris has been overlooked completely, even within the sci-fi community. Of those that did see it, many didn't really get what the film is about. (I blame the marketing campaign for that to some degree, trying to sell an action or horror sci-fi movie when this film was neither of those things.) They couldn't embrace the subtle, constant tension and unconventional, subversive, underlying themes. Spiritual science fiction is one way to describe it. A haunting, hard journey of man facing his memory, his "sins" made flesh, literally. Solaris is painfully insightful about relationships and the way we remember events and people to a degree that again, words can't capture. The end of Kelvin's journey is something that people can talk about again and again, trying to figure out what really happened to him.Did he ever finally get "home"?

reviews.review_title: not very good, and not very clear
reviews.content: This film is alright, but for the first 45 minuets, i had no idea what was going on. it didn't explain things that should be obvious. the plot wasn't very good either, for i didn't see one. A depressed psychologist, goes to a ship (dont know what is for) because a friend asked for him there because things were happening. He didn't say what though. the ending wasn't very clear what happened either. was he dead? was she just one of the 'visitors'. it wasn't very clear. George Cloony was also not very good in this film. His acting was just not up to scratch. It did not have enough character development in ti, too. at the end of the film, i felt i did not know the characters, and i felt highly unsettled. It could have been better.
