If you loved Blade Runner don't let yourself be fooled be the commentaries on Solaris. It has nothing to do with Blade Runner. BR is 1 of the best Scifi movies ever made. During Solaris I fell asleep the first time in my life. I am 44, I go to cinema 1-4times month and never fell asleep even with other movies which I did not like. I would call this movie an artistic Science Fiction ...meaning no action, beautiful pictures,very strange story. And the actors? What is G.Cloney doing in this movie?I like Stanislaw Lem. But I did not read Solaris. I will do it and I bet that the book is much better than this movie.

This movie intrigued me for some time. But upon realizing what the movie is about, I was disappointed in the message. First I see the beings do not breathe. The resurrections are referred to with disgust. The other team is not correct about flesh and bone inheriting the kingdom. Yes blood is sacred but its not dirty. We will rule on the earth for the 1000 years but everything will be wonderful. Hard for some who lack appreciation for the new opportunity, but hey, free will comes at a cost.
this movie is pure trash and pure nonsense.Nothing makes the least bit of sense.Sappy story along with romance makes this romantic C- sci-fi chick flick.

There are a number of interpretations that can patch together a resolution for this picture if one is not particularly troubled by plot holes and logical conundrums. For instance, a giddy fantasist could conclude that the main character has reached out to an alien life form and has fallen in love with it: a real wham-bang love story. A determined sci-fi fan might see Blade-Runner-style tragedy. A prodigiously sane person completely unexperienced in mental illness might suppose that main character succumbs to madness. A quick cynic might conclude that passive-aggressive aliens adroitly manipulate the main character's unresolved feelings of love and guilt re: his suicide wife to achieve their nefarious ends. A Socratic person might conclude that if such is the case, the main characters's embrace (a la Cypher in The Matrix) of an illusory "wife" in favor of reality is pitiable. A moralist might find the same choice reprehensible; an existentialist, absurd; an aestheticist, disgusting.I don't subscribe to the any of the more generous interpretations. In fact, I am deprived of any interpretation at all, because the story failed to sustain my interest. I freely admit to fast-forwarding through many of the dull silences and duller (though fast-cut) dialog. The picture did not create enough of an illusion for me to suspend my disbelief sufficiently to care about what was actually happening. Here is why the execution, in my view, failed: 1. In what is actually a short picture, the pace is glacial and the film at times downright boring, especially after it is clear that these "aliens," if aliens they are, intend to employ only mild-mannered psychology and low-key guilt trips to obtain their ends (as opposed to ray-guns, spatulas, creepy mind-f#@ks, or anything else that might possibly inspire fear). If any kind of tension is to be sustained, the "visitors" phenomena ought to be able to inspire dread of some kind in the viewer. This side of the balance fails however because there is no fight in the main character, who falls for the aliens' machinations almost immediately, with the unsurprising result that the human stakes are too low. We might feel pity for this weak-willed guilt-sodden sap, but hardly fear. Conversely, if one tries to interpret the "visitors" phenomena in a positive light, tension also fails, for the same reason: it is obvious that the love-smitten main character will do nothing to harm these visitors. Likewise, that the only other human crew member (if she IS human -- you decide), partly because she is so underdeveloped, likewise poses no real danger to any friendlies. Furthermore, one never gets the impression that the phenomena, however interpreted, represent any ill to the main character that amounts to even one-third of a hill of beans. The main character just isn't man enough.2. Some reviewers clearly were impressed with the emotional reality of the main character-"wife"/visitor relationship. I didn't find much emotional depth, despite all of the in-your-face edits. If we are to be able to imagine we are viewing a picture in which a main character is faced with aliens, human-shaped vorpal bunnies, self-created revenants, mental illness, what have you, the picture ought to be more frightening. Instead, we are left with a main character who weakly succumbs to phenomena that somehow manage to be more soporific than anything else, probably because they spend most of the picture rehashing the main character's relationship with his dead wife. With a weak MC and little sense of threat (i.e., something at stake), my response can only be, WHO CARES?

I saw the original in the 70's and liked it very much.  In fairness to the original, I should see it again, but based on my recollection of it this remake is much better.  Clooney and McElhone are wonderful.  Soderbergh should be well on his way to Oscar nominations for best direction and screenplay, and so should Clooney for best actor.  I was struck at how emotionally moved I was while watching this film.  I had tears streaming down my face at times.  This came as quite a surprise.The screenplay is wonderfully ambiguous.  There may be strong spiritual, mystical, and religious undercurrents at work here.  But, then again, maybe not.  I expect this film will generate a good deal of discussion. Without giving too much away, I wonder how many saw the reference to "Adam and God" painting of the Sistine Chapel?This is a fabulous film.  It goes right up to the top of my list of favorite sci-fi films.  Truly serious sci-fi films are rare.  I hope this film goes on to become a major critical and financial success.George

Solaris is a unique event film that will alienate many multiplex'ers who will stray in by accident.  Fox has little idea how to market this earnest meditation on loss, and the prescreening I attended was plagued by continuous walk-outs. This picture should not have opened wide like a Jurassic Park sequel, but rather platformed in New York, L.A. and then outwards.While audiences will surely divide on the overall merits of Solaris, the final twenty minutes are among the most compelling committed to film.

Visually: Interesting. Nice contrast from the mechanical, stiff, spaceship interior and curvasious organic forms of Solaris and the hot chick with the big eyes.Concept: ..almost there, just didn't make it somehow.  I buy into the "something missing" post.I think the ending might have killed it.cc2002

reviews.review_title: A welcome explosion-free return to good sci-fi
reviews.content: I understand those who argue that Solaris is slow-- there's not a single explosion or laser blaster fight in its entire 95 minutes-- but what Solaris lacks in beats per minute it makes up for by returning to sci-fi's philosophical storytelling roots, raising questions of ethics, morality, and mortality, and instilling a sense of wonder about our tiny place in the universe.Overall, Solaris is an excellent and welcome relief from Hollywood's usual botch job in the sci-fi arena.

reviews.review_title: Movie is better than the book.
reviews.content: I finished reading Solaris by S. Lem last night. The recent movie version (George Clooney) is better than the book because it completes the theme of "How do I know I'm 'real'?" The book leaves this theme incomplete and ends on a note of love lost.So how is this theme demonstrated? or are there hints to be carried into our own lives? In the book, Rheya listens to the conversations of the others, observes her own absence of memory about how she arrived and concludes that she isn't 'real.' In the movie, Rheya's reasoning process is very powerful tool to use in our own lives. I won't reveal what it is in this review.The book seems to meander off trail into a lot of unnecessary back story and fantasy about gods. The movie stays tightly focused on what does it mean to be real and how to we know it. It took me a while (a couple of years) to recognize the value of the lessons of the movie. I am eager to watch it again and find what I may have missed.

firstly, if you've read the book: forget it.if you haven't read the book: relax and soak up the beauty of Soderberg's directing.its a very bad idea to compare the film to the book of Solaris. In my opinion, the book is a great read, if somewhat derivative and at points tedious. The film is one of my all time favourites. Soderberg does not try to do a remake, or a film of the book, he does what anyone who has any sense does. he takes the idea that works in the book. and changes it to work as an excellent film. the combination of the screenplay, directing, acting and cliff Martinez' awesome, atmospheric soundtrack all come together and make Solaris nothing short of a masterpiece.The film is really like an art exhibition in a way, some people may not enjoy, but if you're going to watch it, do so with an open mind and just enjoy the truly superb piece of film making.

reviews.review_title: A creditable adaptation of a sci-fi classic
reviews.content: I was lucky enough to see this film at a UK preview screening followed by an on-stage interview with Steven Soderbergh and George Clooney. However if I didn't like the film, they wouldn't have convinced me otherwise.  Luckily the film was very good, both cinematically and with good acting performances. During the interview, both their comments on Solaris backed up what I had been thinking throughout the film.I admit that it could have been better with more background on the planet itself and what had previously happened, and was perhaps a little too short to do the source material justice. However Soderbergh's  focusing on the relationship between Kelvin and his wife, and his questioning of what was human, did really work. It had echoes of the similar theme in Bladerunner.I didn't surprise me it hasn't done that well in the US, as I can't name any other, non action sci-fi film that has, 2001: A Space Odyssey being the exceptionIn summary I'd rather see Sci-fi films like this, than any number of asteroid blasting gung-ho kill the CGI alien film, that purport to be Sci-fi.  8/10 from me.

Seen the Tarkovsky film, read the Lem novel - all that's irrelevant. Forget re-make bashing and any kind of comparison - it's usually a pointless pursuit for trainspotters. I should know, I am one!I first saw this movie dead-beat on a plane back from New York, very very sleepy and was mostly captivated by the drifting music while I dozed off. That time around I was annoyed by the glamorous looking couple in the movie. However, I wanted to hear the music again so bought the DVD and re-watched it all the way through while wide awake. Now the whole movie seems like one long dream itself, haunting and beautiful. I agree that other movies, and the original movie and book, deal with philosophical issues at greater length, but despite being fairly cold itself, this is a film about emotions and is intensely visual. Lots of sly visual allusions to other films, including obvious ones to 2001, but that always was one crazy hippy movie!Anyway, I would definitely recommend this, 10/10, if you have time, and I agree with another commentator, watch it with your lover/partner! It demonstrates that not all US movies have to be big bucks blockbusters or grungie indie movies - there's room for pure cinema (now what does that mean? :-)

reviews.review_title: Soderburgh/ Thinking outside of the box !!
reviews.content: This movie was outstanding, I can't say enough good things about it. I loved the way soderburgh used his independent filmmaker skills with the backing of 20th Century Fox. The character and story development are slow adding to the suspence. I feel the underlying love story was very touching and left me with a great feeling for days after seeing this film. This film was a little edgy and could be misunderstood by some. I would advise anyone and everyone to watch it and get overwhelmed in the true meaning of this film.  If Steven Soderburgh or George Clooney happen to read this good job and please continue to make films like this it's really what Hollywood needs. This film leaves you with a great feeling about true love and humanity.

I loved this movie, I just gave it a 9 out of 10. I could see how some people may get hung up on the pacing, especially if you are used to shoot-em-up type movies. This is not a typical Hollywood plot, so it may confuse 7 out of 10 viewers. I thought it was a masterpiece however. Great directing, visually stunning, great acting, great emotional depth, and what a plot!If you like movies that are not predictable, that you can't figure out what is going to happen from the first five minutes of the film, then I would recommend this movie to you. If you are the type that likes very formulaic plots where there is a good guy and a bad guy, and in the end the good guy wins and saves the world, then this movie is maybe not for you.

reviews.review_title: A thoughtful, romantic, lovely tone poem
reviews.content:
Before I saw Solaris, I thought the movie poster (featuring George Clooney kissing his co-star) might be misleading.  However, the film turned out to be very romantic, as well as intensely philosophical and beautifully shot.
Clooney continues to choose challenging roles and quality material, and director Soderbergh continues to prove his "auteur" status.  This film is entertaning while you are viewing it, and then it stays with you afterwards in an eerie, yet thought-provoking way.Overall, a fine film that may not appeal to the kiddies, but should please many deep-thinking adults.  Hardcore sci-fans should also enjoy this work a great deal.

it's a really good film and interesting and it's an action film when i see this film i think a bout another planets it's very mysterious i feel really nervous when i see it summary it's the most interesting film i've seen when i was young until now. i hope everybody could see this film one day. interesting film and the main characters are beautiful and handsome. special is George clooney. he acts very well and i hope you will feel it's a good film when you see it and you vote for it, too. I bet you will feel it's an interesting when you see it first and i dream one day i meet the main character ( Gerogre Clooney ) it's just my dream when i am an adult and older than now

reviews.review_title: Quality is not always about speed
reviews.content: After reading the comments , I feel that i should elaborate. This is a slow movie. It is meant to eb a slow movie. It is an excellent one, the slowness in a vital part of it. And please not, it is much faster than the Tarkovski original.Wel lworth seeing. Excellent ending.

reviews.review_title: Shorter and more direct than the original
reviews.content: This is one of those movies that gives me that sci-fi feeling I like, more so than the original Solaris (or Solyaris). The reason is much because of the newer effects and visual appeal, but mostly because of it's shorter more direct approach, you could say more commercialised, which here I don't believe is a bad thing. Also for Solaris (2002) avoiding to elaborate too much makes Solaris (2002) more thrilling than the original.I have given both the 2002 and 1972 version an 8 of 10 stars. The original Solyaris is longer and the philosophical aspect is more elaborate, and I DO think it is better in many aspects. But for me the shorter more direct approach of Solaris (2002) gives it the upper edge.

reviews.review_title: depends on what you expect to see
reviews.content: In short, if you expect to see a psychological drama as oppose to sci-fi movie with dynamic plot, you should enjoy this film. Sci-fi part is really just a setting in this film and thus is completely secondary. I thought the lead performances, script, cinematography were all good in this picture. Curious to see what Tarkovsky had done with this.Felt compelled to write a short comment about this b/c of the prolific amnt of bs reviews here...

an intelligent sci-fi film that doesn't depend on action, blood and frantic pacing. I haven't much of a problem with those items, but it's so nice to have one come along that requires one to think and to use their own brain to interpret some of the plot rather than having it spelled out and usually being very predictable. Kudos to Soderbergh. Shame it was such a commercial failure, but it's certainly no surprise considering that the masses seem to only want to see variations of the same plots. I didn't care for the endless original, so this came as a surprise. A very good movie and Soderbergh just absolutely refuses to be pigeon-holed.

reviews.review_title: Could have been so much better... (Spoilers)
reviews.content: It takes a brave man to follow Tarkovsky's answer to 2001 and Steven Soderbergh is that at least. First, the good: the film looks beautiful and the score lulls you into a relaxed, observatory state of mind. The cast are attractive and the worst of the anachronisms of Lem's book have been removed. There is actually a resolution to the movie and it is far more emotionally literate than either of the originals. Saying that there is much that has been messed about with to very little effect other than to ruin the intended plot. The essence of Solaris (the book) is an exploration into Man's (I do not mean to imply gender here) method of scientific analysis and how fallible that approach would be for an intelligence that exceeded their own. The only meaningful dialogue with the vast sentience that is Solaris comes from Kelvin's unresolved regret for the loss of Rheya, his love for her and the transmission of his unconscious thoughts to the planet itself. In this adaptation (mega-spoilers here): - Solaris itself appears never to have been studied or visited and the whole idea of the 'living sea' is lost.'Coroporations' (very 21st century and totally irrelevant to the plot) want to own Solaris as 'a possible energy source'. Again, why? This is both impossible (Steven do you understand *anything* about physics?) and detracts from one of the central points about the book which is Man's pure academic struggle to understand an intelligence greater than their own. The entire space station's library in the original(s) were devoted to decades of study into the phenomenon of Solaris. In the mythology of the book the planet has formed whole schools of thought and analysis - all lost hereBerton is lost from the plot and his son becomes Gibarian's. This character then becomes the representative of the planet. Neither the book or the Tarkovsky version needed this device so why do we in this film?Snow (Snaut) has become an alien. Why? It was not necessary to the plot. The planet never knowingly killed before (Jeremy Davies is definitely vying for the most irritating portrayal of a character ever.) There are rumours that this film was butchered for theatrical release and I sincerely hope that this was the case!

This film gave me a hell of a mind trip. In my opinion thats the reason why i gave it 7/10. Are we just puppets? Are we only imaginary. Is OUR existence real. Well I don´t know. But it´s a "seeworthy" movie. You wont regret it. But don´t expect a "fast" movie.

reviews.review_title: A rather dull film with some redeeming qualities
reviews.content: Solaris has a runtime of roughly 90 minutes without logos and credits. Still, many of those precious minutes are spent on numerous stylized flashback sequences. Most of these definitely serve a purpose but take entirely too long and aren't particularly exciting to watch, being mostly dark and dim. Some of them feel arbitrary and purposefully stretched to boost the length of the film.It seems like Steven Soderbergh went out of his way to avoid exposition through dialogue, possibly out of fear of having it be too obvious or condescending. A lot of time is wasted on showing the audience that George Clooney is some kind of shrink. Yet, by the time he sets foot aboard the spaceship, we still have no idea what Solaris actually is or what kind of mission the crew is conducting. Simply knowing that might have greatly increased my enjoyment of the first half. The deliberate vagueness does not contribute to the sense of mystery at all, it just makes the characters less believable for not seeming all that bothered by it.Some credit is due for the way in which Soderbergh manages to portray the rather philosophical subject matter and have the characters explore and discuss it without breaking our suspension of disbelief. That being said, since none of this is technically original material, I think it's appropriate to base my rating mostly on artistic considerations. Intellect has little to do with one's enjoyment of this movie. It's definitely no Star Wars, but it's no 2001 either. It doesn't take a common man to get annoyed by the inconsistent pacing and dullness.

reviews.review_title: Terrible Film-making (Warning: This comment contains spoilers)
reviews.content: Solaris is not a sequel, its not an action/adventure/science-fiction film or fantasy like A Star Wars or Terminator. It is way beyond opposite of all that. It is more of a dramatic, mysterious, romantic adventure in the future when a planet known as solaris is a place of energy. An energy source that would be able to contain a world with highly advanced, unwastefull or unpolluting energy. The energy source ends up being used for Earth, which brings our planet to a futuristic and highly advanced and sophisticated in mathematics and science in the energy's capability. I took the impression thats how Earth was futurelly-like. But this exotic and occasionally sexually active and erotic adventure passes like a wind blowing over a tight swindle.Starring George Clooney, and in definitely one of his most richest roles, he plays unusually in this bizarrely overrated motion picture. He is a hard-to-understand character. But in the beginning he is sent to a space-ship which impressionally is the central station for watching over Solaris. It moves around the planet like a satellite. While making sure the planet's energy is being reflected to Earth for good reasons. Strange and Bizarre activities have been happening on the ship lately. When Clooney gets their, he sees blood and dead people. He also sees blood coming from the vents on the ceiling. He realizes he and a co-pilot are the only ones left on the team. Once there were about seven of them. Clooney eventually asks what had happened, and the guy who really...speaks...like...this (the co-pilot) says a metaphorical statement. And throughout the entire movie, they don't even explain it once, which is one of the film's disappointments. But once clooney sleeps and wakes up in the middle of the night, seeing his wife (who supposedly died) is alive again. Thats where the confusion comes in. It is a mind-bending tale, with very good ideas.It shows a few long 10 minute flashbacks throughout the movie of Clooeny and his wife, their relationships, their romance, including their sex. Also when he brings her on the space station, and how he puts her in a small glass shuttle, and for some odd reason he presses the go button and lets her go off into space while she is still in their. While Clooeny's suspicion of her being dead, she appears back on the ship again. Then a random kid comes up, maybe a 7 year-old-kid. Later on, Clooney see's the co-pilot's dead body in the vents of the ceiling, which is where he had noticed the blood coming from the vents. While the co-pilot hangs out in his room, Clooney realizes that everything is just a memory. His wife who had randomly appeared on the ship was just a memory of what Clooney knows of her. Same goes for the co-pilot. Then Clooney realizes that the random kid is also just a memory. These memories that seem so real is by the strength of solaris which is how the memories are appearing in actual life.When solaris starts to implode, the co-pilot leaves, the girl just disappears, and clooney including the kid just sit in the ship, waiting for solaris to explode and kill them. It is somewhat a sad scene, Clooney's raw intensity in this scene is simply astounding. (personally the best scene of the movie). Then after Clooney dies, he's back at his house, and his wife stands their looking at him.Now, first of all this movie was absolutely the most boring movie I have ever seen. The first 20 minutes are purely raw intensity and deep in entertainment. But the rest is dreary, especially repetitive with sex and nudity. The movie is just about obsessed with it. But it is drenched Win confusion. The deliberation is always slow. The movie is slow. The movie sucks. It is the worst movie I have ever seen. Definitely up for the razzies. If you're expecting drama, expect MAJOR drama. Because it is an orall experience. These are good ideas with a terrible execution.Secondly, critics are idiots. Thye apparently loved this movie. You can see how, but I thought it was patchy, dry, dull, soulless, heartless, slow, weak, boring, and terrible. Whenever someone mentions this movie (which people never really do) I'll just laugh. Its lame. Its not anyones kind of movie, its easy to fall asleep in. What kind of a story is this. Its not even interesting. And having solaris' explosion is a lot bigger of a situation than how they should of reacted. Leaving isn't the answer. It is the Earth's frickin power source. Ultimately the world would fall apart. And the last scene was terrible. Made me feel even worse for this movie, the world is still alive, and it shows the wife appear again. Did Clooney die or just appear back at home? either way, the direction was awful, same with James Cameron's writing.THE WORST MOVIE I HAVE EVER SEEN.1/10 -- if it can go lower: 0/10.

reviews.review_title: Very good, different. But the end is confusing.
reviews.content: I really enjoyed this movie. It was different, to say the least. Good acting and special effects, and a weird (in a good sense) plot. The only problem I had with it was the ending. It was just too confusing.It made me want to get the original novel and check that out.

reviews.review_title: An artsy romantic tragedy on a sci-fi backdrop with visual and musical parallels to 2001.
reviews.content: An artsy romantic tragedy on a sci-fi backdrop with visual and musical parallels to 2001.  This is a quiet and sedate movie with no explosions or violent outbursts - Jerry Bruckheimer could never have made this film.  It has intelligent and fallible characters - which is to say, believable characters, well acted.  The pace of the movie is leisurely -slow, never forced, but towards a definite conclusion.  I am surprised the studio ponied up the amount of money necessary for the well-done sci-fi effects and futuristic set design.  Doubtless having the well-known Clooney made them believe it would be a worthy gamble.  And though Clooney carries his character well, the intelligent and meditative tone to the movie almost ensures it will not be seen or distributed nearly as much as it should.

reviews.review_title: It's about time a good film can be seen in theaters
reviews.content: Even better than the original, Soderberg brings amazing camera work along with good editing and great storytelling. People with less amount of IQ would probably not be able to understand where the movie is going, however these types of films, similar to Kubric's 2001 are made once every ten or fifteen years. If you are an action film lover you won't like this film so don't waste your time, this is also not a film for kids. Soderberg's amazing use of short focal lens throughout the film works very well with the narrative of the film. Most of you won't like it but this film will be remembered in ten-twenty years.

reviews.review_title: Feels like an original-series Star Trek episode remade after 2001: A Space Odyssey.
reviews.content: If you make an effort, moving and spooky.  If you don't, pointless and dull.It will be up to you -- it's a pretty film, but, because there's not really much in it that will feel new, not really compelling.

This is a beautifully shot movie with some very interesting themes.  It questions the limits of human knowledge as well as common belief that our mental constructs such as "designing", "creating" and "destroying" can and should be applied to the whole universe and all of existence.The movie illustrates these ideas through a largely romantic based story.For anyone who enjoys science and philosophy, I completely recommend this film!

++ fascinating premise, keeps you thinking but is not too mysterious++ finally a movie that isn't afraid to turn off the "this is how you're supposed to feel" soundtrack and let the director, plot and characters do the work!+ wonderful cinematography, effects, and soundtrack+ 2001: A Space Odyssey references+ "Snow" character - interesting characterization, great portrayal. decent actingplot is a little thinslow paceabrupt endingOverall: Worth seeing, esp. for SciFi fans, but be in a mellow mood.  Not for the masses.  Despite its short length, it's still too long due to the slow pace, yet manages to leave you with a feeling like you've just eaten a rice cake - "where's the substance?"  For all the hype about it being confusing, i found it fairly straightforward.

They should have skipped running this film in the theatre and had it go straight to video.  I don't know who is responsible for this poor exercise in film, but someone should be fired.  This film is sooooooooooooooooooooo boring!!!  The ideas and story are actually very good and thought provoking. However the film itself is a dog.  What a waste of time.  Save your money, you'll enjoy it more on videotape where you can fast forward through the repetitive shots of clooney's wife.  Also you can write down all the clues to try to piece the story together.  This is the worst film ever made (seriously).

reviews.review_title: A very poor film, it must have lost millions.
reviews.content: I have just totally wasted 99 minutes watching an uninteresting, unbelievable,morbidly slow and coma inducing film that failed to interest me or convince me of the validity of the storyline. I thought that with George Clooney starring in it that it would have at least been entertaining, it wasn't. The only thing I found interesting was the visual effects, these were very colourful and almost etheric. I was so pleased when it had finished. It left me wondering how much money and talent had been wasted in making it, and who where the unfortunate financial investors and how much had they lost. In my opinion the story was wafer thin and many of the questions raised were never answered to my satisfaction. It just emphasises to me that without a rock solid interesting and hopefully believable story line all the big money needed to make a film today is wasted.

When I saw the coming attractions for Solaris, I was dumbstruck.  I've be a long-time fan of Stanislaw Lem, and I'd never seen the earlier film version. I couldn't image how anyone could hope to take any of Lem's works, let alone Solaris, and make a film of it.  Having seen it, I have to admit that I'm pleasantly suprised.  While it's not exactly a faithful representation, it is a deeply atmospheric interpretation of the story.  George Clooney continues to impress me with his emotionally moving performance of Chris Kelvin, and Natascha McElhone is astonishing as his wife, Rheya.  Although I knew that I had to see this film, I had serious doubts going into it.  It may not be everyone's cup of tea, but in my opinion, by daring to create a film outside of the mainstream that interacts with the audience on an almost entirely emotional level, Mr. Soderbergh has made an important contribution to his art.  Solaris is a certifiable success.

An excellent movie. I found it quite moving throughout, with mature performances from all the actors (though there are only half a dozen people in it) and the best work I've seen from Clooney. I haven't read the book or seen the original but I can't imagine doing so would spoil this movie in any way. The film manages to perfectly achieve the tense atmosphere of the investigation into the mystery of existence around Solaris, and the heartache this causes the people there. The actual sci-fi is quite subdued in the movie, and this just made it more realistic for me personally (though this is the first time I've seen a Higgs field mentioned on-screen). I'm not convinced everyone in the future will wander around explaining all their technological marvels all the time like in some sf movies, and doing so just detracts from the storyline. Having the sci-fi restricted to the scenery and concentrating on the story produces a much more involving and thought provoking film.

Just seen it on DVD and I regret not seeing it on the big screen. The film isn't quick and if you're after a "X-Men" style experience you will be sorely disappointed. But if you're after a thoughtful, moving and philosophical film that will linger in your mind for days to come you'll love it.In style I found it very similiar to Gattaca (if you liked Gattaca I would guess that you'll probably enjoy Solaris) even down to the soundtrack (which is haunting and beautiful) and the visual look of the film. Also reminiscent of Heat (another film I adore).A real gem which was doomed to obscurity in the current climate of film making.A surprisingly good film for such big Hollywood names to make.To sum up, if you want crash bang excitement rent see something else, if you want to think and ponder the nature of life, love and the universe, sit back and saviour this film.

reviews.review_title: Much better than I thought it would be.
reviews.content: I haven't read the book, nor have I seen the original film adaptation. But the story seemed to be consistent, so it appears to stand alone well. There were no inconsistencies in the plot that I saw.I can't remember a Sci-Fi film, apart from 2001, which was realistic (and daring?) enough to not have sound effects when in space.Clooney and McElhone were superb. Especially McElhone. Though I don't think I've seen Clooney in such a dramatic role before.The ending was good, even though I don't like "happy endings" as a rule.I loved the music. Although there seemed to be only two main pieces, they were wielded well.The friend I saw it with thought it was boring in places. But he wanted to see "Equilibrium". He didn't understand the ending so I enjoyed explaining it to him. He also didn't understand the incorporation aspect of the "visitors". Perhaps others will have the same problem.

reviews.review_title: For those who see "meaning" in the absence of any.
reviews.content: Some films take a compelling concept, and create a story that is moving, poignant, meaningful and thought-provoking.  Other films are unabashed entertainment to thrill the masses.  And then there are films like SOLARIS. Films made for only one reason: to satisfy the egos of filmmakers who actually think they're saying something.It has become its own genre.This last kind of film has a small but earnest following.  And you can bet their audience will find meaning in ANY tale.  But you can also bet they'll never agree with each other on what that meaning IS.  Oh, but that's the point, you see.  It's "interpretive".  It's subjective.  We all see different meanings in it.  That's the whole beauty of it, they say.A similar kind of film is David Lynch's MULHOLLAND DRIVE.  And it would seem that people will tend to like or dislike both.  And if you come across someone who LIKES it, don't dare suggest it's awful -- or else it's assumed you're not intelligent enough to "get it". (Or perhaps just not creative enough to have imposed your own meaning upon it -- which, let's face it, if I wanted to WRITE the movie, I wouldn't have come to see YOURS!)Personally, I prefer a story.  I prefer something that makes sense and has a forward motion.  Something that adds up -- ALL of it.  I can go cerebral and make the challenging mental connections along with the best of them.  But SOLARIS and its breed (and their followers) believe that juxtaposing images in a random or lingering fashion -- as long as you have a thread of a story -- makes for some sort of artistic masterpiece.But it doesn't.There are some very nice elements in SOLARIS.  The concept, for one.  I haven't seen the original nor read the book (which shouldn't be required when seeing a film, by the way).  But the story concept is EXCELLENT.  I would have LOVED a well-told version of this thing.Jeremy Davies also gives a dynamic performance (hammy, perhaps, but at least it was fascinating to watch).  Clooney was solid.  McElhone was radiant. Davis was good.  I enjoyed the score and the aesthetically-pleasing cinematography and the expansive set.But when Soderbergh is at the helm of a story that DOESN'T have a clear linear drive (as BROCKOVICH and OCEAN'S both did), you get self-indulgent filmmaking, pure and simple.  TRAFFIC's another example.  Great to look at, excellent acting, nice scenes -- adds up to nothing we hadn't seen on a hundred television shows.  Maybe it's just me, but I find Soderbergh the most consistently overrated director working today (well, alongside Lynch, perhaps).The worst part is that I LOVED the IDEAS behind these films.  I would've liked each of those mentioned here to have been great WITHOUT having ME supply their meanings.  I just wish the filmmakers had done their jobs (tell a story), rather than pander to those few who find meaning where there is none.If that's you, then this is your film.

I read these comments before watching the film and so expected a stinker. Solaris is no where near being a bad movie. In fact its a great movie and the negative comments on this board says more about the reviewer than the film. If you are NOT an overstimulated multiplex squatter with ADD who expects, nay demands explosions and car chases every 2 minutes or else lots of angry men with guns shouting all the time then you will appreciate this film. It takes about 20 minutes to adjust to the pace (which is decidedly measured) but once you settle into it then the cinematography, soundtrack, plot and acting are a joy.Its a thought provoking and occasionally moving film which you will enjoy if you are cine-literate and possess a wide diversity of filmic tastes.

Forgive me if I'm wrong but aren't movies supposed to have plots??  What happen here?? Great director, great actor and great (I'm the king of the world) producer.  I guess too much greatness went to their heads as this movie has neither beginning nor end.  Okay I can take the idea that the movie is slow but please show some suspense.  You know when Chris (George Clooney) sees his wife for the first time he was shocked and afraid that he ships her off into space.  But when he sees her the second time I didn't even care since there was no suspense to build up to that climatic moment. The story is depressing but they could have added some dialogue and some more suspense to keep the audience wondering until the very end. Frankly, by the time the movie ended I didn't even care that happened to these two characters.  Another problem is the other crew members on the space station; we are introduced to them and nothing more.  They might as well not been there.  I guess Steven Soderbergh added them in to add some dialogue to the story.  At least make them interesting.  In an interview Soderbergh said that he hardly used FX so it doesn't take away from the story.  Sorry Steven but there was not story to take away from.

Solaris seems to be a mysterious force that can remake or resurrect people.In a way, it is God, it is the unknown and all that ambiguity!It's a wonderful film to watch because you come away effected by it, not in an obvious way that you can dispense with easily however. I truly felt for the characters and Soderbergh's deft musing on ideas and themes are superb. I got a similar feeling from Sex, Lies.. and also Traffic. The films he make deal with fairly major issues; but seem to really effect the individual characters. Reminds me of Philip K Dick stories in a way. The story rolls out a wonderful pace, fragments of memory from various characters mixed in with visuals of the planet. Did anyone else see the strands across Solaris' surface? Reminded me of brain synapses...in the original one Russian character says something like 'the planet acts like a mind' or something like that. A lovely take on those lines I think. The acting is superb; Clooney is excellent. Who is the 'hairy' guy, who's been 'copied'? I can't remember his name, but he was in another film which had Bono from U2 in it (something Millenium Hotel?). I really enjoyed the soundtrack, really great with the visuals. The first post on this film said that the film was generally a bit dull. I didn't get that feeling at all. Acted superbly, the visuals were very simple and not over bearing. Everything seemed to work well.

This movie is amazing. It is what sci-fi movies are supposed to be like. It keeps your attention from beginning to end. The editing to special effects are all amazing. Goerge Clooney does and excellent job and instantly has you wrung up in his character. You feel his emotions throughout the whole movie. I recommend you see it if you have any sense of intelligence. I give it 5 out of 5 stars and 2 thumbs up.

I thought it was going to be a great movie when I first started to watch it. But I was about to go to sleep the whole movie, "The beginning" seemed to continued forever. Nothing happened and they got those sick dreams. It felt like the were filming the whole movie on an area of about 10m2. There's a lot greater movies out there to spend your time in front of. But if you want something that makes you go asleep this is the movie for you! The story really sucked, i cant figure how anyone can like this movie!I gave this movie 2/10, a movie as slow like this one don't deserve more.

CONTAINS SPOILERS! What an outstanding piece of work. This is pure sci-fi: take a wild concept - what if our memories of lost love ones could become real and take on their own lives? - and then follow the idea to its logical conclusion, as realistically as possible.Despite a slow start this film scores, largely because of the outstanding portrayals of its two central characters, Chris (Clooney) and Rheya (McElhone). Of the two, McElhone is the mesmerising heart of this film, delivering an understated but electrifying performance as a new being struggling to understand what she is, and struggling to negotiate strange memories of her pain-wracked relationship with Chris.The parallel stories of their relationship past and present play out beautifully and almost every scene delivers a thoroughly convincing emotional bombshell. And no, it isn't a chick flick. This is grown-up film-making. It feels a lot like a play - dominated by long conversations between the two main characters. But it never drags and never gets boring. On the contrary, it is totally gripping because it commands such belief in its characters and their situation.Hats off to George for a nuanced, heartfelt performance and for being enough of a professional to give over so much screen time to McElhone. There are long shots here of conversations between these two in which we see nothing of Clooney at all - just McElhone's extraordinarily beautiful, haunting face, studying her reactions as he speaks. And it works. This film will stay with you for days.Highlight: Clooney's anguish when he discovers that Rheya has aborted their child (paralleled at the end when Rheya discovers that he killed her first "copy") - a powerful scene and the kind of acting you rarely see in Hollywood movies. We need more of this stuff.

reviews.review_title: Love to see an extended version
reviews.content: This is a magnificent film and remake. I agree that it excels the original - though the original is magnificent, and anything by Tarkovsky is worth repeated viewing. Watching Solaris after watching two similar, but obviously different, recent films (The Fountain, Sunshine) made me think not only that Solaris stands shoulder to shoulder with these, but that if there were to be a re-issuing of Solaris, in an extended version, now would be the time.I understand that Soderbergh has talked about the possibility of releasing an extended version (apparently thirty minutes were cut due to negative first screening). I would love to see an extended version, provided the extra thirty minutes weren't redundant in any way, but added to character or plot (e.g. more conversations with the post-suicide Tukur; or more discussions/explorations of what Solaris is). Sorry to be picky, but those would be the conditions for my interest.

This movie starts out interesting, but pretty soon it becomes silly, and much more fantasy than sci-fi. The acting is so-so. The script is often stupid/awkward, but sometimes poetic (in a good way). The characters aren't introduced much, and seem unfamiliar and hard to associate with. The movie generally doesn't evoke much emotion, except a few times, mostly because it so often induces disbelief. Certain camera shots (like seeing a character's face) feel unnecessarily long without adding substance, and at the same time, some story aspects are underdeveloped. There is no explanation for how clones of specific dead humans, with their memories, appear out of nowhere. The crew members are certain, by unknown reasons, that it's the planet below that creates them. Of course. And they are not unusually perplexed, amazed or in disbelief. The whole movie feels shallow because of this unrealism. It would have been potentially interesting to learn more about the planet Solaris.Also, more could have been done out of the main character's approach to Solaris. More emotion.At one point the characters discuss how the "visitors" are built. One of the crew members comes up with what is supposed to be a wild guess, the other one programs a particle accelerator (how come they have one on the ship to begin with?) based on that guess, and it just happens to be correct. And again, no questions asked and no explanations. There are multiple such ignored bits in this movie.The mentioned physics is bad too. Bosons do not have anti-particles, and the Higgs field gives *everything* mass, and exists everywhere. Although the Higgs was not yet experimentally confirmed by the time this movie was made, this has been theorised for some time. It would only take a simple internet search.However, the movie has some good aspects too. The visuals are beautiful. There is some really aesthetic lightning and scenery. The planet Solaris looks fascinating, and there are some nice shots of it. There are a few good story elements about love and regret, and the occasional emotional atmosphere. Background music is fitting.

reviews.review_title: Does everything possible to keep you in the theater
reviews.content: The original Solaris by Andrei Tarkovsky is a cult classic.  Rent it at Blockbuster and compare.  As with all Tarkovsky's movies, it is made for the "enlightened" and does not even make an attempt to win over anybody else. You'll see how much more of the story Tarkovsky leaves off the screen - for the patient viewer to reconstruct.  Your attention will be challenged by seemingly endless visual sequences. At times the dialog is so rich with different ideas that you need to rewind a few times to simply hear it all. Thus the Tarkovsky's version would not work for general audiences - it requires too much commitment from the viewer.  I saw it in the 70s, people were walking out of the theater - just as expected.Soderbergh knows all that and makes everything humanly possible to adjust the movie to the general public's tastes.  He focuses on the most fundamental ideas.  He sticks to the tightest, most straightforward storyline.  He cuts the movie himself with the precision of Eric Clapton's guitar.  He also knows that he will lose audiences if he fails to entertain them all the time, so he casts two undisputedly beautiful actors: Clooney and Natascha McElhone, augments the couple with a wonderfully funny sidekick (Jeremy Davies). He turns every frame into a glamor shot, adds romantic love scenes (with nudity, mind you), a state-of-the-art sci-fi soundtrack and elaborate computer graphics... and still people walk out of the theater. My heart breaks.  I fear that before long movie makers will just give up.

reviews.review_title: Should not have recieved wide-screen release.
reviews.content:
Most people who have reviewed this film see it as boring and ponderous. It doesn't have the classic sci-fi lasers, explosions, and aliens with five apostrophes in their name. This is, unfortunately, the exact same attitude that expelled Stanslaw Lem from the Science Fiction Writers of America in 1976.The main problem is the film is, it should not have received a wide-screen release, but should have been reserved for release to the art-houses. I fear Clooney's star-power or the fact that James Cameron produced the picture may have prevented the film from being released to a more suitable audience. The main-stream American audience is not going to "get" the point of the film; because of the subtlety of the script, it requires more attention than the average fan-boy is used to spending.This is also a good example of what C.S. Lewis called "true science fiction", in that the science of the situation is necessary for the sequence of events to occur. There is no way for Chris to re-live his past mistakes with Rheya unless she shows up for him to interact with her.
Another problem most viewers may find with the film is that it is character driven. This is difficult for many American audiences to take (coming from a goal-oriented society) and few have the patience or constitution to try and find out more about a character. Plots are much easier to digest.It's a beautiful film, well photographed and stunningly directed. The performances are strong, but handle what would have been a difficult script for lesser actors. The sets are breath taking and the costuming is detailed without being ridiculous.I'm only sorry it was set before the wrong audience. Their disappointment in this film is based on ignorance and an assumption that all science fiction belongs in the "action" or "horror" sections of their local Blockbuster.

Ignore the reviews, SOLARIS (2002) is great.  Bright, beautiful, and compact. Borrowing from Tarkovsky's 1972 Soviet version of the film, Soderbergh openshis remake on Earth (unlike Lem's novel, which takes place entirely in space) and brilliantly sets the tone for his entire interpretation of the story. He makes Chris Kelvin a burned-out shrink, rather than a scientist or "accountant,"allowing George Clooney wide range for his emotional response to the..."occurrences" ... he finds on the Solaris station.  Jeremy Davies is, as always, amazing, and gives his version of Dr. Snow twists that bring the general tension and surrealism of the original novel to palpable cinematic clarity.  And, they've even managed to eke viable plot out of  Lem's otherwise philosophical tract by re-drawing the third character as Helen Gordon, a obsessed physicist,constructed with diabolical focus by Viola Davis, who's driving force is to see that "Humanity wins."  The three ingredients, emotion, surrealism and a mission, transform the abstract elements of the novel and original film into one of the most intelligent sci fi films since 2001.  There's room on Planet Earth for a few smart films like SOLARIS.

Yep, awful. Didn't expect much, and it let me down. How anyone voted this as a 10 is absolutely ridiculous.Although, i must admit, watchable, i watched till the end. And the end was incredibly disappointing.Clooney is absorbed to the ship immediately, whereas you'd have to be mad to believe what happens to him even in the first few moments.You'd expect the character, a doctor going there to save them, to be reasonably sane. Yet he takes to it like a duck to water.There is know twist, the fact that one of the small parts is actually one of the beings has zero relevance to the plot. In fact that being some detracts from the film rather than increasing the storyline.Maybe i was rather generous with my vote of a 4, but as I didn't turn it off, I felt i had to give it something.

I will keep this short. This truly brilliant filmaking. The movie, of course, is not for everyone, but if you are patient and enjoy woderful visual style, solid thematic representation, and a thought provoking finale, then get out and see this film. Soderbergh is probably the best director working today, and George Clooney continues to impress.

reviews.review_title: Big disappointment on this confused film
reviews.content: I think not only myself, but the movie itself, got confused.The first trailers I saw made it appear a sci-fi movie. Then the trailers turned into a psychological drama. The movie turned into somewhere in left field.It has the worse parts of 2001, the pinch yourself to stay awake, in less than a 2 hour film. I even thought the last image of the film looked amazingly like the red light of Hal.Take the plot summary on imdb :"Upon arrival at the space station orbiting an ocean world called Solaris a psychologist discovers that the commander of an expedition to the planet has died mysteriously... "Not once did they mention an expedition to the planet. They floated around this big glowing orb, looked like a star. Died mysteriously? The first thing they said is he committed suicide, this is never questioned. Where's the mystery?So somehow between filming and release the story got confused, the end result is just as confused.Looking at online reviews it appears it received some praise from those who saw it before the official release. The other reviews say it's ambiguous. I can only guess some last minute changes were made.My suggestion, wait until the director's cut DVD comes out and maybe the film will be worth watching.

Stanislaw Lem died a few weeks ago, and upon reading the NY Times obit I realized I had never read anything he wrote. Three books were especially recommended, so I got them all. I am sorry to report that I could not make it through "His Master's Voice," but I thought "Solaris" was inspired. After reading the book, I got the movie and watched it last night. I was more than an hour into the movie when my wife came downstairs. I ranted for a while about how disappointed I was with it, and about how little it seemed to have in common with the brilliant book. She said "So then how come you are still watching it?" Good question. I turned it off and went to bed.I guess what it comes down to is that if this movie had been called anything other than "Solaris," I probably wouldn't have minded, but "Solaris" the book and "Solaris" the movie do not overlap.

reviews.review_title: Solaris: A movie, that sparked interest, but failed to ignite the stove.
reviews.content: When I hired this movie, I had no preconceived ideas and started watching with no expectations at all as I have not seen the original or read the novel.What I found was a movie that had a decent foundation, the ideas altogether held my interest, and so I continued to persist with the movie, hoping for an astounding revelation or discovery, but overall the film was astoundingly slow and there was no shock forthcoming, another negative point was the lack of connectivity between all it's parts and so I felt the film didn't really flow that well, a few minor holes were not filled, and characters were not fully developed.Overall I gave this film 3 stars, 1 positive is that it made me interested in reading the novel, and seeing the original film.

Solaris is based on a Russian movie named Solyaris. The plot elements are very similar between the two versions, but the Solyaris is quite a bit longer than Solaris. The planet/object 'Solaris' has intelligence; the capability to manifest your subconsciousness or dreams into reality. This is a common theme in Soviet era movies, for example the Russian made movie Stalker in 1979 is a quest to find a place in "The Zone" where you could basically get your wishes granted. Considering the bland lives of living in the Soviet union during that era, it's no wonder movies like this made such an impression on those people.The point of the movie is that if you could have your dreams, would you forgo reality and choose the dreams? In Solaris, the manifestations of your dreams take on a life of their own. The consequences are not predictable, so maybe dreams are best left locked up in the mind...

reviews.review_title: Thanks Mr. Soderbergh for your originality!
reviews.content: This is by far the most philosophically challenging moment in the life of James T. Kirk (George Clooney), Captain of the U.S.S. Enterprise.  Lost in the Nexus during a rescue operation on board the Enterprise-B, Kirk realizes that he can fix his regrets from the past, erase his personal mistakes, while in the Nexus.  Fellow Starfleet officer Jean-Luc Picard (Viola Davis ), Captain of the Enterprise-D, also becomes trapped in the Nexus. After realizing the emptiness of life in the Nexus, Picard attempts to convince Kirk of the same.  But, will Kirk choose to remain in the Nexus and live a hollow, vapid existence, forever reliving and reshaping his past, or will he follow Picard back to reality?  I won't ruin the end for you..  you'll have to see it to believe it!

"Solaris"The script and story sure were very interesting . Tonight, however, I felt somewhat cheated watching this film. Reviews and magazines were talking about "science fiction" and Soderbergh stating that this film resembled for him what "2001" resembled for Kubrick. I can honestly say:  Mr Soderbergh, you are wrong : Solaris is not 2001.In fact, you missed any opportunity to convert this film into a visual and emotional masterpiece. You decided to shoot almost the entire movie in closed rooms and repeat an establishing shot of the cosmos over and over again. Is this really your vision for a movie that could have defied the meaning of what a science fiction film is all about?You said in an interview that this was supposed to be your last film before going into a break..Please do. Have some rest. And when you come back  bring us more of that mojo , those risks you took in those previous movies , the ones before "Ocean Eleven" of course, another "just-good-for-rental" film.Yours truly,a Fan.

While watching "Solaris", I kept checking my watch. I found it slow in the beginning, and I found myself wondering what the point was going to be.I got more out of the movie thinking about it afterwards. Thinking about the relationship between the two lead characters, the way things can turn sour, the mistakes they made, and the regret they felt when it was too late.The movie has themes about heaven, redemption, and life after death. Although I found it slow, I enjoyed talking about it afterward, and thinking about it.

Unlike the Tarkovsky version this concentrates on the heart rather than the philosophy of the book - which is ironic since Lem objected to the humanisation in the Tarkovsky version. An emotional journey into relationships and what they entail. Soderbergh weaves a tapestry of human emotion beyond the book's boundaries, and beyond Lem's original novel, which sacrificed passion for debate. And it still manages to homage the Tarkovsky version with the water motif (rain on the window in the first shot - rain in the background in the dinner conversation scene.) Soderburgh has taken the source material and crafted an original piece of cinema which reflects both the book and the original film. And to add to that, the music's fantastic.

The movie started slowly, very slowly, and an hour later I was still wondering when anything of any real note was going to occur. The story revolves around the central character Chris (Clooney)being sent to a research station. He is still haunted by memories of his beautiful wife Rheya. Several characters have died in mysterious circumstances, and the other two paper thin characters- (whom we rarely see) say he'll soon find out why for himself. This leads us into a psychological nightmare for both Clooney and the viewer ,as he tries to work out why the lovely Rheya has returned to the station. Where did she come from? Is this really in his mind? Is he going mad? Do we really care!There are endless irrelevant romantic flashbacks and the whole thing seems as endless as space itself. Hardly gripping Sci-fi bring back the Daleks! 3/10.

I saw this film last night and it's been in my head all day today. Why oh why aren't more sci-fi films like this made these days, instead of "blockbusters" like Attack of the Clones and Independence Day? I saw both of these films on release and left the theatre feeling let-down and disappointed. Not so Solaris. From the opening sequence I was captivated. Everything - visuals, music, atmosphere, acting (especially Clooney) were top notch. I've always thought he was a decent actor but this for me was by far a career best. Ok there was some unnecessary shots of his butt but who cares? Even my girlfriend, not the deepest thinker that's ever lived, confessed that she'd enjoyed it. Reading some of the user comments I gather this film bombed in America, which doesn't surprise me. If it's not a film involving gung-ho heroes killing every baddie in sight or a film where they re-write history to suit themselves - see U571 or The Patriot - they really don't want to know (my apologies to the half of America which has a brain, and I suspect there ARE a few of you!). Anyway I give Solaris a deseved 9/10. And do you know I went to see this film on a Wednesday night, the theatre was three-quaters full, and not a SINGLE person left before the end!

reviews.review_title: Don't waste your time to go see this slow laborious bore.
reviews.content: I appreciate cerebral science fiction, i.e. 2001 or Blade Runner, but you have to stay awake to enjoy it.  The film does have some interesting ideas, but the film ran in slow motion so you keep waiting for something to happen or inspire you, but it never does.  You never get to the point where you care about the characters.  The big talk is seeing George Clooney's behind, but you have to be awake to see it.  Sorry, but don't waste your money to go see this movie.  Maybe video rental when it comes out in 1-2 months, but at least then you can sleep in your own living room.

Without doubt the must awful movie I have ever seen The pace is very slow the story makes no sense and George Clooney is rubbish he has no emotion Will never like him since he ruined batman He couldn't act his way out of a paper bag He's overrated It's just boring and I like intelligent movies Watch sphere if you want a good movie that is similar Maybe the original Russian movie is better

THis is a very interesting, and yes, very American version of Stanislaw Lem's original novel.Similar in tone to the Russian film of 1972 but less ambiguous and like the Russian film throws away the novel's ridiculous ending.Kris Kelvin's pain is much clearer than in the 1972 and his jettisoning of his wife's first imitation is heartbreaking.Clooney hands in only a less stiff performance than usual, but his style is appropriate to Soderburg's approach.I enjoyed this movie very much and enjoy it more as time passes.

reviews.review_title: THIS IS NOT A SCI-FI MOVIE
reviews.content: I was bored. I wandered around the video store looking at all the shiny boxes, until (as always) I closed my eyes, spun around and grabbed something. Lo and behold, I had grasped Solaris. Somewhere in the back of my head, I think I recalled hearing someone say it was slow movie... I've sat through worse, so I figured I'd go for it.I got it home and proceeded to watch it. (As is the thing to do with just rented movies.) I have to say... I pity the fool who watches this movie in hopes of a sci-fi romp.Solaris is a beautifully done vaguely experimental piece, exploring notions of life, death, heaven, hell, memories, the soul, all kinds of things. I heard the original movie was 5 hours long. Most of you will be relieved to know that it's only 99 minutes... Some of you will be horrified to know that it feels *every bit that long and then some*.This is not a plot-driven story... It kind of gives a body to the, "it's not the destination it's the journey" addage. All in all, this is a film simply exploring ideas and notions. The whole sci-fi surrounding is just a catalyst to give the topics the jumpingboard they need.As near as I can tell, there are about 2 different sides when it comes to this movie, portrayed here, by the actual conversation with my father at the movie's conclusion:Me: I think solaris is a metaphor of God. Dad: I think solaris is a metaphor of suck movie.Watch it, but know that THIS IS NOT A SCI-FI MOVIE.

I'm disappointed that the film enthusiasts of imdb could hate this film so much. Please save your venom for the $100 million garbage spewed forth weekly by the studio factories. ***SPOILERS*** So here we have a militant atheist, scientist (psychiatrist) and all around smug intellectual - a real shining specimen of the greatest species in the universe. What happens when such a person is unexpectedly confronted with with an intelligence far superior to his own? An intelligence that (inadvertently?) shows you just how insignificant you are by effortlessly creating physical replicas of people from your own memories? Now the real confusion sets in. The person that appears out of nowhere just happens to be your dead wife. Flashbacks/dreams tell the story of love, depression, suicide and regret. What the other comments fail to mention is how lively the character is in these dream sequences as the romance blossoms. The disconnected character portrayed is not bad acting - it is good acting for a character whose lover had recently made good on her threat to kill herself.What is Solaris? Is it a heavenly messenger from which God issues second chances? This is the most pleasant conclusion and one which the emotional doctor embraces. The scene in which the duplicate wife explains her confusion about her situation - having memories but no feeling associated with them - is pretty haunting. These disturbing scenes just escalate - he tries to calm her with pills, then plans for a return to Earth. She is suicidal because: (1) his memories are of a suicidal wife, and (2) her awareness of her "situation" drives her mad. After some disturbing scenes, she is successful in her suicide attempt. The now more rational doctor is convinced by the other "real" person on the station that Solaris must be some malevolent alien intelligence and Earth must be warned. Are its intentions really bad? Or does it just not understand the consequences of its actions to humans? This idea doesn't comfort me at all. We are used to being the masters of our universe, with every frontier to be conquered eventually. What if we are doomed forever to continued suffering at the hands of unknowable forces?Anyway, interesting flick. I applaud the artistic and philosophical effort.

reviews.review_title: I was very sceptical about it earlier...
reviews.content:
I was very skeptical about it earlier, especially because of George Clooney. Anyways, we had our very occasional sci-fi evening yesterday, and in between Ukkonen (nice short Finnish sci-fi-action flick) and Hitch Hikers Guide BBC series this title came up. I got curios, throw out my biases, walked briskly to the store today, and enjoyed the movie on DVD.Oh, was I surprised how well Soderbergh has got it together. And don't anybody worry, Clooney handles his burden respectably.
All you Tarkovsky freaks and sci-fi puritans, please give it a chance, you might like it somewhat. I did.

reviews.review_title: "I'm sure glad that I didn't pay to see this".
reviews.content: I won free tickets to see "Solaris" as did the rest of the audience at this sneak preview.  The movie was slow and confusing at times.  The audience laughed when they weren't supposed to and I saw a few people walk out. George Clooney did a fair job acting in a role that wasn't too challenging. I never saw the original and now I have no desire to.  I overheard a woman sum up my feelings when I overheard her say "I'm sure glad that I didn't pay to see this".

reviews.review_title: Movies are supposed to be entertaining!
reviews.content: I own over 3500 videos and aprox. 400 DVD's. I admit that doesn't make me an expert on good or bad films, but I do know when I have been entertained. As soon as I saw the star of this film was George Clooney I said to myself, "this movie has to at least have some moments". Boy was I wrong!!! I used to buy a DVD or video on story power or sometimes just on a favorite star but NO MORE!!! After paying close to $20.00 and sitting through 99 minutes of the most boring movie I have ever watched I will make triple sure that I at least hear a few people say something like "Wow" or "Great flick" before I waste another dime on lousy movies. The only movie that I can put in this same category is About Schmidt, one of the years worst films, but was great compared to this stinky thing someone had the nerve to call a movie. Trust me, save your money and you would be better off spending the time bitting your nails.

I don't know if this is a 'thinking persons' movie.  I do believe that people who are more comfortable with concrete thoughts and actions will dislike it intensely (as shown by the incredible volume of negative user reviews here).If you read, and enjoy being gently lowered into a different world by a good author, then you will probably enjoy this movie thoroughly.  If you don't enjoy external manipulation of your thoughts and feelings, you won't enjoy this movie - you will find it boring and pedantic.I thoroughly enjoyed being pulled into this dream.  Everything about it, from the beginning (no credits, it just starts) to the end, works to take you away from the norm and move you towards Solaris and its own reality.I saw the original film a few months before the new version was released. Although I respected it for the vision and style, I was not able to really feel a part of it.  Maybe because of the subtitles, or because its pace is more designed for a European sensibility, I found myself drifting away from it many times.  Clooney's Solaris, with its quiet feeling also allows me to drift, but pulls me in and holds me there.When a movie or book is able to envelop me in its dream, and actually hold me there long after the end, it has accomplished its goal.  Solaris held its pull on me long after the last view of the planet disappeared from my screen.  I was left with that dreamlike feeling and mood for a long time afterwards.  To me, that is the ultimate sign of an excellent story well directed and acted.

reviews.review_title: I just seen the sneek preview of this!
reviews.content: I just saw the sneek preview of this film.  This was a great piece of art. George Clooney did an excellent job in this movie as did Sodenberg. Solaris moved along kind of slow in the beginning and ended with a great climax. This movie touched religion and the existence of other beings in the world. I would definitly recommend this film.

**SPOILERS!!!** Soderbergh has a tendency to produce good movies and bad movies, so I was somewhat worried when I walked into the movie.  It started off giving me a bad impression, but completely saved itself at the very end. Watching the movie, I was consistently reminded of the Myst game series.  Not for stylistic reasons, but simply the overall detached tone seemed to be very similar.  This movie is an example of Soderbergh's incredible ability to imply things very subtly.  Half the plot is hinted at through flashbacks, and for those people who like to think, a lot is told in so little time. This movie makes no attempt to explain the science fiction it incorporates.  Rather, it spends its short time explaining the psychology of the humans and Solaris.  People going in expecting a sci-fi will be greatly disappointed if they are expecting realism; this is a psychological movie, and explains that well. My favorite line was the last part, where George Clooney asks, "Am I alive, or dead?"  It doesn't matter, because if he believes he is happy, then it is of no consequence whether or not he is dead.  This is how the entire movie is; even we do not know whether he is actually at Earth and dreaming, or still in Solaris.  It is an exploration of the human mind, and how it reacts.  This is the type of thing that Soderbergh often attempts, and when he succeeds, delivers a

I want my money back!!!! After pleading to my girlfriend and cousin that we go see this movie, I was embarrassed that it was so bad that half the audience left the movie theater before it ended...With Clooney begging to be in this role,  Soderbergh at the helm, and James Cameron producing, I thought it was a "sure bet" that it would be very entertaining.  I'm the type of person who sees many different kinds of movies (from G rated to Adult) and different genres (from comedy to psycho-thrillers), but this movie was so boring that I too almost left. PLEASE DO NOT MAKE THE SAME MISTAKE AS I DID- Wait atleast for video or you will be extremely disappointed! Shame on you Soderbergh, after hits like TRAFFIC and ERIN BROCKOVICH, you made a big stinker of a movie.  Please  take some time off and THINK carefully about your next project.

reviews.review_title: Very narrow and straight forward compared to the classic Russian Solyaris (1972)
reviews.content: The original movie, although by today's standards very outdated, displayed a bigger picture, unlike the new Solaris which simply focuses on the romance between Chris Kelvin and Rheya Kelvin. Some other plot twists attached to the new Solaris were disgustingly irrelevant to the general mood of the picture and the story in general. SOLYARIS DOES NOT DO THESE THINGS.See the classic, please.

reviews.review_title: You will leave the theatre with questions
reviews.content: What you'll leave the theatre with is exactly what Chris Kelvin is having to deal with when he arrives at the space station orbiting Solaris.The answers aren't given to you by Soderbergh.  You're forced to think about what is happening and why.If you're looking for an A+B=C kind of movie, Solaris will disappoint.  If you like being left thinking in a continuous loop of deciding what happened and why, you'll love this film."There are no answers, only choices.", Gibarian

I just saw this movie, and totally loved it, probably because I UNDERSTOOD it.  I had seen the Russian original a couple of months ago (didn't even know about this one, until I saw an ad on TV a couple of weeks ago), so perhaps that helps we with some background knowledge of the story to begin with.  I didn't understand the Russian version though, maybe because I accidentally watched the second tape before the first one.  I thought the story was much clearer in this movie, probably because it was in English, and was a modern production.  I remember thinking how quiet the movie was, but that it was good, because so many modern movies rely so heavily on music and action to capture the short attention span of the general public. It would be great to see a good movie with no action and no music helping it along. If someone doesn't like the movie because they don't understand it, that's a shame, because it is a wonderful movie, and gave me an emotional hangover as I was leaving the theater.

reviews.review_title: This is THE MOST BORING movie I have ever seen! Save your money!
reviews.content: Worse than Event Horizon! I'm Talking Boring! Save your money on this one folks. I would have never believed it if I hadn't seen it with my own two eyes.

I really wanted to like this movie, but to me it failed miserably.  I went into the film anticipating a thinker and was excited at the prospect, but I feel the execution of the film failed miserably.  Ive never seen so many people walk out of a movie half way through.  The shots were beautiful and well-done, but the story never took off and bored more than enlightened. I know everyone is jumping on the bandwagon for this movie and giving it rave reviews, but this is just a badly plotted and paced film.

I couldn't stay awake. One of the most boring movies ever produced. I liked 2001 even though I didn't understand it. This tried to duplicate the cerebral mood of 2001 but it was bad. There were some points where you were about to have an emotion or two, but it never panned out. I want my $9.50 and two hours of my life back!

reviews.review_title: I actually signed up to IMDb to write a review on this movie
reviews.content: Yes, I actually signed up to IMDb to write a review on this movie.Having seen the original 70s film and reading the book, this version seemed utterly boring and badly developed.The 70s version will really boggle your mind, if you'll have the patience to watch it from start to finish. I would not recommend seeing this movie if you've read the book or seen the original movie.

reviews.review_title: Very good movie based on Lem's novel
reviews.content: Warning: MINOR SPOILERS --------------Excellent story-telling, with great visuals, editing and music. A treat for Soderbergh fans.In my opinion, one of the central ideas of the novel was man's first contact with extra-terrestrial life, and the problems inherent to such an event. The movie refers to this a few times, perhaps more so in the ending, which is different from the one in the novel. The last scene in the novel is pretty cool too...The movie is almost entirely devoted to the love story (sub-plot), which is nicely done, with good acting by the cast.If you like 2001:A Space Odyssey (many references in the movie), are a Soderbergh fan, or like "atmospheric" movies, you will like this one.

Wasn't planning to go, seeing many negative reviews here. I went and there are no regrets! Not for those who enjoys movies based on cartoons or comics, chewing popcorn and slurping coke. It requires you to WATCH, listen, and think. It took me a bit to be taken in by this movie's plot.  The untransitioned shots and plot-jumps were confusing at first until the mindset of the movie was obvious.  I enjoy movies that make the viewer THINK about things in life we take for granted, which this movie does well.
